<item>
  <title>About</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/about/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 02 Jun 2011 06:59:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?page_id=2</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[In 2009, at age forty-four, I joined the statistics of one in eight women diagnosed with breast cancer each year. The medical team told me, "You're healthyâwith cancer." Sort of funny, isn't it?

This blog includes tips I found along the way on my journey.Â My intention in sharing is to lighten your loadâwhether you are the one diagnosed, or a caregiver.

I never refer to the individual experiencing cancer as a warrior, victim, or survivor. Nor do I refer to cancer as a fight, struggle, battle, or war. I urge the reader to stay in conscious gratitude for people, events and things in their life.

Many of the suggestions I'll provide are universal for anyone needing help regardless of gender or diagnosis.
<div><span style="color:#000000;font-size:small;">Health and Happiness,
</span><span style="color:#000000;font-size:small;">Claudia</span></div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div><strong>Â </strong></div>
<div style="text-align:center;">Â© 2012 Claudia Mulcahy</div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Decide how you will you approach this opportunity</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/02/decide-how-you-will-you-approach-this-opportunity/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 02 Jun 2011 05:56:18 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=3</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I don't call myself a<em>Â warrior, victim,</em><em>Â or survivor. NorÂ </em>I donât refer to cancer as a <em>struggle</em>, <em>fight</em>, <em>battle</em>, or <em>war</em>. <em>Â </em>I see the experience of cancer as a path. To walk a path, we must put one foot in front of the other. No two people will experience this journey the same way.

The ideas I share are practical, inexpensive and useful for someone diagnosed with cancer, and those who love them. The tips are written for women newly diagnosed with breast cancer, but are often appropriate regardless of gender, or type of cancer. They are uncommon, common-sense suggestions.

I wish you peace. Deep Peace.

I wish you health, and happiness.

Godâs Blessings to you, and to those who help you.

Claudia]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Choose Wisely</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/06/choose-wisely/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 06 Jun 2011 04:59:13 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=25</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If youâve just been diagnosed, you may want to be alone with the information for a while before figuring out how to tell someone else. When youâre ready, share whatâs going on with someone you trust. Find a grounded, emotionally strong and supportive person. This is such a highly private, intimate and emotionally charged diagnosis. People can hardly say the word âcancerâ let alone âbreastâ and ânipple!â Itâs a crucial time to find how you and others will cope.

Donât run around telling the world youâre having a biopsy. Some folks thrive on drama. Theyâre the ones whoâll tell you horror stories, warnings, and worry for you instead of providing strength. Chose with whom you share wisely.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Love and Fear</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/09/love-and-fear/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 09 Jun 2011 21:30:53 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=35</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[However she responds to the diagnosis of cancer, remember two things: There are only two emotions from which everything else evolves. <em>Love</em> and <em>Fear</em>. If sheâs showing up angry, look behind that behavior. Itâs fear. Fear of hair loss, energy loss,and loss of independence. Fear of others washing her dishes incorrectly. (Yes, get ready for some irrational behavior!

Meet her to the best of your ability, with love. It doesnât make her outbursts acceptable. It makes them endurable. The ride of emotions is likely to calm down soon. It may ebb and flow for a year or two, peaking around new events, such as first chemo, radiation, and each surgery.

<strong>Tip</strong>: Recognize <em>your</em> emotions. Fear, judgement, discomfort, pure loveâyou name it. Knowing where you <em>really</em> are with <em>your</em> emotions, not pretending or wishing, will help you.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>They Ainât Broke!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/20/they-ain%e2%80%99t-broke/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 20 Jun 2011 17:59:24 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=38</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[The person diagnosed with cancer isnât broken. They donât need fixinâ. If youâre a fixer, that puts you in a tough positionâbut not impossible. You know you would do anything for the person diagnosed. No matter what you do, they still have cancer.

So. . . take a deep breath, and a step back.

I liken this stage to a broken arm. You canât fix her arm. But you can help her. You can drive her to the doctors. You can also make her dinner, or bring over some chocolate chip cookies. Thereâs no cast to sign with cancer, but there are cards to send, calls to make, and help needed for chores.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Treatmentâs Over, Now What?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/13/treatment%e2%80%99s-over-now-what/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 13 Jun 2011 05:43:06 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=41</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I called a friend in the mid-west whoâs recently completed treatment for lung cancer. (Never smoked a day in her life.) Itâs tough for her now. She wants to âget back to livingâ but is tired, moody, and not moving well. She has neuropathy in her feet, and her joints are stiffâ both side effects from chemo.

I told her I thought the six to twelve months after treatment are, in a way, as tough as the treatment itself. People (including the person fresh out of treatment) think, âHey, it's over, I should be able to get back into life.â

Chemo. Radiation. Surgeryâeven on their own areÂ <em>major</em>Â stuff!Â Your bodyâs healing. Be gentle with yourself. Allow your mind and body time to adjust to the new normal. For me, things seemed to get a bit worse before they got better. I think that's because I was more aware, more awake, and more eager to "move on." That's when neuropathy and Â joint pain set in, and I realized how weak I'd becomeâall while my "To Do List" kept growing.

<strong>Tip</strong>: Caregivers and friends - Even when treatment ends, she may find answering the phone is easier than initiating a call. Donât be afraid about âdisturbingâ someone. You can leave them a message, or ask them the best time to call again.]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Free iPhone App: Breast Cancer Diagnosis Guide</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/16/free-iphone-app-breast-cancer-diagnosis-guide/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 16:14:31 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=47</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I recently found this goodie on www.breastcancer.org: As of February 2011, thereâs a free iphone app: Breast Cancer Diagnosis Guide. This app walks you through your breast cancer pathology report, other tests and information that you and your doctor will use to help decide which treatments are right for you. Add your diagnosis information for easy reference, and receive relevant articles from www.breastcancer.org re: research news. The app includes illustrations and definitions. The Breast Cancer Diagnosis Guide mobile app was named an Official Honoree by theÂ 2011 Webby Awards.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The Waiting Game</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/23/the-waiting-game/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 23 Jun 2011 16:04:52 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=60</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Waiting for test results isnât easy. Not all tests are done by the same lab, and some take longer than others to get/give results.
Be patient. Youâre gathering lots of information now, and when enough puzzle pieces are together, you and your doctor can sit down and talk about the reports so you understand your options for a treatment plan.
You may be tempted to search the internet for information. I highly suggest you share what you find, and thoughts you have with your medical team. Anyone can put anything on the internet. Donât believe it all (that goes for hear-say as well.) Use reputable sites, and common sense.

Four credible websites:

BreastCancer.org
CureToday.com
<a class="zem_slink" title="National Cancer Institute" href="http://www.cancer.gov/" rel="homepage">National Cancer Institute</a>: www.cancer.gov
<a class="zem_slink" title="American Cancer Society" href="http://www.cancer.org/" rel="homepage">American Cancer Society</a>: www.cancer.org]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Tips for Cancer-Prevention Dining  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1490</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1490</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

I make fish tacos at home and love them. I tend to use bass, halibut or cod with lots of shredded cabbage, some hot sauce and a blop of plain yogurt wrapped in flat bread. Recently, I was taken to a Mexican restaurant for brunch. I ordered the fish taco combo. What a surprise when a <i>huge</i> deep fried pice of fish took up most of my plate. âDeep friedâ hadnât even crossed my mind, and it wasnât written up in the menu as such. I scraped away the breaded shell until discovering a <i>tiny</i> piece of fish.

Iâm conscious of what, and how much I eat. Here are some healthy tips you may want to consider before eating out, where it can be more difficult to keep things in moderation.
<ul>
	<li>Drink a glass of low-sodium vegetable juice before starting your meal (or before you leave for the restaurant.) Itâs healthy, and will fill you up a bit.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>When you have something like ice cream, an alcoholic beverage or a deep fried item, âtrade offâ by passing the bread, chips, or mashed potatoes.Â  (Or, if youâre like me, youâll skip the ice cream and alcohol so I can have my carbs in peace.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Eat the good-for-you-stuff. I must admit, I do not like restaurant veggies, but I do still eat them, as small as the portion of them is. Theyâre over cooked, sitting in butter, and they just donât taste right. Iâve heard some restaurants add sugar to them. Iâll usually eat an apple before going to a restaurant. (Thatâs one of those âtrade-offsâ mentioned above.) Other ways to eat the good stuff is to look for dishes with fruit, whole grains, lean proteins. Some include fish, chicken, tofu, cottage cheese and beans. Beware, many restaurants, especially Mexican use lard in their refried beans, and some other beans are high in calories. No need to be paranoid, just be conscious of your choices.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Share your meal, or take half of it home. NO BODY needs an 18oz piece of steak, or fish for that matter. Three ounces of protein a meal is what you need.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Skip the appetizer, or share it. Or, make it your meal with a salad or soup.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If the menu lists the calorie and fat count, read it. Fat from calories shouldnât be more than one-third of the total calorie count. If calories per serving are 300, fat from calories should be less than 100. Here are some numbers from the <a title="American inst for Caner Research" href="www.aicr.org. ">American Institute for Cancer research</a> (AICR).Â Aim for your meal to be 400-500 calories.Â  (If you Supersize your meal at one of those take-out places, youâre almost at your entire daily calorie count of 2,000!) In general, avoid trans fat. Keep saturated fat to 20 grams or less a day, or at least aim for low numbers. Sodium should be kept to 600 milligrams or less per meal. (I find this per meal number high.) Fiber: do you get 25 grams per day? Most people donât.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Eat slowly. Chew your food. Chew, then talk; not both at the same time. If the music is loud or fast, youâll have to be more aware of your eating pace.</li>
</ul>
These are just a few of many tips you can incorporate into a healthy, cancer-preventative, social lifestyle.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>th</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/30/radiation-hair-loss-and-the-circadian-cycle/th-2/</link>

<item>
  <title>Grew Summer Tomatoes - Now What?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1803</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1803</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/tomato-vine.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1804" alt="tomato vine" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/tomato-vine.jpg" width="317" height="318" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Did you grow tomatoes this summer and now wonder what to do with them? If you can find a neighbor who grew zucchini, youâre in luck! Swap vegetables, and swap some recipes, too. Here are some facts about the tomato you can digest in good health:

When processed or cooked, tomatoes actually contain more lycopene than raw tomatoes. The structure of the antioxidant lycopene changes, making it more easily absorbed by our bodies. So, pour on the pasta sauce, and feel good about buying canned tomatoes in the winter. Just half-cup of tomato sauce is plenty for an adequate lycopene boost to your system. Food sources of lycopene have been found to be more beneficial than supplements. For more information about lycopene,

http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/dietandnutrition/lycopene

<b>Tons of tomatoesânow what?</b>

Tomatoes are consumed more than any other non-starchy vegetable in America. Here are some ideas to make sure they donât go to waste.
<ul>
	<li>Share them! If a friend or neighbor has plenty of something else, barter ;)</li>
	<li>No sandwich is complete without a tomato slice.</li>
	<li>Is spaghetti for dinner? Cook up some tomatoes, and crush them for the sauce.</li>
	<li>To add some character to your breakfast eggs, dice some tomatoes.</li>
	<li>Cold or warm tomato or gazpacho soup. Youâre on your own here. Iâve never made either.</li>
	<li>Stuff tomatoes like you would a stuffed pepper and cook, or stuff it with tuna, or cottage cheese.</li>
	<li>Make stew or soup with all sorts of tomatoes: fresh, canned, dried - they each add their own flavor.</li>
</ul>
<b>For snacks or hâorderves:</b>
<ul>
	<li>Make some salsa for a quick appetizer: (dice tomatoes, chop cilantro, onion, jalapeno pepper, garlic, and squeeze some lemon.) If you have a molcajete - a traditional Mexican version of a mortar and pestle, crush the ingredients - itâll bring the flavor out even more by crushing them a bit. If you like smooth rather than chunky salsa, put things in the blender after you chop them up.</li>
	<li>Another side dish or snack with tomato: thick slices of tomatoes and alternatively overlap with slices of mozzarella cheese as you make your way around a plate (If youâre near a Costco, they sell packages already sliced.) Add some fresh basil. Drizzle olive oil on top, and add salt and pepper, and balsamic vinegar if you want a stronger flavor.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The New Normal</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/04/the-new-normal/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 04 Jul 2011 15:27:17 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=67</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Hooray!! Cancer treatment is over! It makes you want to do a cartwheel even if you never could!
Three months after my last chemo, two months after my bi-lateral mastectomy, and one month after starting the reconstruction process with expanders, I freaked out in the oncology office. âMy hair is growing back, why donât I have energy?â

They call it âtransitionâ or, âthe new normâ. For the last few months, youâve been focused on getting better; crossing the finish line. But now, Who will drive you? Who will help you grocery shop? Who will make a quick meal on a day you feel you've expended finite energy? Who will understand your need for talking a lot about cancer nowâor not at all.

Iâd used the gauge of my hair growing back to determine when and how my body should get through the day without naps or help. Ooooo so wrong.Â My oncologist answered my question about hair growth equating to energy by saying, âYouâve been through major stuff! Your bodyâs recovering. Give it one-two years.â
So, your hairâs growing back. You look great. Everyone is breathing a sigh of relief. Go easy. It takes time for physical and emotional healing. Family and friends are in new roles, too. They no longer need to drive you everywhere, and may not see how getting the mail, AND watering plants, AND cooking adds up to your exhaustion.
<strong> Tip</strong>: Continue to ask people for help up to six months after treatment. A bag of Russet potatoes is heavy! Get someone else to pick it up for you.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Questions To Ask Your Doctor Before Cancer Treatment</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/27/questions-to-ask-your-doctor-before-cancer-treatment/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2011 13:38:53 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=83</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Some Ideas of Questions To Ask:

Whatâs the treatment plan? Whatâs the goal of treatment? (Cure? Remission? Symptoms relieved?) What are potential risks of the treatment? Some doctors donât like to talk about side effects, thinking it may plant the seed for your mind to run wild. If you feel your doctorâs not talking, ask more questions. Even if all the answers are, âIt varies.â âItâs so individual.â âWe donât know.â But ask, âWhat do I do if _____?â âWill âitâ (nausea, neuropathy. . .) go away?â âWill âitâ (hair, energy. . .) come back?â

<strong>Tip:</strong> Use one pad of paper for all your cancer related doctor appointments. Write the date and doctor's name at the top of the page. This way, if one doctor asks you about a visit with another doctor, youâll have all your questions and answers with you.

Use the same pad of paper to write down questions that come up between doctor appointments. One day I joked about my always having my yellow pad of paper with me. The medical team said, âWe love it! You donât forget to ask us anything, and it saves time.â]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The Double Edged Sword</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/30/the-double-edged-sword/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 30 Jun 2011 15:58:20 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=86</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Are countless people telling you to be positive? Do you feel youâve failed if your attitude has headed south?âEven if just for the day? Give yourself a break. When youâre scared, anxious or feeling lousy, you may not be as positive as usual. Itâs called being human. Be real with what youâre facing in the moment.

There will be folks you donât know, saying, âItâs all attitude.â âYouâve gotta be positive.â While I agree thatâs the truth, itâs not the <em>whole</em> truth. Itâs as if it becomes the obligation of the person being diagnosed to comfort those just learning of the diagnosis. It seems people with cancer are expected to show off how positive they are regardless of how they feel. No one likes a grump. No one likes being a grump, either. <em>The Course of Miracles</em> reminds us there are two emotions from which everything evolves: Love or Fear. Think of it. When someone in a car cuts you off, you may get mad. Being upset stems from the fear of almost hitting the other car! Maybe you werenât paying attention. Maybe you just realized you forgot your driverâs license. Whatever it was, it wasnât your ability to say, âThere goes God in a hurry."

Being positive made a huge difference in my experience with cancerâHaving said that, Iâd get upset when someone seeming to have no clue would be outrageously chipper. These people werenât my core support group. I found the more someone told me they understood, the less they seemed to. Scriptures tell us, âIn all things be grateful.â (Itâs not for all things.) So, even when youâve got a rotten day going on, you can be thankful you made it out of bedâor that you have a bed!

Dare I say, âHave a good dayâ?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cancer is not a âwarâ â You are not a âvictimâ</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/07/cancer-is-not-a-%e2%80%9cwar%e2%80%9d-you-are-not-a-cancer-%e2%80%9cvictim%e2%80%9d/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 07 Jul 2011 15:41:32 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=92</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Iâm not saying cancerâs easy. Iâm saying donât give cancer power. We give people and events power over us by talking bad about them. They become larger than life. Itâs a bit like the Dementors in Harry Potter. âThe big câ is the condition we treat like Lord Voldemortâor dare I say, âHe who must not be named.â Dementors were dark creatures.The foulest inhabitants of life. They would steal happiness, and cause depression. The more people freaked out about them, the more life Dementors gained.

Change your perspective about your experience with cancer. Change your vocabulary from âwarâ, âbattleâ, âfightâ, âstruggleâ, âvictimâ, âthe big câ, âsurvivorâ, "warrior", âsickâ, and âI have cancerâ to wording like âconditionâ, âexperienceâ, âIâve been diagnosed with cancerâ, âI had cancerâ, âI went through the cancer journey, or experience.â The idea is state the fact without claiming having a disease (dis-ease). Itâs just a matter of changing your perception and semantics. I believe they both play into our health and happiness.

Youâll see the light at the end of the tunnel. I trust youâll know itâs not a train.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Get a Second Opinion</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/11/get-a-second-opinion/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 11 Jul 2011 15:10:46 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=105</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Itâs usually wise to get a second opinion. If you like the first doctor, you can always return to them. If you donât like them, you will definitely need another opinion. By âlikeâ I donât mean youâd want to hang out with the doctor. Do you respect them? Can you trust them to treat you?

Donât feel youâre hurting their feelings by seeking another opinion, or transferring doctors. Itâs your right. How many pair of shoes, or outfits do you try before buying one? Without âdoctor shoppingâ do your homework, and treat the appointment as an interview. Youâre the one doing the hiring.

Bring information from the first doctor to the second opinion.Â (The receptionist at the second doctor's office may request you send it ahead for them to review.) Know your diagnosis, your stage (if you know it at this point), and options for treatment, along with how to reduce chances for possible reoccurrence. Ask questions. If youâre interested in trial (experimental) treatments, ask about your options. Do you have confidence in this doctorâs ability to treat you?

If not, go find someone who speaks highly of their doctor, and go for a third opinion. Once you've found your doctor, avoid "doctor shopping."

If you donât know where to go for a second opinion, you might ask the doctor, staff, or people you know. Look around in your community for hospitals, clinics with good reputations. Look at the doctor's bio on the hospital's website. If you get a good feel from what's written, make an appointment for a consultation.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Eating Healthy </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/14/eating-healthy/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 14 Jul 2011 14:40:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=109</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Salt, sugar, fatty intake: we know theyâre not good for us. Eating âdietâ food isnât ideal, either. So, whatâs a person striving to be healthy to do?

Glad you asked!

Are you eating fruits? Vegetables? Are you eating in moderation? Itâs not about saying, ânoâ to any âparty foodâ, (in fact, I was just told I needed to eat more salt!)Â  Itâs about conscious eating. Live a little! Have your cake and eat it, too! But be conscious of what and how much youâre eating.

How about exercising? Are you teaching Rover to fetch in hopes of grand rewards like delivery of potato chips and beer? Or, are you taking Rover for a walk?

During chemo, I figured calories were more important than monitoring how I got them. I ate whatever I craved. I ate things I hadnât eaten in yearsâroast beef, ice cream, and iceberg lettuce. As you get stronger, youâll be able to discern a bit more if the crave is for a need, or out of habit. You must decide the road youâll takeânot as in Rocky Road Ice Cream.

Happy, healthy eating!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Worry</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/18/worry/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 18 Jul 2011 14:59:39 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=112</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[In my family, when someoneâs worried, and trying not toâinevitably, Alfred E. Newman of Mad Magazine, gets a mention. âWhat-Me Worry?â

Some people end cancer treatment with the label, âcancer free.â Others are in âremission.â And there are those who die from this crazy thing called cancer.

In each case, there can be sleepless nights, with worry about recurrence, or leaving family and friends much sooner than expected because youâre dying. Worry about physical and cognitive abilities not returning quick enough. When will the pain end? Or, does pain mean cancerâs back? When will energy return? Then thereâs worry about relationships that have changed during the cancer experience. There may be worries about income, employment, insurance. Worries how hair will come inâ<em>Oh, please keep it the same as beforeâor not. </em>The list goes on. . .

Worry doesnât help anything. We all know that, but itâs habit. Even if youâre strong willed, when youâre tired, filled with drugsâchemo, radiationâ the mind takes the path of least resistance. Thatâs where habit and the subconscious mind play hardball against the conscious mind. It may be hard at times, but if youâre fed up with worry, find a mantra. Use a short phrase. A word. A prayer. Whatever works for you. If youâre mind goes back to worry (and it will), gently bring it back to your mantra. The mind cannot think two things at once. You are in control.

The purpose of a mantra is to keep your mind focused on something else. In India, elephants are given a stick to hold with their trunk as they walk through the crowded markets. The stick keeps the elephantâs trunk occupied, and out of the venderâs fruit baskets! The mantra becomes the elephantâs stick. (You being the elephant.)]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>National Cancer Institute - a great resource</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/21/national-cancer-institute-a-great-resource/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 21 Jul 2011 14:01:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=125</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[National Cancer Institute (NCI) is part of the National Institutes of Health. NCI provides information about cancer, and the journey through itâ such as finding local support groups and answering questions like, âWhat can I expect to experience?â âWhat questions should I ask my doctors?â âWhere can I get financial, legal, or transportation help?â âWhat are the benefitsâand side effects of various treatment plans?â âWhatâs a clinical trial, and what clinical trials are available?â

Use their website, printed information, or their phone line. NCI only asks you to share your name if youâre requesting something to be mailed to you. They only collect area codes - not phone numbers, and they donât ask for donations.Â <span style="color:#000000;"><a href="http://www.cancer.gov"><span style="color:#000000;">www.cancer.gov</span></a></span>

English and Spanish: 1-800-4-CANCER, or 1-800-422-6237.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Ease and Grace Accompany Me (an affirmative prayer)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/25/ease-and-grace-accompany-me-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 25 Jul 2011 13:24:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=128</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Taken from Creative Thought Magazine August 2009

Everywhere I go, God is there. In all I do, God is present. This Power is always working for my good. I am never alone. I move with the knowledge that Divine Life supports me. it expresses through me as courage, confidence, ease, and grace.

I permit wisdom to work in wonderful ways in my life. Allowing God to express through me as my health, happiness, and well-being on every level, I surrender by resting in perfect knowing. By doing my part, I encourage the grace of Spirit to work though me. I walk through my day with ease, seeing Godâs glory at every corner. I let go of any fear or doubt, and lean into the Power that backs all life. I have what it takes to be where I want to be.

I am blessed. I am whole. I am grateful. I state this claim to God and trust the Law [of nature] to lead the way. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Caregivers</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/07/28/caregivers/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 28 Jul 2011 15:08:16 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=147</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Everyoneâs focused on the patient diagnosed with cancer. Howâs the caregiver doing?

Caregivers often forego their own activities ranging from dental appointments to church, gym or other social outlets. That may backfire.

The caregiver who doesnât ask others for help is likely to stress out, and burn out. Follow flight attendant advice: put your own oxygen mask on first, then help those around you. If you donât take care of yourself first, you run the risk of endangering those you intend to help. If youâre overwhelmed, exhausted, or freaked out, youâre not much helpâand now there are two people needing help.

Three ways to put on your âcaretaker oxygen maskâ:
<ul>
	<li>Â Connect with people who can support you, such as family, friends, and support organizations or groups for caretakers.</li>
	<li>Â Keep a list of help needed, and a list of people whoâve offered help.</li>
	<li>Â Eat. Drink. Be Merry. Eat consciously. Be aware of what youâre eating, especially if you seek food for comfort. Drink for hydrationânot numbing or escape. If you need some flavor in your water, add a squeeze of lemon, a few slices of cucumber, or add a tiny bit of fruit juice. Be Merry. This isnât about denial. Itâs about finding good even in a rough situation. Focus on whatâs working for you and the person diagnosed.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Stage and Type (emotion and expression)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/01/stage-and-type-emotion-and-expression/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 01 Aug 2011 14:02:55 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=166</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Don't stuff your emotions. Itâs normal to have a strong emotional response to a serious diagnosis. Itâs part of the grieving process and itâs common for patients, and those close to them. Denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance are the five stages of grief. (Taken from The Grief Cycle model first published in <em>On Death &amp; Dying</em>, Elisabeth KÃ¼bler-Ross, 1969.) The stages are all natural to experience, and will vary in degree from person to person.

Some people prefer to talk about their treatment for cancer, and their experiences. Others don't want to talk about it at all.Â For the synergistic type, there are support groups, one-to-one counseling, and people close to you with whom you may find support. Folks with a more analytical edge may find journalingÂ helpful. They may also prefer to visit websites, on-line chat groups, message boards and blogs.

Here are some reputable cancer related sites: <a href="http://www.caring">www.caring4cancer.com; www.breastcancer.org; www.cancer.gov; www.cancer.org.Â  </a>Whatever site you visit, donât take any information as absolute truth. This blog included. Situations are so individual. What may work for one person, may not work for another.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Protein</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/08/protein-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 08 Aug 2011 08:00:15 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=182</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[According to American Institute for Cancer Research, older adults, people with type 2 diabetes, and those recovering from cancer need to eat more protein.

âDistributing protein throughout the day may be better for maintaining muscle.â says Collins, MS, RD, AICRâs Nutrition Advisor. âAim for 15-25 grams of protein at each meal, which can come from vegetables and grains along with 2-3 ounces of meat, fish or poultry or 2-3 servings of high-protein plant foods and low-fat dairy.â

Unlike plant protein foods, animal protein foods provide all the essential amino acids that our bodies canât make. No more than eighteen of those ounces should come from red meat per week. Some other ideas for protein: Skinless chicken, or fish (some fish has beneficial omega-3 fats.) Kidney beans, soy beans, lentils, and chickpeas contain 14-16 grams of protein per cup. Quinoa contains 8 grams per cup; brown rice has 5 grams. Peanut butter has 8 grams of protein per 2 Tbsp.

Whatever you eat, keep variety in your diet, and eat mindfully.Â  Enjoy!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Good Morning, Sunshine!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/11/good-morning-sunshine/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 11 Aug 2011 08:00:04 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=193</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[What inspires you to get up and live each day?]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>193</wp:post_id>

<item>
  <title>Express Yourself</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/15/express-yourself/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 08:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=195</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Because of cancer, some people begin their quest for religion. Some find a deeper meaning in their worship than what they experienced before cancer. Others turn away from God completely.

Life is always seeking expression. You may find new avenues of expression that surprise you. You might stop reading, but begin painting; stop going to the gym, but discover yoga, or dance; stop attending church, but find a deeper connection with a higher power.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>It Takes a Village</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/05/it-takes-a-village/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 05 Jan 2012 08:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=197</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Want to help? Wether someone has cancer, or needs help for another reason, you can have a big impact without knocking yourself out. Reach out to an elderly neighbor, a sick co-worker, or someone you know going through a rough time. You donât need to know the person well, or the details about their situation. The type of cancer doesnât matter if youâre offering to be a driver. That falls under the category of nosyâitâs about you fulfilling your need to know. Offer what you can do: take their trash cans out - or bring them back in. Bring them their mail. Run errands. Rides to the doctor. What can you do to make a difference?]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Stop. Look Around.</title>

  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Want to help? Whether someone has cancer, or needs help for another reason, you can have a big impact without knocking yourself out. Reach out to an elderly neighbor, a sick co-worker, or someone you know going through a rough time. You donât need to know the person well, or the details about their situation. The type of cancer doesnât matter if youâre offering to be a driver. That falls under the category of nosyâitâs about you fulfilling your need to know. Offer what you can do: take their trash cans out - or bring them back in. Bring them their mail. Run errands. Rides to the doctor. What can you do to make a difference?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Stress Relief</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/22/stress-relief/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 22 Aug 2011 08:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=201</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I just read a great article by staff at the Mayo Clinic.

I liked how the author addressed that there are many avenues to oneâs spirituality, and that no matter how spiritualityâs achieved, the end result can help relieve stress.

Religion and Spirituality are not synonymous. Watercolor painting may be an act of spirituality to one person â taking them to a deep feeling of connection with a higher power. To someone else, prayer or meditation may be their answer. Another person may feel a connection with God (or whatever they call that profound feeling of peace) in the form of a walk at the beach, or in the forest.

For some great tips on âSpirituality and Stress Relief, Making the Connectionâ visit <a href="http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/stress-relief/SR00035">http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/stress-relief/SR00035</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>I Claim Health (an affirmative prayer)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/25/i-claim-health-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 25 Aug 2011 08:00:10 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=203</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[As published in Creative Thought Magazine, June 2009:

The One that created all heals all. This Power is God. It is everywhere present at all times. I know Spirit is within me, so I relax, knowing It is in control.

God is the Source of all healing, whetherÂ emotional, mental, or physical. I allow God to reveal Its perfection in and through me. I accept the wholeness of who I am, knowing I have never been broken, worn out, or damaged. Even if I acknowledge a tiny sparkle within, that light spreads and heals. The Divine awaits my clarity as to what I desire and what I accept as true. It mirrors back to me from within, calling me to consciously claim health, peace, and well-being.

I am grateful I hear the call, and I choose to answer it. All is well in my world, and I celebrate it into being regardless of immediate appearance. I accept my good in mind here and now. With a joy-filled heart, I let it be. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Broccoli</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/08/29/broccoli/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 29 Aug 2011 16:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=206</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[In labs studies, the compound sulforaphane in broccoli seems to kill breast cancer cells that aid tumor growth. Other compounds in broccoli seem to stop growth of prostate cancer cells.

Broccoli, brussels sprouts, cabbage, collard greens, kale and turnips are all in the same family (cruciferous). They each hold generous amounts of cancer-fighting properties. They all contain fiber, vitamins and minerals such as vitamin C, folate and calcium.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Consider the Following Description of a Physical Reaction:</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/01/consider-the-following-description-of-a-physical-reaction/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 01 Sep 2011 08:00:36 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=209</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[âThe neural circuits in your brain begin to reverberate. Chemical and electrical impulses start flowing rapidly through your body. The pituitary gland is stimulated; hormones and endorphins race through your blood. Your body temperature rises half a degree, your pulse rate and blood pressure increase, your arteries and thoracic muscles contract, your vocal chords quiver, and face contorts. Pressure builds in your lungs. Your lower jaw suddenly becomes uncontrollable, and breath bursts from your mouth at nearly 70 miles an hour.â

(You have just laughed.)

From Making Humor Work, by Terry, L. Paulson, PhD]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>I Bless My Body (an affirmative prayer)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/05/i-bless-my-body-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 05 Sep 2011 08:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=211</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="text-decoration:underline;">As published in Creative Thought Magazine August 2008</span>

The Divine Intelligence that creates all does so with perfection. I am the Universe in expression as joy, love, beauty, and health. As I celebrate my life, so does the universe. My life is whole, perfect, and complete. It always has been and always will be.

The trillions of cells within my body know exactly what toÂ do and how to go about their duty. Every cell moves throughout my body with ease. As each does its part to support this body divine, I hold the vibration of gratitude and provide them a loving environment of a happy, healthy, and comfortable life. I rejoice with how my body functions.

For all of this good that brings ease and grace to my life, I give thanks. I release this blessing and take care of my perfect body. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>What if You Learned Cancer Wants Out of You, Too?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/08/what-if-you-learned-cancer-wants-out-of-you-too/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 08 Sep 2011 08:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=223</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

We hear cancer is the evil one. We bad mouth it, hunt it down and kill it. While continuing with your treatment, you may want to have a conversation with your cancer.

What if you saw cancer as the kid who never had any friends? The child who was hurt, not listened to, and ignored? Then, what if you took the time to sit down and ask cancer to sit with you. Just be. Breathe into where the cancer currently resides. Then talk with it. If it could talk, what would it say? If something unpleasant comes up, don't take it personally. (Remember, it's the hurt one with no friends.)

When the cancer has finished "talking", share your view with it. Perhaps you see it as an invasion of privacy. It's the uninvited guest who's entered your sacred space, stayed too long, and made a mess. Stand in your Truth, not in fear. Tell cancer it's time to go back to the nothingness from where it came.

When we come from fear, the thing we fear holds on tighter. We're all itsÂ got! You may want to tell cancer it's done it job, it's safe for it to leave now, and visualize it packing it's bags to leave for good.

If you want to share your experience with other readers, what does your conversation sound like?

<span style="color:#000000;"><strong>
</strong></span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

<item>
  <title>BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/12/brca-1-and-brca-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 12 Sep 2011 08:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=225</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If there are changes that take place within the BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 genes, itâs called mutation. If thereâs a gene mutation, thereâs a significant raised risk of breast (men or women) and/or ovarian cancer. A blood test is given to individuals who have a history of breast or ovarian cancer in their family, or who have a specific type of breast cancer to determine if a mutation has occurred. If the individual tests positive, theyâll be sent to a genetic counselor, and talk about the options.

If you have fit into any of the following, you might have an increased risk of BRCA gene mutation. If this hasnât already been brought up in appointments, contact your oncologist, or a genetic counselor and ask them about your situation.
<ul>
	<li>You or a close relative had pre-menopausal, bilateral breast cancer</li>
	<li>You or a close relative (mother, sister, daughter) had ovarian cancer</li>
	<li>Two or more relatives (aunts, cousins, parents, siblings, children) had breast or ovarian cancer</li>
	<li>A male relative had breast cancer</li>
	<li>You have a relative with a known BRCA1 or BRCA 2 mutation</li>
	<li>You have Ashkenazi (Eastern European) Jewish ancestry and have had ovarian cancer, or close relative who has breast or ovarian cancer</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>I Embrace Health (an affirmative prayer)  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/15/i-embrace-health-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 15 Sep 2011 08:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=227</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="text-decoration:underline;">As published in Creative Thought Magazine February 2010</span>

There is only Divine Perfection. It is at the core of me. It is my cellular essence. Knowing every aspect of my physical self is God, I let my body express and experience God as joy, love, health, and wealth.

I am flexible and strong, beautiful and whole. Circulation in my body is easy and perfect. My vision, hearing, and speech are clear. I am positive as I move through my day with confidence in youthful maturity. I am that I AM. Any seeming disbelief in my bodyâs perfection is replaced with knowing I am God in action. I am the channel God moves in, speaks from, and sees through. I also know all I encounter is Godâeveryone and everything, everywhere. As I release any appearance of disbelief, I direct the perfection of God to replace the void with vibrant energy and loveâlove of life, love for myself, love for others. All is well. I feel it, embrace it, and live it. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Hair loss</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/22/hair-loss-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 22 Sep 2011 08:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=233</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Chemotherapy works by killing rapidly dividing cellsâboth âgoodâ and âbadâ (cancerous) ones. The unpleasant side effects from chemo come from the type and amount of chemo you are given. The most common side effects from chemo include hair thinning or loss, nausea, and mouth sores. These areas (hair follicles; stomach and mouth lining) are areas of rapid cell growth.

Here are some tips to help you move through the side effects of hair loss:

Hair loss isnât always a side effect of chemo. Your medical team will be able to tell you what you can expect with your treatment.

Cancer, or hair loss is not your identity. It doesnât change who you are.

Before your first chemo, you may want to get a short haircut. Approximately three days after your second chemo youâll begin to lose hair. You may want a loving friend or family member to shave your head. I went my momâs hair stylist whoâd had breast cancer. When I left, I felt I had the tiger by its tail. I was in control; not cancer.

Try on wigs, scarves, hats, turbans. If you decide not to cover your head at all, wear sunscreen.

If you want to wear a wig the same color as your hair, look for wigs before hair loss. Try them on, but donât buy one while you have hair. It may not fit when you donât have hair.

Your hair will grow backâtypically 1-2 months after your last chemo treatment. My eyebrows were the last to leave, and first to come back.

What works/worked for you?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Anemia</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/26/anemia/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 26 Sep 2011 08:00:19 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=238</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Decreased red blood cells and hemoglobin (a protein that helps your blood carry oxygen) is called anemia. Anemia can cause fatigue.

<strong>Here are some tips to help deal with anemia:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Eat small amounts every 2 hours.</li>
	<li>Eat high iron foods. You may have lost your taste for green leafy vegetables, but watermelon, canned green beans, brown, black, white beans and meat all have high iron.</li>
	<li>Light exercise helps. Move your body. For at least 10 minutes a day, move.</li>
	<li>Live like a cat. Nap! Take short naps that donât interfere with night-time sleep. Balance naps with exercise.</li>
	<li>If you become dizzy when you get up from lying or sitting, get up slowly; hold on to something sturdy, tell your medical team.</li>
</ul>
How did you / do you work around anemia?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Fatigue  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/09/29/fatigue/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 29 Sep 2011 08:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=242</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Fatigue can effect concentration and the ability to complete daily tasks. You may have low energy and high need for rest after doing non-strenuous activities. For me, applying make-upâeven while sitting down, was exhausting. I settled for lipstick and earings.

Anxiety and depression can add to fatigue, as can unending pain, sleep disturbance, lack of exercise and side effects of some medications.

<strong>Here are some tips to help you move through the fatigue:</strong>

Ask for help. Have a sign up list, or call in favors from those whoâve said, âIf you need anything...â

Use paper plates instead of needing to wash dishes, or empty the dish washer. Think of paper plates as the environmental trade-off of saving water.

Prioritize you activities to conserve your energy. Some activitiesâand people take more energy than others. Put the important things earlier in the day.

Food provides your body energy. Try to eat a balanced diet. Even if you donât feel like eating, set your mind to eat somethingâhalf a cup of yogurt, string cheese, a piece of fruitâevery 2 hours.

Exercise daily. Your ability to do so may vary. It may mean walking to the mailbox, or around the block. It may mean going to a yoga class. I enjoy exercise, but for me, it was one of the hardest things to push through.

Whatâs your input on how to deal with fatigue?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Neutropenia and Infection</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/03/neutropenia-and-infection/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 03 Oct 2011 15:00:36 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=244</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Neutropenia is a condition of having a low white blood cells level due to chemotherapy killing rapidly dividing cellsâboth âgoodâ and âbadâ (cancerous). This can cause serious infection, and interrupt your chemotherapy schedule. (That sounds good at first, but really, you want to get through chemo as quickly and smoothly as possible.)

A blood test for a complete blood count is taken every two weeks on the week of chemo, and Â detects neutropenia. Neulasta and Neupogen are medications to help your body produce more white blood cells, helping prevent neutropenia, and infection.

<strong>Some ways to manage or prevent neutropenia and infection include:Â </strong>

âIn addition to the list of ongoing precautions during treatment for cancer, check your temperature. If itâs over 100.5 degrees Fahrenheit, call your doctor, or on-call doctor.

âAvoid crowds. Stay away from people who are sick. If someone wants to visit and theyâre sick, ask them to reschedule. At this point, your immune system is <em>really</em> fragile. If you have to go to the store, wear a surgical mask. Yeah, it looks a bit goofy, but it beats getting sick.

âAvoid food bulk bins, pot lucks, and buffets. Make sure all foods are washed, and meat is fully cooked. Stay clear of shrimp and raw eggs.

âMaintain personal hygiene, and encourage others, too. In addition to frequent hand washing with warm, soapy water, I requested those who stayed over to bring their own toothpaste (to prevent their toothbrush from touching my tubeâthen my toothbrush.) Take daily showers.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Does the phrase "Living in the Moment" have different meaning to you now, than it did before cancer? Share with readers wanting to know how <span style="text-decoration:underline;">you</span> "Live in the Moment" â with or without cancer.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Nausea and Vomiting</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/10/nausea-and-vomiting/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 10 Oct 2011 08:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=249</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I was fortunate. I never once threw up. My lips quivered four months, but I never lost my lunch.

Prevention is crucial. Take your anti-nausea (antimetic) medication. If the side effects are rough, tell your doctor. There are plenty of options for other medications.

<strong>Here are some tips for preventing or managing nausea and vomiting:</strong>

âEat small amounts, frequently. Donât get hungry. Nibble here and there throughout the day.

âDrink well before or after a meal. Otherwise, youâll get full on a half glass of water and not want to eat. Drink in sips versus a big drink at once. Keep a balance between hydration and nutrition.

âEat food at room temperature. (The aroma of heated food may set off nausea.) If the food needs to be heated up, use the microwave, then let it sit to cool off some. Or, have it prepared out of the home. Between smells and energy, itâs in your best interest to let others cook for you. Tell them what works these days. Your taste buds and tolerance will change.

âGo easy on greasy and spicy food, especially on an empty stomach.

âThe day of chemotherapy and the day after, eat lightly, if not liquid only. I stuck with 7-Up, a few saltine crackers and chicken broth.

âAvoiding lying down for two hours after eating will help greatly in reducing nausea.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>249</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2011-10-10 08:00:54</wp:post_date>

<item>
  <title>I Trust Life (an affirmative prayer)  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/13/i-trust-life-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 13 Oct 2011 08:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=251</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[As published in Creative Thought Magazine, January 2008

There is One Power, One Presence, and One Infinite Wisdom. I look out and know I have a universal support system. My every breath is provided for me. My heart beats with joy, and I am open to Divine Life affirming who I am and the desires I hold.

Taking time daily, I pause to embrace the feeling of trust, knowing, and faith that the Universe supports me in all my good. I release any fear and replace it with faith. When I have faith, I release worry and doubt. I trust things work out for me easily at the right time. I visualize myself reaping the success of Godâs abundance. I embody the feeling of knowing I live in a Universe that is orderly, and Creative Power backs me.

I walk through my day, knowing I am one with the majestic power of Spirit. I release my word in trust. I let go, and let it be. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Laugh!  Short-term benefits</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/17/laugh-short-term-benefits/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 17 Oct 2011 08:00:43 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=253</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[For starters, laughter can lighten your load mentally. It can interrupt the feeling that we carry the weight of the world. By interrupting that feeling, you can re-frame your thoughts, creating a new, lighter feeling with which to move forward.

Laughter increases release of endorphins from your brain, and increases intake of oxygen. It stimulates your heart, lungs and muscles. Have you ever laughed so hard, it hurt? What a workout! A hardy laugh increases your heart rate and blood pressure, resulting in a relaxed feeling. This relaxed feeling can help reduce some of the physical symptoms of stress by stimulating circulation and aiding in muscle relaxation.

Go ahead, Laugh at life and all itâs absurdities!Â Think itâs more far-fetched than a root beer sippinâ snake?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Still  Laughing! Long-term effects</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/20/still-laughing-long-term-effects/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 20 Oct 2011 08:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=255</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Positive thoughts actually release neuropeptides that help fight stress. Laughter teams up with this, helping aid the immune system, keeping the body healthy, or pointing it in that direction.

Laughter can cause the body to produce its own natural painkillers. It can break pain, especially pain from some muscle disorders. Laughter can help us cope with difficult situations, and helps us bond with other people.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>I Trust the Process (an affirmative prayer)  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/24/i-trust-the-process-an-affirmative-prayer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 24 Oct 2011 08:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=258</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[As published in Creative Thought Magazine, December 2007

âOur doubts are traitors, and make us lose the good we oft might win, by fearing to attempt.â âWilliam Shakespeare, Measure for Measure.

God is Good. God is here and now in my life. The God I believe inâand call Energy, Universe, and Creative Wisdomâis always present. it is always working in, around, through, and for me. There is no separation between this Power and who I am.

God is expressing as freedom from fear or want. Its flow of guidance moves through me as wisdom. It is my partner in success as I direct It. I state my desire in a clear, direct manner and trust the Universe with the how of bringing me my desires. I move to receive what I claim as mine. It makes no difference to the Universe whether I want physical health, world peace, loving relationships, or greater income; It follows the direction I give. As i do this, I let go and have faith, knowing the Almighty is at work.

There is nothing to get in the way of Creative Wisdom, not even me when I consciously team up with Spirit. I state my claim, know it is good, and let it be. And so it is.

Rev. Claudia Mulcahy]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Remove The Boxing Gloves  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/10/27/remove-the-boxing-gloves/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 27 Oct 2011 08:00:08 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=260</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If we fight for something, we must fight to <em>keep</em> that something.Â Surrender. Relax into knowing youâre safe. Itâs not a white-flag surrender. Itâs like leaning back to float. If you fight the water, youâll surely drown.

To surrender, you must give up fear. Doing that requires courageâtrusting someone, or something has more ability to help you than you have on your own. Trust. Trust this person or power has more knowledge than you in the area needed. This is not to be confused with abdication. You must find the medical team you trust, and believe in. If youâre spiritual, you must do your spiritual work. If you sit to meditate, are you meditating in the energy of love, strength, and health? Or is it a meditation of worry? If so, thatâs time spent in fear, and thatâs lack of faith.

Whatever you lean into, know Itâs everywhere present - including in your body. Itâs a power for good, working in, around, through and for you. Accept it. Expect it.

Whether you lean into a spiritual power for good, or have 100% faith in your doctor, the trust has to be there. If the trust is there, the need to fight is removed.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Be Here. Now.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/03/be-here-now/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 03 Nov 2011 08:00:02 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=265</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Be in the present. The Now. Thatâs really the only place we can ever be. If youâre thinking about tomorrowâs appointment, youâre in the future. If youâre revisiting a conversation in your mind from earlier today, youâre in the past.

Right now, feelâreally feel the chair below you. Your back against the chair. The ground beneath your feet. Lower your shoulders. Breathe in. (Thatâs a pretty good indicator to the Universe you want to be here.) Now, just for a minute, close your eyes as you pay attention to your breath. In, out, in, out. . . Notice the sacred space in between the exhale and inhale.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Decreased Appetite</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/07/decreased-appetite/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 07 Nov 2011 08:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=269</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Chemotherapy changes how food tastes. Food may taste bland, bitter, or have a metallic taste. This may last until a few months after your last treatment. So, what do you do when you know you need to eat but arenât hungry, and the taste of food isnât rewarding? Here are some ideas:
<ul>
	<li><span class="Apple-style-span" style="line-height:26px;">Â During chemo, I hated the tasteâeven the smell of garlic. I still canât stand it. Â I switched over to using ginger more than I used to. . .Â </span></li>
	<li>Â Ginger or mint can help mask a metallic taste, as can using plastic utensils.</li>
	<li>Â Get someone else to cook, and use the microwave instead of the oven to cut down on food odors.</li>
	<li>Â Eat often, but tiny amounts. A few spoons of yogurt, a blop of cottage cheese, a chicken wing.</li>
	<li>Â Sip liquid throughout the day. Drink before, or after a meal so you donât fill up on liquidâor lack hydration by filling up on food, with no room for a drink.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Ask, and Youâll Receive</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/10/ask-and-you%e2%80%99ll-receive/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 08:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=272</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[You wonât have enough energy to keep up with all the chores. Friends want to help, but may not know what you need. Ask friends to help when they come over. Or, specifically ask them to come over for a certain chore. Request friends or family to do the heavy shoppingâthings like potatoes, and water bottles. Make sure they unwrap and put away what they buy, and open a bottle. I got to the point with weakness where I would ask anyone passing by to open my bottles or cans.

Guests:Â Take out the trash after cutting watermelon, or other messy or smelly things. Â Sweep, mop, vacuum, dust, clean windows, water plants, add water to flowersâor trash or compost them if they look old.Â ASK, âWhat are you eating this week?â Bring over a little something for her to try.

Fatigue and weakness doesnât go away the day chemo ends. Youâll need help for four to six monthsâand in some cases one-to-two years to do certain things. It really depends how much you do in a day. If I do one big thing, Iâm fine. If I do three, Iâm wasted for the following few days.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 Gene  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/14/brca-1-and-brca-2-gene/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 14 Nov 2011 08:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=279</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[American Cancer Society states that 1 in 8 women (13 percent of women) develop breast cancer. Women with an inherited BRCA gene mutation have an 80 percent chance of developing breast cancer. Less than 3 percent of women develop ovarian cancer. But, 40-50 percent of women with the BRCA gene mutation will develop ovarian cancer by the age 70.

The genetic test is easy, but expensive. (Several hundred dollars.) Not all insurance covers it. The test is a simple blood test, and can determine if the person with cancer has the mutation. If they do have the mutation, their relatives may have it also, increasing the risk of cancer.

If you do get tested, youâll meet with a genetic counselor, and then go off for some blood work. Know that it takes a month before you get the results back. I actually forgot about the testâin my mind I was going through the motions, and âknewâ it would come back negative. Uh. . . (I tested positive, and my ovaries were removed.) If you agree to share this information with your family at large, youâll be given a letter to give certain female family members. Then, itâs up to them if theyâll be tested or not.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>279</wp:post_id>

<item>
  <title>Anxiety</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/17/anxiety/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 17 Nov 2011 08:00:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=281</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Anxiety is normal when handed the diagnosis of cancer. If anxiety takes over, and you find yourself grinding your teeth, worrying, not sleeping, itâs time to let anxiety know YOU are in control. Here are some ideas to help:
<ul>
	<li>Exercise daily. If youâre movinâ your body, itâs exercise.</li>
	<li>Chair yoga, Tai Chi, Chi Gong, stretching, walking.</li>
	<li>Meditation. If you donât know how, try various methods. Consciously focus on your breath. Not changing it. Just being aware. Another type of meditation can be done by focusing visually on something - a candle, flower, any one thing. You can do a walking meditation - even washing dishes can become a meditation. The idea is to be present in whatever you are doing when you re doing it.</li>
	<li>Breathe deeply. Do it consciously. Breathe deeply while youâre driving, shopping, and Â on the computer. Just keep doing it.</li>
	<li>Join a support group - as a patient, or caregiver.</li>
	<li>You may choose to talk with your doctor about anti-anxiety medication, or counseling.</li>
	<li>Communicate whatâs on your mind with those you love. They may be anxious, too.</li>
	<li>If you have a spiritual group, lean into them. If you donât have one, and want one, begin talking with people. You may find like-minded souls.</li>
	<li>Read things other than cancer related material.</li>
	<li>Travel, or comedy, DVDs. Stay away from dramas with people dying of cancer, arguments, etc.</li>
	<li>Journal. If you can take action on something that comes upâdo it. If you have no control over it, then the control is in your perception and attitude.</li>
</ul>
Again. Breathe deep.

Ahhhh!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Giving Thanks</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/21/giving-thanks/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 21 Nov 2011 08:00:46 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=284</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color:#000000;"><span style="color:#000000;">Iâve heard some say theyâre grateful for cancer. I can't say I am, but gratitude is very important to me and I can say I maintained gratitude throughout the cancer process. </span></span>

<span style="color:#000000;">For five months, the walls in my living room became a âWall of Gratitude.â Iâd write down events, people, or things for which I was grateful. Visitors were thrilled to see their name on the wall, and theyâd often tell me theyâre favorite one to read. (A friend who loves trees was pleased I included âshade tressâ on my list. Another friend laughedâbut understood gratitude for âbodily functions.â)</span>

It comes down to perspective. Even on really rough days, there are people and things for which you can be in gratitude.

<span style="color:#000000;">What's on your gratitude list?</span>

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2011/11/img_23671.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-286" title="Wall of Gratitude" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2011/11/img_23671.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Pain Management  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/11/28/pain-management/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 28 Nov 2011 08:00:17 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=295</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>Preventing</em> pain is key. If you have pain medication, take it as prescribed by your doctor. If the instructions are to take the medication as necessary, take it before you experience severe pain. Itâs easier to cut pain off at the pass than it is to de-escalate pain. <em>Consistency</em> with pain medication or other techniques really does help.

Tell your doctor if your pain gets worse, or if the medication doesnât provide lasting pain relief. Also, tell your doctor about any side effects your experience from your medication. Keep a journal and write down concerns and questions you have before your doctor appointment. Bring the journal to all your appointments. If youâre concerned about becoming addicted to pain medication, bring this up with your doctor.

Some non-medication pain-relief suggestions could include: meditation, prayer, music or exercise. If youâre interested in massage or acupuncture, run it past your oncology team first. I was requested to avoid those modalities while in treatment. It may be suggested you wait until after treatment, then get a lymph drainage massage from this point forward versus any other type of massage. This holds true if youâve had any lymph nodes removed.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Diarrhea</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/01/diarrhea/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 01 Dec 2011 08:00:46 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=298</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[It seems individuals undergoing cancer treatment either experience diarrhea, or constipation!Â Put shyness in your back pocketâwell, so to speak. If you're experiencing diarrhea or constipation, mention it to your medical team.Â Diarrhea brought on by chemotherapy must be brought to your doctorâs attention as soon as possible. Diarrhea can potentially be life-threatening if not controlled.

Here are some tips for preventing, or dealing with diarrhea:
<ul>
	<li>Â Eat small amounts often, rather than a few bigger meals.</li>
	<li>Avoid hot, or cold food.</li>
	<li>Â Keep liquids going in to prevent dehydration.</li>
	<li>Room temperature beverages are easier to tolerate.</li>
	<li>Drinks like Gatorade are good for replenishing the bodyâs electrolytes.</li>
	<li>Stay away from spicy, fatty and greasy foods. Also, acidic juices and milk.</li>
	<li>Stick with low-fiber food. White bread, rice, eggs, chicken without the skin, or baked fish. Bananas and potatoes are good to eat, too.</li>
	<li>(Avoid high-fiber foods such as fresh fruit and vegetables, popcorn, nuts, beans, whole grains.) High-fiber food can make diarrhea worse.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Constipation</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/05/constipation/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 05 Dec 2011 08:00:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=301</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If itâs not one thing, itâs another!Â If you have diarrhea or constipation, donât be embarrassed to mention to your medical team.

Constipation can be dangerous if you have a heart or respiratory illness, causing fainting, and chest pain.Â The best way to not have to bring up constipation with your medical team is to prevent constipation! Here are some tips:
<ul>
	<li>Â Exercise daily.</li>
	<li>Walkâeven if for 5-10 minutes.</li>
	<li>Raise your knees to your chest a few times like big marching steps.</li>
	<li>Deep knee bends.</li>
	<li>Thereâs a great move I learned in yoga years ago. Rub your fist on your stomach and rub in a clockwise motion 5-10 times.</li>
	<li>Eat foods high in fiber: Beans, vegetables, whole grains.</li>
	<li>Fiber alone wonât do the trick. You must hydrate to help the fiber move on out.</li>
	<li>Keep fluids going down.</li>
	<li>Prune juice works better than prunes, and warm prune juice works wonders!</li>
	<li>âSo does Good and Plenty Candy (black licorice.)</li>
	<li>Check with your doctor before taking stool softeners.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
