<item>
  <title>Neuropathy</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/08/neuropathy/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 08 Dec 2011 08:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=303</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Got that fingers-slammed-in-the-door feeling? Canât feel sensations in your fingers? Do your feet burn like theyâve been in a bucket of ice? And when you walk, it feels like youâre walking barefoot on golf-balls?

Itâs called peripheral neuropathy. It may be slight, or severe. It may end with treatment, or last a few yearsâor more. Most people do recover from the nerve damage, but in some, the damage is permanent.

Some chemo treatments affect the nerves in your body. Let your medical team know if you have any tingling, burning, freezing or prickling feeling in your hands or feet. Give them a description, an intensity level and an estimate of duration. This is where a journal of questions and concerns helps at doctor appointments. Write down whatâs going on with your body in between your appointments so you can make the most of your appointment time.

<strong>To be continued. . .Â </strong>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Neuropathy - Continued</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/12/neuropathy-continued/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 12 Dec 2011 08:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=305</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li>Depending how severe, or when (if) you develop neuropathy, your doctor may decrease or change your chemo. You may be given a medication to help relieve the symptoms. I didnât get very numb in my hands or feet until my last two chemo treatments. Then <em>Wham</em>! At one point, I couldnât walk across my living room floor, so I crawled. The nerves in your fingertips and toes are furthest from the spine so it may take some time to recover, especially if youâre tall. Hang in there. Also, ask your doctor about your taking vitamin B, or Alpha Lipoic Acid for helping repair your nerves.</li>
	<li>Â Loss of balance is common after a mastectomy, and with neuropathy. If youâre having trouble with your balance, ask your doctor about physical therapy to help your balance.</li>
	<li>Â Avoid temperature extremes. Your hands and feet may be extra sensitive to hot and cold.</li>
	<li>If you have neuropathy in you hands, be careful with sharp objects. The dulled sensation in your hands may increase the risk of cutting yourself, or not feeling a knife drop or move from your grip. I had others cut things like watermelon for me, or chop onions and celery.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Helping The Lymphatic System</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/14/helping-the-lymphatic-system/</link>
  <pubDate>Wed, 14 Dec 2011 08:00:26 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=308</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[RememberÂ <em>The Hippity-Hop</em>? Static bouncing is like that, but youâre not skipping down the driveway. Itâs perfect for watching television, talking with a friend, or in your own world of thoughts.

Grab a medium size balance ball at the gym, or blow off the dust on the one at home!

Sit on the ball like itâs a chair, with your feet on the floor.

Bounce while sitting for 5-10 mins.

This is a great exercise for reducing and preventing lymphedema. Within 5 minutes of bouncing, I need to clear my throat, meaning the lymph nodes are working, pushing toxins up and out.

Other good activities for lymph drainage:
<ul>
	<li>Jumping on a trampoline</li>
	<li>swimming</li>
	<li>raising your arm up like youâre in school waiting to ask a question and open and close your hand.</li>
	<li>wiggling!</li>
	<li>manual lymph drainage massage (Vodder massage.) This is <em>not</em> a âregularâ massage. There are very specific areas and direction with lymph massage. Less is more. Talk to occupational therapists, nurses, and massage therapists to find a qualified lymphedema specialist. Also, youâll want to learn self-care maintenance. Using a pneumatic pump as the only therapy, is not recommended for lymphedema.</li>
</ul>
Until then, happy bouncing!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>What is Lymphedema?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/19/what-is-lymphedema/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 19 Dec 2011 08:00:19 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=310</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>Lymphedema</em> is swelling caused by a blockage of the normal lymph flow, which then causes swelling in the affected body limb/s. This blockage occurs when lymph channels are destroyed (through radiation, or removed via surgery.) The fluid in the body has no where to go and may cause tissue to expand, harden, or become infected.

With treatment, self-maintenance and compression, lymphedema can be controlled. Itâs a serious, progressive condition, though. Stage-1 lymphedema can be reversed. Pay attention to your body. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential. (See Warning Signs of Lymphedema blog entry)]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>310</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2011-12-19 08:00:19</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2011-12-19 08:00:19</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>what-is-lymphedema</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="breast-cancer"><![CDATA[Breast cancer]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="lymphedema"><![CDATA[Lymphedema]]></category>
  <category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
  <wp:postmeta>
    <wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
    <wp:meta_value><![CDATA[23862730]]></wp:meta_value>

    <wp:meta_key>publicize_results</wp:meta_key>

<item>
  <title>Warning Signs of Lymphedema</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/22/warning-signs-of-lymphedema/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 22 Dec 2011 08:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=313</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Lymphedema is a serious, progressive condition. Stage-1 lymphedema can be reversed. Pay attention to your body. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential. The following are warning signs of lymphedema. If you are an individual who is at risk for lymphedema, become familiar with the list below and contact your doctor, or lymphedema therapist if you notice any of the changes.
<ul>
	<li>Â Feeling of heaviness, or pressure in the affected limb.</li>
	<li>Sensation of swelling - even before swelling takes place.</li>
	<li>Jewelry or clothing fitting more snugly than usual.</li>
	<li>âPins and needlesâ feeling in the affected limb.</li>
	<li>Bursting sensation in the limb.</li>
	<li>Skin not bouncing back after pressure is applied to the swollen part and held for a moment.</li>
	<li>Loss of skin elasticity.</li>
	<li>Hardening of the skin.</li>
	<li>Skin ulcerations.</li>
	<li>Red or blotchy skin - it could be a sign of a very serious bacterial infection.</li>
	<li>Feeling of heat in the affected limb, or quadrant of body.</li>
	<li>Even before a visual sign is present, sensing a difference, could be the first sign of onset.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Precautions for Lymphedema  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/29/precautions-for-lymphedema/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 29 Dec 2011 08:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=317</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>Hearing all the precautions re: lymphedema brought me down fast. Do your best to keep your attitude light while honoring your body.</div>
<div></div>
<ul>
	<li>Modify, or eliminate activities that seem to set-off sensations or symptoms of lymphedema.</li>
	<li>Wear your compression sleeve for all repetitive, or weight lifting activities (including heavy groceries, grandchildrenâbe them heavy or not, mopping, kayaking, tennis. . .) Get the idea?</li>
	<li>If you lift weights at the gym, go slow. Wait 2-3 days and see how things go. If it seems okay, then continue with your work-outs, but monitor how the affected limb does afterward.</li>
	<li>Avoid if possible - scrubbing, pushing and pulling against resistance.</li>
	<li>Donât over-tire the limb when exercising.</li>
	<li>Needles and blood pressure cuffs to the affected limb.</li>
	<li>Take extra caution with scissors, knives.</li>
	<li>Take action if pricked from garden thorns, or scraped while hiking.</li>
	<li>Burnsâbe them sunburns, oven burns, steam burnsâtend to them.</li>
	<li>Avoid Jacuzzis, saunas.</li>
	<li>If you get manicures, bring your own nail-care equipment.</li>
	<li>Donât cut cuticles.</li>
	<li>Keep skin clean, and monitor.</li>
	<li>Bounce. Wiggle. Swim. Jump. Theyâre all REALLY GOOD for you in the prevention of lymphedema!</li>
	<li>Change position of the limb often.</li>
	<li>Wear compression sleeve on airplanes (and kept on for a few hours after landing) and travel to high altitudes, such as a road trip to the mountains, or skiing.</li>
	<li>Donât sleep with the wearing the compression sleeve.</li>
	<li>Stay hydrated, and move around.</li>
	<li>Breathe. Do it regularly! Take a deep breath right now. . .</li>
	<li>Eat protein. This is important after cancer. Not to eat âtonsâ - but to eat an adequate amount.</li>
	<li>Limit sodium.</li>
	<li>Avoid sodas, wine (seems to set off lymphedema more rapidly than any other food/drink.)</li>
	<li>Drink water.</li>
	<li>Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>âB Positive.â Itâs More Than a Blood Type.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/09/b-positive-its-more-than-a-blood-type/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 09 Jan 2012 08:00:20 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=335</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[âAct as ifâ âItâs all goodâ âChange your thinking, change your lifeâ âFake it âtil you make itâ âyou know the phrases. These phrases, or mantras are meant to keep us headed the direction we intend to go.

But often people will skim from the top, and sometimes âbeginner mindâ can be dangerous. If you cut your hand and think good thoughts, will all be well? Maybe. First, being a positive person doesnât give you license to be a careless, mindless person. Need a band-aide? Use one. Need a doctor? Go. If you want to travel overseas, do you have your passport ready? Have you saved the money? (Ah, but if you want âmoney speakâ youâd be at my blog: <a href="http://spiritandmoneymatters.wordpress.com">http://spiritandmoneymatters.wordpress.com</a>)

Go to the cause. (Hint: Itâs you; not them.) If you cut yourself, do your knives need sharpening? Do you need to step back from multi-tasking? What part do you play in people upsetting you? Are you easily upset? Are your thoughts, words or actions harsh? Do you tout âOne Love. Coexist. Equalityââthen, drive aggressively, gossip, or hold grudges? Whatever we give in thoughts, words or actions, we receive. It doesnât matter if weâre âjokingâ or itâs a âfact.â The âgood/badâ seldom return from the same person we gave, but the Universe matches in kind. What goes around, comes around.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Personal Attendant   </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/12/personal-attendant/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 12 Jan 2012 08:00:51 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=337</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I have a friend in Tampa FL (Dunedin) who is looking for a personal attendant. This means someone who is a certified nursing assistant, can pass a level 2 background check, has common sense, and is an animal and people lover. Please help get the word out. Thanks!

Just a reminder: When an attendant doesnât show up to work, the person theyâre hired to help is abandoned. The person needing assistance cannot get out of bed without help. Think about it. This means no eating. No dressing. No help with their bowel program. No letting the dog out to the backyard. The list goes on. . . Itâs a very important job. Youâll be valued, but you must realize what responsibility comes with this job.

Thanks again for sharing this with your friends. Please leave comments for more info. Iâll connect my friend with you.
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Attitude Check</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/19/attitude-check/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 19 Jan 2012 08:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=343</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Life happens. Even happy, healthy people get cancer. As a New Thought minister, Iâd hear new students talk about another personâs situation: âItâs all attitudeâ can become a flippant catch-all phrase.

It goes way beyond <em>talkinâ the talk</em>. Itâs not necessarily what we say; itâs what we <em>feel</em>. Often, people donât know the cause behind their situation (health, wealth, partnerships. . . ) Itâs the conviction we haveâknowingly or not. The universe doesnât respect ignorance, and even when we know better, there is often a lifetime of "stuff" beneath the surface. Fire can heat a house, or burn the house down. It doesnât matter that you didnât know it would do that.

Same is true with emotions. They can bring us up, or take us down. Example: Think of a very happy moment in your life. Stay with itâare you smiling? Now, think of something that brought (or could bring) you sadness. If you stay with it, youâll feel heavy and may even cry.

So. . . Obviously, focusing on happy times is more rewarding. BUT â do not fall into the blame-game of yourself, or others.Â <em>Thatâs</em> not healthy! If you feel sad, be okay with that. Donât wash over it as if it didnât happen. <em>Heal it</em>. Go to the <em>cause</em>. You may not even need to know the exact cause - but know âthe cause of this situation needs healing.â It may be a one-time fix. It may be something to work on for a while. None of the details matter. Be open to a healing, be open to the commitment on your part involved in achieving that healing.

In the big picture, It <em>is</em> all goodâbut we may have to dig a bit deeper in the pile to find the pony. Good can come out of tough situations.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Jewish Folklore</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/26/jewish-folklore/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 26 Jan 2012 08:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=347</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[As Adam and Eve trudged out of Eden, God felt sorry for them. He called them back and gave them a gift to ease hard times ahead: a tear.

Scientists have found that tears of pain and sorrow can trigger certain brain chemicals that help us relax and these chemicals also act as natural pain relievers.

Male or female, grab a tissue, or a long sleeveâpreferably yours, and let it out (for crying out loud.)]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Grief</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/01/30/grief/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 30 Jan 2012 08:00:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=350</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Grief is more of a process than a feeling. Whether grief is over what <em>was</em>, or the loss of someone who was in your lifeâit can be a slow, painful journey. The feelings involved will take up time, energy, and just when you think youâve crossed the bridge, a date shows itself on the calendar. It may be an anniversary of a diagnosis, surgery, or passing.
<ul>
	<li>Â Donât shut yourself off. People may need cues from you. Let them know you need their support.</li>
	<li>Cry if you feel like it. Tears provide a release. Youâll physically feel better.</li>
	<li>Vent if you need to. Donât be afraid to complain loudly to God. Job did.</li>
	<li>Pat yourself on the back. some daysÂ will be tough. Depression makes the smallest of activities more exhausting than a full dayâs work.</li>
	<li>Trust peace and strength will return to you.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Lean Into Your Grief</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/02/lean-into-your-grief/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 02 Feb 2012 08:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=352</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Give yourself <em>as long as you need</em> to grieve (diagnosis, loss of a body part, lifestyle, or passing of a loved one.) Some may not understand, especially if theyâve not been there, or even if they have.

But time alone is 50% of the healing. Youâve also got to do your part. Make time to journal, pray, mediate, talk with someone, write letters to the person or condition, join a support group or counseling. Allow a space for tears to feel welcome. âStuffing emotionsâ isnât healthy.

Youâre not nuts. Emotions bring us to the edge. Weâre raw, tired, may feel sad, regret, and anxious. Maybe you feel God abandoned you and/or someone else.

Look at your beliefs. Do you believe something good can come out of this? Whatever beliefs youÂ  have for your new life, you will gather evidence to support them. You can acknowledge this is a painful time, and youâre sad with this experienceâand you are willing to be part of your healing for as long as it takes.

Part of your healing may include asking the question. âWhy?â âHow?â And part of your healing will begin when you move away from those questions into questions like, âNow that itâs happened, what will I do?â âWhat one thing can I do today to bring myself some happiness?â There comes a time to stop looking down at the sorrow, and look up at the possibilities.

âWhen you do, the skyâs the limit.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Commitment To Your Highest Good:</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/06/commitment-to-your-highest-good/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 06 Feb 2012 08:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=357</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[At all times we are at a moment of choice. Some may decide to move through the cancer experience balancing spiritual Truth with medical fact. Some days your scale may tilt. If so, recommit to your choice. Even if you have to do it over and over every day. Be conscious of the direction you want to go. If youâre headed in the opposite direction, stop: meditate/reflect; pray/talk to yourself; grab an affirmationâor an ice cream cone; read a spiritual book/dig up a funny joke; call a friend/counselor.Â Whatever you do, intend for it to be helpful. Believe youâve received your good before you experience it.]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Can-Cer. . .</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/09/can-cer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 09 Feb 2012 08:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=361</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[I read a great idea in Unityâs <em>Daily Word</em>. The man who wrote the short article had been diagnosed with breast cancer. He meditated for a word or phrase to replace the term âcancerâ (which is such a trigger word.) His answer came:

Cancer is a contraction for <em>can cer</em>tainly!

You<em> can certainly</em> overcome any health challenge.

You <em>can</em> <em>certainly</em> experience absolute good!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Protect Your Teeth</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/protect-your-teeth/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 16 Feb 2012 08:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=368</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Chemo whetherÂ pill or I.V., and radiation can be really hard on your teeth. To prevent cavities, youâll want to step up your oral hygiene and avoid getting âdry mouth.â

I usually flossed before. Now I floss twice a day; everyday. Now Iâm also a fan of Biotene mouthwash, toothpaste and gum. When you look for gum, make sure it has the ingredient <em>Xylitol</em>. Ice Breakers Ice Cubes gum has it, too. Itâs what helps stimulate saliva flow and reduces dry mouth. Biotene dry mouth toothpaste and natural toothpastes (Tomâs of Maine, Dr. Nateâs) donât foam like traditional pastes because they donât use the ingredient Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS), or any derivative. SLS is a detergent, causing bubbling. It cleans by scrubbing and stripping the mouth of protective layer, thus drying out the mouth. Use a non-alcohol mouthwash with fluoride. Also, I found Dentswabsâthose little sponge lollipopsâhelped get rid of dry mouth after surgeries. If youâre a mouth breather, drink water to keep your mouth moist. Thatâll help prevent cavities. My dentist celebrated when after chemo I had âonlyâ one cavity!]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>368</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-02-16 08:00:45</wp:post_date>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[&#8230;] If the side effects of chemo or surgery anesthesia is making you constipated, donât just rely on fiber to get things moving again. The fiber requires hydration. Itâs not about drinking 32 oz. in one sitting. Sip throughout the day. In addition to constipation, itâll help prevent dizziness, kidney troubles, indigestion, dry eyes, nose and mouthâand a moist mouth will help prevent cavities. Hereâs a post on dry mouth,Â and protecting your teeth during chemo. [&#8230;]]]></wp:comment_content>

  <title>Happy Birthday, George!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/20/happy-birthday-george/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 20 Feb 2012 08:00:50 +0000</pubDate>

  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[George Washington, didnât have cancerâor wooden teeth. But he did have toothaches, and by age 58, heâd lost all his teeth. I found an interesting website that shares aspects of George Washingtonâs life, including his dental history. Each section has a short quiz at the end.

Entering his second term as President, George Washington delivered a short two paragraph inaugural address. (presumably because of mouth discomfort.)

<a title="George Washington's Teeth" href="http:// www.dentalmuseum.org/gw/01teeth.htm">Â www.dentalmuseum.org/gw/01teeth.htm</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Kind Words </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/23/kind-words/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 23 Feb 2012 08:00:15 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=375</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[A few months ago a complete stranger told me, âToday is your miracle!â

It was the perfect thing for me to hear at that very moment.

Sometimes <em>we</em> are someoneâs miracle!

Show up. Pass kindness on.

&nbsp;

Miracles happen all around us, all the time.

Stop. Look. Listen.

Accept your good.

&nbsp;

Today is <em>your</em> miracle!

Give thanks.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Conserving Energy  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/01/conserving-energy/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 01 Mar 2012 08:00:34 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=377</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If everything is a priority, then nothing is a priority. You may be frustrated with how tired you are, and you may want to push through that fatigue. But it really comes down to priorities. You may need to choose between activities, or schedule them during your high energy hours. Map out your day. It may go something like this:

Get out of bed. Eat a few spoons of yogurt. Lie on the couch. Shower. Put some clothes on. Lie on the couch. Finish dressing. Eat a few more spoonfuls. Rest until your ride picks you up for your doctor appointment. Come home and rest.

Or, maybe youâre needing to decide between a walk with a friend, or making dinner for tonight. Ask for help. We heal better when weâre not run-down. Our bodies require sleep to heal; to grow new, healthy cells. Think of a baby. You donât push that baby to stay awake when theyâre falling asleep. You honor that little soul. Honor yourself in that same way.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>377</wp:post_id>

<item>
  <title>Happy Leap Year!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/27/happy-leap-year/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 27 Feb 2012 08:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=380</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Okay, youâre not a frog, so why do we have leap year, anyway?

The earth takes approximately 365.24 days to circle around the sun once. Since 1582, nearly every four years February 29th is added to the Gregorian calendar. Without adding a day almost every four years, weâd lose close to six hours every year (about 24 days in one century.)

So, What will you do with all the extra time you'll have Wednesday?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Laughing Yoga</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/08/laughing-yoga/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 08 Mar 2012 08:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=387</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Ho-ho. Ha-ha-ha! Iâd been to laughing meditation before and thought it was dumb. A few people sitting around forcing âlaughsâ out. It wasnât my thing. A few months ago I found myself at a laughing yoga meeting. Iâd met the leader, and she was actually pretty funny! On my first visit there was also another first time visitor.

We did group introductions. Something Iâve never liked in a room filled with cancer patients. âHello. My name is ______ and I have (blah blah blah) cancer.â Itâs nails on a chalk board to me. I greeted everyone, said my name then handed it over to the man next to me. Someone stopped me and said, âYou didnât say what type of cancer you have.â I responded, âCancer isnât my identity. I came to laughing yoga for an escape.â The man next to me was a first time visitor from back east. He introduced himself then said, ââand I have bladder cancer.â Immediately, he let out a <em>ripping</em> <em>howl</em> of laughter. It shocked everyoneâinto laughter! Between my not wanting to affirm cancer, and his laughing at cancer, we shifted the group. Some of the regulars in the group skipped their cancer label for the first time. Everyone got a good laugh.

Whatâs not funny in your life now? Laugh at it! Go to the mirror and smile. Post a note âHo-ho. Ha-ha-ha!â Itâs not about denial. Itâs about moments of freedom.

Anyone remember the scene in Mary Poppins with Uncle Albert, âI Love to Laughâ?

<a href="http://youtu.be/pOMqqI-kzHY">I Love to Laugh</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Affirmations</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/05/affirmations/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 05 Mar 2012 08:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=392</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Whatâs one of your favorite affirmations or quotes?

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>392</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-03-05 08:00:54</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-05 08:00:54</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>affirmations</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
  <category domain="category" nicename="attitude-2"><![CDATA[Attitude]]></category>

  <title>Puppy Love</title>

  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you have a dog, or other pet that helps you get through cancer?

Is it their unconditional love? Their need of you to take care of them? Your desire to have support without having to look good, answer questions, or entertain a visitor?

Have you ever been part of animal therapy? What was your experience like?

<item>
  <title>Oâ Lucky One!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/15/o-lucky-one/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 15 Mar 2012 08:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=399</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[St. Patrick's Day. Indeed, a day I should have eaten some Lucky-Charm cereal.Â It was the first day I heard, "This looks suspicious." It was the first step on my journey toward an April Fool's day diagnosis. (I thought I'd be the one laughing!) My second opinion was on the Tuesday after Palm Sunday. (A bit freaky to have a cancer diagnosis the week of Good Friday!)

I do see how fortunate Iâve been the entire way through my journey of cancer. Every twist in the road was for my highest good. The good wasnât always obvious, but over and over the good shines through.

I am lucky.

P.S. Today is known as the "Ides of March" (mid-March, March 15.) It's the date on whichÂ Julius Caesar was stabbed 23 times to death in the Roman Senate by a group of conspirators, one of whom was his friend, Marcus Junius Brutus.

Rather than focusing on the Ides of March and "watching your back" I invite you to look for your rainbow, and the pot of gold this week!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Springtime</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/19/springtime/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 19 Mar 2012 08:00:39 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=401</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[We sprung our clocks ahead this week. Weâll have more hours of light in the evening for several months. How does this transfer into your own life? Do you anticipate <em>lighter</em> days ahead? Can you turn away from the darkness of cancer, at least sometimes? Is there bounce in your step? If not, can you imagine the day there will be lightness? Bounce? Imagine that lightness, and bring it into the feeling of ânowâ â not âsomeday.â

Itâs not to say ignore a rough time, or to brush over grief, regret, or sorrow. Itâs to honor the part of you that craves lightness, joy. You can honor both. Allow yourself time to be sad. Itâs real. AND allow yourself time to think of all the support you receive from the Universe. Did you have access to safe water today? Indoor plumbing? A day without throwing up? Those are all light shining through!

In what ways can you be like the spring flower reaching for the light? (even when it gets tossed about in the wind, it strives to reach, stand tall, and shine!)]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Financial Blues</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/22/financial-blues/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 22 Mar 2012 08:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=403</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Picture this:

Youâre in the United States of America. Itâs 2012. Youâve just been diagnosed with cancerâand have no health insurance. Maybe you recently lost your job, or you were on your spouseâs health plan and they lost their job. Perhaps you worked and didnât have health insurance. Unfortunately, there are lots of similar stories.

Cancer-related bills. Perhaps itâs the prescriptions, the doctor visits, chemo, radiation, or the lab tests and scans, or the cost of gas to get to the doctor. Maybe youâre fully covered by insurance, but arenât working. Have you cut spending on food or clothing? Have you spent your savings because of cancer?Â If youâd like to share, please do.

Ask for help. Talk to a hospital social worker. Call Medicare, Medicaid, Social security. As a tax payer, youâve paid into them. Go to reputable cancer websites such as American Cancer Society and ask if they can help you. If your energy is too low to do the search and inquire, have someone do it on your behalf, helping you as much as they can.]]></content:encoded>

  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Have you see Venus and Jupiter this month? Wow. Theyâre beautiful! No matter whatâs going on in the world, seeing two of our planets so bright, clear, and âcloseâ has been a welcome reprieve from much of the news going on. Night skies can do that. If you, caretaker or patient, can get outsideâgo. Look up. Take it in. The stars, moon, galaxies, and planets - they put things into perspective. Enjoy!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Whatâs New?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/03/29/whats-new/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 29 Mar 2012 08:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=408</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[(re: breast cancer)

Okay, your breasts are gone, but you have shape from implants. Your hair came back, but itâs different. Your energy isnât what it was before cancer - but it itâs better than it was the month after chemo, or radiation.

Whatâs working in your life? If we can accept that things (even non-cancer related) will never be the same as they were âbeforeâ cancer, we can begin to move on. Even if we donât accept it, things change. Weâll NEVER have THIS moment again. So, whatâs new with you?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Alpha Lipoic Acid, and Vitamin B  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/04/02/alpha-lipoic-acid-and-vitamin-b/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 02 Apr 2012 08:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=431</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[The medical treatment saved your life. Some wholistic treatments may help you feel better.

If your feet or hands burn and tingle as a result of neuropathy, ask your doctor about using Alpha Lipoic Acid (ALA.) Both my neurologist, and oncologist suggested it to me (600 mg 3x a day.) Iâve seen suggested ranges from 100-600 mg 3x day. Itâs suggested not going over 1,800 mg a day. Alpha Lipoic Acid can help repair nerve damage sometime caused by chemo, radiation. Itâs often used by people with diabetes to help with complications of diabetes.

Also, Vitamin B, especially B-12. Iâve been taking sublingual B-12, but recently learned methylcobalamin âmethylâ B-12 is better absorbed and better retained by the body than cyanocobalamin B-12 (the B-12 most people take.) Whatever form, B-12 works best when not swallowed as a pill/capsule. It works best when chewed, melted in the mouth, or received as a shot.

In addition to ALA and vitamin B-12, I used Neurontin (also known as Gabapentin.) They allÂ inched me forward. Be patient, especially if youâre tall. It takes the nerves on a tall person longer to get from their spine to their toes than it does on a shorter person.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>431</wp:post_id>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>alpha-lipoic-acid-and-vitamin-b</wp:post_name>

      <wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>

    </wp:commentmeta>
    <wp:commentmeta>

	<li>Â What helps you get through tough days, or tough events?</li>
	<li>What would you tell someone whoâs in a similar situation to help them out?</li>

Is/was one part of cancer the hardest for you?

For some, the hardest day is that of diagnosis. For others it may be the treatment itself, or perhaps the preparation such as tattoo markers for radiation. What was one of the toughest aspects for you, and how didÂ you move forward?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>âYou Should Try . . .â</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/04/16/you-should-try/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 16 Apr 2012 08:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=452</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA["You should try. . ." Have you heard it before? Does it make you laugh? Make you mad? Give you hope? From daily mega doses of ginger to broccoli pillsâto hydrogen peroxide. Complete strangers will tell you what you should try for your health. Never mind they donât know how healthy you were before cancer, or what your doctor has told you. Yes, you have free will, but be honest with your doctors about any changes incorporated before risking to counter act the treatment plan they're given you.

Iâve said this before. If youâve chosen western medical model as an avenue to help you, youâve got to work with it. Some of it is counter intuitive, like killing all cells - good and bad to save your life. Several good-hearted people told me to take mega doses of vitamin C while in chemo, or radiation. My medical team <em>specifically</em> asked me <em>not</em> to take any vitamin C or anti-oxidant supplements because they interfere with the treatment given. Later, do what you will. Iâm a fan of good food, a balanced diet, and that may or may not include supplements, knowing the body voids them pretty quickly.

Having said this, I did take ginger-root capsules during chemoâalong with anti-nausea medication. The capsules helped with very minor nausea, and warmed me up on the days I was cold. The ginger was a bit rough on my stomach. During chemo, we lose some stomach lining. Eat mellow food and youâll be fine.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>452</wp:post_id>

<item>
  <title>Sufi Proverb</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/04/19/sufi-proverb/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 19 Apr 2012 08:00:17 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=454</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Whether it's a job loss, a heart ache over a "the one" or a serious health diagnosis. It's all relative, and it usually takes time to see the good that's come from dark days and sleepless nights. I remember a break-up from years agoâtwo days before Valentine's. That week, I went to church for a social pick-me-up. I "randomly" chose from a basket of affirmations and thoughts passed around a circle. Around the time of my bi-lateral mastectomy, I came across the proverb again. Here it is for you, just incase you're the one needing to "randomly" receive it:

When the heart weeps for what it has lost, the spirit laughs for what it has found.

â Sufi Proverb]]></content:encoded>

  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Just this weekend I received this from a relative:

Breast cancer classification promises better therapies

In hopes to more precisely target treatmentsÂ and bypassÂ unnecessarily toxic therapies,Â researchers have devised 10 categories for breast cancer tumors.

The article is by Eryn Brown, Los Angeles Times.Â April 19 2012

The complete article can be viewed at:
<a title="Los Angeles Times Article" href="http://www.latimes.com/health/la-he-breast-cancer-genetics-20120419,0,7505697.story">http://www.latimes.com/health/la-he-breast-cancer-genetics-20120419,0,7505697.story</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>When Worry Returns</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/04/26/when-worry-returns/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 26 Apr 2012 08:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=460</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[We may flow in and out of worry. We breathe, and release the breath. We don't make a big deal about it. If we're stuck in worry, we can't move forward. We literally cannot think a positive and negative thought at the same time. Nor can we take a step forward and backward at the same time. We must decide what thought, and what direction we intend to go.

Sometimes it's hard. We don't always want to share our worries with our friends or caretakers. They may carry the same worries, and we may either want to spend our time with them in enjoyment, or maybe they're individuals who we know are not able to lift us in thought, feeling and well-being.

If worry interferes with your life, tell your doctor. There are several options: counseling and medication to name the most common. Also, organizations like American Cancer Society and National Cancer Institute have phone lines open 24 hours a day to help you in English, or Spanish.

ACS:<span style="color:#000000;"> 1-800-227-2345</span>

NCI: 1-800-4-CANCER, or 1-800-422-6237

Other posts on worry:

<a title="Worry" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=112&amp;action=edit">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=112&amp;action=edit</a>

<a title="Decide how you will approach this opportunity" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/02/decide-how-you-will-you-approach-this-opportunity/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/02/decide-how-you-will-you-approach-this-opportunity/</a>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>460</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-04-26 08:00:54</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-04-26 08:00:54</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>when-worry-returns</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

<item>
  <title>Wear a Hat</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/07/wear-a-hat/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 07 May 2012 08:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=490</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Over ten years ago, I lived in New Zealand. I really liked how they took a serious topic like skin cancer, and had fun with it. Below is a link to two photos from a New Zealand newspaper.

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/use-your-head-wear-a-hat.pdf">Use Your Head Wear A Hat!</a>

Also, check out the blog:<a title="SunnySleevez" href="http:// sunnysleevez.wordpress.com" target="_blank">Â sunnysleevezÂ </a>for some tips to protect your skin.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>490</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-05-07 08:00:29</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-05-07 08:00:29</wp:post_date_gmt>

<item>
  <title>Motherâs Day</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/10/mothers-day/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 10 May 2012 08:00:42 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=496</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Maybe you're a parent who's also a caretaker. Maybe you've become the caretaker of a parent.

Below is a poem from the Sufi Mystic, Hafiz. He lived 1320-1389, about one hundred years after Rumi. Read this poem with Motherâs Day in mind. Iâm fortunate to have a mother who embodies this poem 100%. If you donât feel that way about the set up you had or have, become the sunâbecome the energy that lights up the whole sky, never demanding back. Happy Motherâs Day. Thank you. With love.

Even after all this time

The sun never says to the earth,

âYou owe me.â

Look what happens

with a love like that,

It lights the whole sky.

â Hafiz]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Skin Care</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/14/skin-care/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 14 May 2012 08:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=503</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[So many aspects of cancer treatment dry the skin.Â Moisturize it baby!Â Radiation is like one big, bad sun burn. Protect your skin more than usual during and after the months of radiation. I did and my skin looks great again.
<ul>
	<li>Â Cleanse with warm water, not hot, and moisturize while your skin is damp. In the morning, moisturize. At nighttime, moisturize.</li>
	<li>Drink plenty of water. Things like soup, pudding, or popsicles also count as liquids. If you want flavor to water, add a tiny bit of juice. Sodas and warm liquids donât hydrate. Hydrationâinside and out of the body, is really important for skin care.</li>
	<li>Stay out of the sun, especially during treatments like chemo and radiation. You may notice temporary pigmentation changes. Maybe red, or tan blotches. Cosmetic concealer may help, or just roll with it. (Depending on the area being treated, you may be asked not to wear make-up, perfumes or deodorant.)</li>
</ul>
Two weeks into my radiation the weather was gorgeous. I had plans to meet with friends staying at a local beach cottage. Aware forgiveness is often easier obtained than permission,Â I told my doctor my weekend plans, adding "I'll only be in direct sun a few hours." I wasn't sure he'd give me the nod.Â He okayed it with my using sunscreen, a broad-brimmed hat, tying a scarf around my neck, and wearing a blouse with a collar over a tank top. I doubt I would have thought it through to this extent, and it would have been a bummer to show up for Monday radiation with a sun burn. They postponeânot cancel treatments. My self-imposed cancer treatment rule was: No postponing any treatments. Focus on the light at the end of the tunnel and do whatever it takes to get there as soon as possible.

Your body will thank you - now and later.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>A Pain in the âJoints</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/17/a-pain-in-the-joints/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 17 May 2012 08:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=507</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[You ache. Your joints hurt. Shoulders. Hands. Hips. Feet. Knees. Itâs not because âYouâre of that age.â Nor is it arthritis. Cancer treatment comes with some trade-offs. One of them is joint stiffness, and pain. The pain is a side effect from chemo, hormone therapy, and radiation. The good news (they tell me) is the pain gradually goes away when all the treatment ends. And unlike arthritis, treatment-related joint pain doesnât permanently damage the joints.

According to the <em>Cure </em>magazine, 47 percent of 200 patients taking hormone therapy report joint pain and of those, 67 percent rated the pain as moderate or severe. Itâs thought medication compliance is affected by this pain.

While standard arthritis pain treatment may not help, <em>Cure</em> magazine states that studies have shown pain relief from acupuncture, and high doses of vitamin D for women deficient in this vitamin.

It comes down to the obvious. Manage your weight. Get plenty of exercise. (This may vary depending where you are on your journey, and the level of pain that day.) If youâre at the gym and donât feel you can grip the weights, consider lifting straps (they warp around your wrists and the weight/bar youâre lifting or pulling down.) Walk, swim, stretch. Your speed may have changed with joint pain. If a gym class has a fast pace, set your own, slower pace. Who cares if you're out of sync with them - mind your body. It's yet another aspect of self-confidence and creativity to rebuild after cancer treatment. âTo thy own self be true!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Fatigue and Eating  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/21/fatigue-and-eating-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 21 May 2012 08:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=519</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If youâre not eating much and are tired, you may want to do a bit of exercise an hour before mealtime. It could be four leg lifts each leg, a walk around the block, or if youâre up to speed, back to your routine. Exercise will bring you energy, and stimulate appetite. Avoid drinking (water, juice, etc) before eating. The liquid will fill you up, and you wonât eat as much. If youâre fatigued, youâve got to make sure youâre getting enough calories, and protein into your system.

I now cook casseroles, enchiladas, and meatballs. I make a large amount and divide it into smaller containers for left overs, or to freeze. Later in the week, I make a salad or put a handful of carrots or snap peasâor cook up some vegetablesâadd some rice, pasta or quinoa and Iâve got a great, easy meal.

Itâs okay to eat breakfast food at night. Save your energy. If youâre tired at the end of the day, you may want to make a sandwich, or a bowl of cereal. (I made the mistake of thinking making pancakesâeven the âjust add waterâ ones would be an easy dinner. I ended up standing at the stove eating them as they cooked because Iâd become so tired during the process.)

I am a big fan of nutritious snacks throughout the day. String cheese, raisins, apples, bananas, yogurt, baby carrots, snap peas, nuts, hard-boiled egg. . . This is great if you donât want to see a big meal, or arenât eating much at once. I also keep nutritional supplement drinks like Boost, or Ensure in the refrigerator. Some generic brands are good, too. Theyâre a few dollars less expensive, and I even like the taste of some of them better. (Served cold and shaken is still the best.) Protein powder is also an option. Itâs good for putting into smoothies. (I donât care what they sayâI still like the taste of blended fruit better without the powder. But sometimes youâve gotta do what youâve gotta do.)

&nbsp;

For other tips on Fatigue see the following links:

<strong><a href="http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fatigue/">http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fatigue/</a></strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fatigue/managing/more_tips.jsp">http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fatigue/managing/more_tips.jsp</a></strong>
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Fiber and Iron</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/24/fiber-and-iron/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 24 May 2012 15:00:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=581</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Fiber</strong>

<strong></strong>Did you know a small pear has 9% more fiber than five dried prunes? Itâs not just about fiber to get things moving in the right directionâitâs about hydration and fiber. Especially if youâre constipated, make sure youâre drinking enough water. Otherwise, youâre just stuffing fiber on top of medications, etcâand none are making progress in exiting your body!

<strong>Iron</strong>

Watermelon is higher in iron than beets. Green peas, and green beans too. So are black beans, brown, white - they are all high in iron. If you eat meat, beef is higher in iron and protein than most other meats. Take vitamin C with calcium, and vitamin C with ironâbut donât take calcium with iron. Calcium blocks iron absorption, vitamin C enhances absorption of calcium and iron.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>581</wp:post_id>

  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-05-24 15:00:40</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>fiber-and-iron</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

<item>
  <title>Fiber Muffin Recipe </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/28/fiber-muffin-recipe/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 28 May 2012 15:00:16 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=583</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Below is a recipe right off the back of the Bobâs Red Mill flaxseed Meal package.

I loving call these fiber muffins, âPower Bars.â Theyâre great to have after surgeryâwhen all the medication has thrown you off. I make them <em>without</em> baking powder (I never use it) or nuts, and freeze them. I take one out the night before I know Iâll have it. They are super moist, and effective. . .

I've only had one person look at me cockeyed when I enthusiastically offered, "Want a fiber muffin?" Everyone else has loved these.

Enjoy!
<ul>
	<li>1 1/2 cups Unbleached White Flour</li>
	<li>3/4 cup Bobâs Red Mill Flaxseed Meal</li>
	<li>3/4 cup Oat Bran</li>
	<li>1 cup Brown Sugar</li>
	<li>1 tsp. Baking Powder</li>
	<li>2 tsp. Baking Soda</li>
	<li>1/2 tsp. Salt</li>
	<li>2 tsp. Cinnamon</li>
	<li>1 1/2 cups Carrots, shredded</li>
	<li>2 Apples, peeled and shredded</li>
	<li>1/2 cup raisins (optional)</li>
	<li>1 cup Nuts, chopped (optional)</li>
	<li>3/4 cup Milk</li>
	<li>2 Eggs, beaten</li>
	<li>1 tsp. Vanilla</li>
</ul>
Mix together Flour, Flaxseed Meal, Oat Bran, Brown Sugar, Baking Soda, Salt, Cinnamon in a large bowl. Stir in Carrots, Apples, Raisins, Nuts. Combine Milk, Beaten Eggs and Vanilla. Pour liquid ingredients into dry ingredients. Stir until ingredients are moistened. Do Not over mix. Fill muffin cups 3/4 full. Bake @ 350Âº F for 15-20 minutes. Yields 15 medium muffins.
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Looking Good</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/05/31/looking-good/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 31 May 2012 15:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=585</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Look Good...Feel Better classes.Â  <a href="http://www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org">www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org</a> Â  (A perk for being diagnosed.) Iâd gone to this class two days before beginning chemo. Most of the other women had just completed cancer treatment and had baby hair growing back. In the class I met a new friend who invited me over to her house the next day to try on some wigs. She had severalâshe spent over $600. for wigs. I tried them on, but opted to wear scarves instead.

If you donât know what colors, textures or styles of scarves look good on you, grab an honest friend to help you out. On the way to chemo one day, a friend and I stopped by the cancer center resource room. The volunteer offered me to try on some turbans and wigs. I grabbed what we all considered to be a goofy turban style and casually plopped it on my head. The three of us simultaneously had an eye-popping, jaw-dropping response. The turban looked great on me! (Hopefully not meaning my looks are goofy...)

What I ended up wearing were colorful cotton scarves. They were cool, and comfortable. I wore colors that complimented my outfits, and were in my personal color scheme.

[caption id="attachment_586" align="alignnone" width="300"]<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/img_2259.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-586" title="IMG_2259" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/img_2259.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a> Scarves and brim bands for hats.[/caption]

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>New FDA Breast Implant Approval</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/04/new-fda-breast-implant-approval/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 04 Jun 2012 15:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=591</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[In March, this year, a new âGummy Bearâ breast implant was approved by the FDA for use in America. Itâs been used in Europe and Canada for years. (Theyâre not the ones in France that hit the news earlier this year.) This will be the third FDA approved silicone implant available in America. This implant offers a textured style, to stay in place, and various shapes. The date isnât known to the public yet, but is expected June or July this year.Â  The company, Sientra, is located in Santa Barbara, CA.

For information on the breast implant typical procedure, types of implants, styles, benefits, concerns, and recovery, see this link: <a title="Breast Implant Information" href="http://www.surgery.org/consumers/procedures/breast/breast-implants">http://www.surgery.org/consumers/procedures/breast/breast-implants</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Friends and Neighbors:</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/07/friends-and-neighbors/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 07 Jun 2012 15:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=594</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Dear friends and family,

What do you do well? What are you willing to do?
<ul>
	<li>Are you a healthy cook? It doesnât even need to be a full meal. Bring over a serving of what you had for dinner, or what youâll have later.</li>
	<li>Do you have energy, and go places? If youâre off to the grocery store, or if youâre willing to take a short visit to a park, or beachâoffer that to someone with cancer (or aged, sick, not driving.) It doesnât need to be longâin fact, it shouldnât be.</li>
	<li>Use a piece of paper, or poster board and draw or write something. Handmade cards from kids are cheerful, too!</li>
	<li>When you drop by for a visit, look around. Pick up the broom, take out the trash, look to see what is needed for the next few days. (Toilet paper, paper towels, food, and if there are any special requests.)</li>
	<li>Does the person you're visiting need laundry washed? A bed made? The feather bed fluffed? Do dishes need washing? Donât ask. Do it.</li>
	<li>If there are things you know you're not the one to do, let the person you're helping know that. Also let them know what you can/will do.</li>
</ul>
<div>When I needed drivers and cooks, I found, to my surprise, very few people who lived near me drove distances, or cooked! I had offers for conversation, walks, and gifts. Those three things were pretty low on my list of what I needed. It's amazing, though, how things unfold. We are taken care of. Maybe not by the ones we expect, but people step up. I had a neighbor I'd never met come to my door and ask what I needed from the store.</div>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

May more neighbours randomly ring your door and offer help. (Isn't that something, when people you never suspect step up to help?)

Catherine

<item>
  <title>In The Beginning</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/11/in-the-beginning/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2012 15:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=601</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[When I was first diagnosed and looking for books, I found them too medical, knocking medical treatment, or oozing with estrogen. I didn't come home with any of them.

This is the first in a series of four short (1.5 minute) book trailers. It includes tips, and book excerpts. My intention is to show aspects of cancer treatment such as the port, expanders and implantsÂ without being scary or flippant. The book provides friends and families ideas to move from feeling awkward, into being of service.

Please share this video.Â Thank you.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l0TMPKxp9TA

<item>
  <title>The Haircut</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/14/the-haircut/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 14 Jun 2012 15:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=605</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[A year before cancer, I'd donated 10" of my hair to Locks of Love. (Don't confuse it with locks <em>for</em> love. They're different.) I'd always loved hats and scarves, but this wasn't exactly what I had in mind. . .

This is the second in a series of four short (1.5 minute) book trailers. It includes tips, and book excerpts. The upcoming book is laced with humor and raw moments; lightly weaving a spiritual edge throughout.

Please share this video.Â Thank you.

<item>
  <title>Mid-Treatment Thrills</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/18/mid-treatment-thrills/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 18 Jun 2012 15:00:10 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=611</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Last chemo! Eyebrows growing back! Friends/Family! â And soooo much to be grateful for!

This is the third in a series of four short (1.5 minute) book trailers. It includes tips, and book excerpts. There are no use of Â terms like: fight, struggle, battle, war, hero, victim or survivor.

Please share this video.Â Thank you.

<a title="Mid-TreatmentÂ Thrills" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/18/mid-treatment-thrills/">http://youtu.be/0YUqcQn26xE</a>

<item>
  <title>Blue Skies and Implants</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/21/blue-skies-and-implants/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 21 Jun 2012 15:00:11 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=614</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Chemo's over. You'll still need to conserve your energy. (In fact, maybe more now, because chemo's accumulative.) Even with that, everything around you will come alive. Blue skies are bluer. Even instant mashed potatoes are manna from heaven. Your hair will grow in silky smooth and baby-fine. Many people will touch it without asking.

This is the fourth in a series of four short (1.5 minute) book trailers. It includes tips, and book excerpts. What do expanders, and implants look like? How about an after survey vest, and drains? Pain management to decrease reliance on drugs? Ivivi SofPulse worked wonders for me.

Please share this video.Â Thank you.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=scClioI6x5A&amp;feature=plcp

<strong>Related Articles and Videos:</strong>
<ul>
	<li><a title="In TheÂ Beginning" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/11/in-the-beginning/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/11/in-the-beginning/</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/14/the-haircut/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/14/the-haircut/</a></li>
	<li><a title="Mid-TreatmentÂ Thrills" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/18/mid-treatment-thrills/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/18/mid-treatment-thrills/</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>I'd love to tell you. . .</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/25/id-love-to-tell-you/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 25 Jun 2012 15:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/22/id-love-to-tell-you/</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Great Sufi Master, Hafiz, (1320-1389) and Rumi (about 100 years earlier) are known as "realized souls." The Rumi quote in Namaste Consulting Inc last week's blog I'd love to tell you. . .. is a theme we sometimes hear when diagnosed with cancer, or someone we love dies. It's the softer version of, "It's all good" when things appear anything but.

As a New Thought minister, I understood there is no loss. I got we are never ending energy. I grasped we are souls having a human experience. I also understood the need to grieve my past (could've, would've, should've....) My present (fear, confusion.) My future (it was forever changed.)

Allow yourselfâand others to be the soul who knows this stuffâand still needs tender care in this human experience. If you're a friend ready to share, "I'd just have the doc chop my breasts off and move on with life."âDon't. It's not comforting to hear you say that, and you do not know what you'd do until you're the one having this discussion with your doctor.

Yes, I'd love to tell you, "It's a breeze." "You'll be better from this experience." "Don't grieve." But I don't tell you that because everyone moves through this in their own way. Whatever your situation, I wish you health and happiness with grace, ease and strength. Peace.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Guided Meditation</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/06/28/guided-meditation/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 28 Jun 2012 15:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=644</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/thumbnail-5-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-648" title="Meditate any way you can" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/thumbnail-5-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="85" /></a>

Thanks Google Image for photo

People think they need to sit up straight and hold their hands in a special way to meditate. No. While that's one way to mediate, you can meditate while washing dishes, or walking. Just be present with what you're doing in the moment. Fed up with traffic and the day zipping by? Take three conscious breaths at the stoplight. Be aware of breath in; breath out.Â At times of pain and fatigue it can be more difficult to meditate on your own.Â Guided meditation and hypnotherapy got me through some rough spots during cancer treatment.

The University of Michigan Comprehensive Cancer Center has a websiteÂ  (link below) with quite a few guided imagery meditations specifically for cancer and caregivers. They include mediations for preparing for treatment, addressing pain, fatigue, anxiety, perspective and balance, and seven meditations specifically for caregivers.Â <a href="http://www.cancer.med.umich.edu/support/guided_imagery_podcasts_descriptions.shtml#relax">Introduction to Guided ImageryÂ </a>(4 min. 33 sec.)

Check out the list of descriptions. they're free and can be downloaded into MP3 files.

<a title="Guided Imagery Audio Descriptions" href="http://www.cancer.med.umich.edu/support/guided_imagery_podcasts_descriptions.shtml#relax">http://www.cancer.med.umich.edu/support/guided_imagery_podcasts_descriptions.shtml#relaxÂ </a>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>644</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-06-28 08:00:22</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-06-28 15:00:22</wp:post_date_gmt>

<item>
  <title>Smart Drugs for Her2 and Hodgkinâs  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/02/smart-drugs-for-her2-and-hodgkins/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 02 Jul 2012 15:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=651</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-10-aspx.jpeg"><img title="T-DM1" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-10-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="96" /></a>

Thanks Google ImageÂ for diagram

About one in five cases of breast cancer are Her2 positiveâmeaning the tumors are high in protein. Great news! Not only for those with Her2, but for those with Hodgkinâs lymphoma.

The Food and Drug Administration has approved T-DM1. Usually women with Her2 breast cancer are given Herceptin, aÂ <a href="http://www.cancer.gov/dictionary?expand=m#monoclonal%20antibody">monoclonal antibody</a>Â that attaches to proteins on some cancer cells and slows or stops the growth of the cells. (<a href="http://www.cancer.gov/dictionary">http://www.cancer.gov/dictionary</a>) along with a type of chemo. In the trials, the two drugs were attached to each other. The chemo remains inactive until the Herceptin carries it to the tumor. Side effects reported are temporary nausea, and some muscle cramps. T-DM1 is expected to be on market next year.Â <a href="http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jun/20/tp-new-arsenal-in-cancer-war/">http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jun/20/tp-new-arsenal-in-cancer-war</a>.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

<item>
  <title>Got Attitude?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/05/got-attitude/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 05 Jul 2012 15:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=656</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="text-decoration:underline;"><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-11-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-657" title="Attitude" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-11-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="120" /></a></span>

Thanks Google Image for photo

<em>"You've gotta ac-cent-u-ate the positive. E-lim-in-ateÂ the negative. Latch-on to the affirmative. Don't mess with Mr. In-Between. . ."</em>

I was raised to see the world in a positive light. In high school, to my advantage, my mom told my dad that I see the world through rose-colored glasses. My dad told her to get me a new pair. After college, I dated a man for a short time. He felt the world was out to get him, and everyone should be behave better than they were. I felt the Universe supported me, and everyone was doing the best they could at any particular moment. One day, in public, heâd had enough. Ranting how âPollyannaâ I was. It didnât take me long to look back and see the gift I received was his breaking up with me two days before Valentineâs.

You donât have to be thankful for cancer. You donât have to put up with nonsense from anyone. You do have to realize that only you can change your thoughts. If you donât change them, youâll continue to get more of the sameâand if you donât like what youâve been getting, then youâre at fault for not taking action, beginning with your thoughts.

I find this really funny. During cancer we hear the importance of a good attitude. But what do we read? â<em>War</em> on cancer!â âAnother <em>arsenal</em> in cancer <em>war</em>!â â<em>Kill</em> the cells!â âSmart chemo <em>bomb</em>â â<em>Fight</em> and <em>Battle</em> it!â â<em>Kick</em> itâs butt, it <em>sucksâ</em>â and on and on. . . It isnât an easy journey! But what we fight to get, we fight to keep. Focus on the health, not the cancer. Energy flows where attention goes. If we focus on health throughout language, thoughts and actions, weâre more likely to achieve it with ease than if we focus on <em>beating</em> cancer. This doesnât mean skip appointments or medication. It means being aware of conversations in which you engage, including self-talk. Go have fun today. Take in life. Know youâre supported by life, and when you pass by the mirror, turn and give a wink, or thumbs up! If youâre not familiar with the song, <em>Accentuate the Positive, </em>give it a listen. (iTunes has lots of versions.)
<div></div>
<div><span class="hg"><span class="hw" style="font-size:24px;">
</span></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Feeling Gloomy?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/09/feeling-gloomy/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 09 Jul 2012 15:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=662</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/daisy.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-663" title="Daisy" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/daisy.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="120" /></a></strong>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for photo

<strong>Pray</strong>. If you pray, do it with feeling, not by rote. If youâre used to saying a particular prayer, say it slowly, listen to the words. Doing this, you may learn you donât understand what the prayer means. Know your intention of prayer is for peace, healing, comfort. . . On nights I couldnât fall asleep, or if I was in too much pain to think my own prayer, Iâd say one of two prayers I grew up with. With each breath inhalation, Iâd say one word of the prayer. Iâd end up falling asleep in the process.

A note on prayer. I believe we pray to change <em>our</em> consciousness; not Godâs. I believe God is an energy of Love and Light. Itâs your birthright to be hereâjust as much as anyone else's, Â or the moon and the stars. I've heard some people believe they (or others) are punished by a "higher power" when they get a disease. Wow! If you've had an upbringing that planted that seed, I suggest you pull that weed-thought out of your consciousness, and get a bigger God.

<strong>Meditate</strong>. In prayer, we talk to God. In meditation, God talks to us. In meditation, we don't ask or tell God anything. We listen. Donât know how to meditate? There are tons of ways to meditate. One quick way to shift energy is to verbally âomâ â just let out a long, âOmmmmm.â Itâs the sound the universe makes while turning. If a body part hurts, try touching that part if itâs comfortable, and âomâ to it, sending it the healing vibration. Some say, âAum.â If you choose this way, pronounce each letter as itâs soft syllable, a-u-m. Let them run together. Either way, take a deep breath, let the sound roll up and out, and hold it as long as you comfortably can. Repeat at least three times. Sit in the silence. You will feel a shift, and the energy around you will shift, too.

<strong>Gratitude</strong>: I donât believe you need to be grateful for cancer, but what about all that support you? Those whoâve gone before you have made your journey easier. You medical team? Insurance? Friends, family, neighbors, strangers who help? Love received and the opportunity to give back, or to have a conversation or relationship you wouldnât have had prior to cancer? Insights? The list goes on. Keep adding to it.
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>
