<item>
  <title>Lymphedema and Cancer Rehabilitation  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/12/lymphedema-and-cancer-rehabilitation/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 12 Jul 2012 15:00:52 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=665</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-15-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-666" title="Hope" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-15-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="106" /></a>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for photo

If your affected limb feels heavy, numb or tingles, you may have the beginning stage of lymphedemaâeven if you canât see a difference in extremity size. The sensation is a warning. Pay attention. If you feel the warning signs, and especially if you notice rings donât fit, find a certified lymphedema therapist. A North America listing can be found at <a href="http://www.clt-lana.org">http://www.clt-lana.org</a>.

A lymphedema therapist may or may not sell lymphedema management supplies such as bandages, garments and donning aides. If they donât sell them, theyâll be able to direct you to a certified fitter that does. Compression garments last six months before the elastic breaks down. Plan to buy two a year. You might check with your cancer center to see if thereâs some financial aid for compression sleeves. They run about $100 if theyâre ready made, out-of-the-box. Plan to add $50-$75 for a custom compression sleeve. The gauntlet or glove, costs about an additional $70. Insurance doesnât cover these products. Boy, if Iâm not the fairy of good news! Sorry.

Dr. Tammy E. Mondry is a certified lymphedema therapist and orthopedic manual therapist specializing in providing lymphedema services. In this Aware Talk Radio interview (14 mins.) she discusses Lymphedema and the treatment options available to those experiencing Lymphedema. <a href="http://newhorizonspt.com/assets/AwareTalkRadioEdit.mp3">http://newhorizonspt.com/assets/AwareTalkRadioEdit.mp3</a>

Her website includes articles sheâs written, and information about lymphedema.Â <a href="http://newhorizonspt.com/lymphedema.html">http://newhorizonspt.com/lymphedema.html</a>

Other posts on Lymphedema:

<a title="Helping The LymphaticÂ System" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/14/helping-the-lymphatic-system/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/14/helping-the-lymphatic-system</a>

<a title="What isÂ Lymphedema?" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/19/what-is-lymphedema/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/19/what-is-lymphedema</a>

<a title="Warning Signs ofÂ Lymphedema" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/22/warning-signs-of-lymphedema/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/22/warning-signs-of-lymphedema</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Tips During Radiation</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/16/tips-during-radiation/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 16 Jul 2012 15:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=671</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>
</strong>

[caption id="attachment_672" align="alignnone" width="160"]<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-17-aspx.jpeg"><img class="size-full wp-image-672" title="Emu" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-17-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="140" /></a> Where does emu oil come from? An emu![/caption]

Thanks Google Image for photo

The list ofÂ  âdonât doâ seems long and limiting. Ask your doctor if you have <em>any</em> questionsâeven if you think theyâre dumb. Ask about your risks. Ask about your treatment plan. Ask. Ask. Ask. For me, radiation was psychologically tougher than other aspects of cancer treatment. The aspect of radiation marker tattoos (to ensure the <em>exact</em> same spot is radiated daily) was <em>very</em> close to a deal breaker for me.

Take it seriouslyâbut lighten up. Listen to yourselfâbut stop the monkey mind (the mind that jumps from one thought to another.) Trust your medical teamâbut donât abdicate your participation on that team.

These are tips that helped me, or that Iâve heard. Ask your doctor before using them. At first, my radiology oncologist wasnât crazy about the idea of my using emu oil everyday after radiation. He worried the oil may stay on my body, and intensify any chance of my skin burning. We came to an agreement and I used 99% aloe vera gel and emu oil throughout the day for two months. I didnât burn or peel. After radiation treatment completed, I stopped aloe vera (which is not a moisturizer) and continued moisturizing my skin with emu oil for another month throughout everyday. My skin looks and feels silky smooth. Instead of itching, I âtappedâ or âTarzanedâ the skin that itched. Immediately let your doctor know of any changes to your skin âcolor, infection, itchiness. Keep them in the loop with whatÂ  you are doing/using on your body. Drink lots of water, too.

As for shaving the treated area, donât. And wait until your skin has recovered after treatment before you shave that area. If you have to shave the treated area, ask your doctor. They may suggest an electric razor. Iâve had so many âlucky twistsâ in my experience with cancer. Two years earlier without knowing Iâd have radiation, and be told not to shave, I had laser hair removal in my axilla (armpit.) I rarely shave now. I shaved once before radiation beganâand when my skin healed. Like I said, it was one of my âlucky twistsâ in this journey.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cosmetics Tips During Treatment </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/19/cosmetics-tips-during-treatment-part-i/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 19 Jul 2012 15:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=693</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/img-logo.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-735" title="look good feel better logo" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/img-logo.jpg" alt="" width="140" height="120" /></a>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for official logo

I consider myself fortunate to have taken part in the "Look Good, Feel Better" program.Â <a href="http://www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org">www.lookgoodfeelbetter.org</a>.Â The classes are free, and while I don't consider myself a real girly-girl, I enjoyed learning some make-up tricks, and spending time the with women in this class.Â TheÂ American Cancer Society (or it'sÂ version in Canada, New Zealand, and other countries) along with Personal Care products Council Foundation, Professional Beauty Association, and National Cosmetology Association put on this free class with cosmetic tips and hands-on learning. This will be covered in the next few posts. The recommendation's include:
<ul>
	<li>Â Properly use and store make-up.</li>
	<li>Wash your hands before applying make-up.</li>
	<li>Instead of your hands, use cotton balls, sponges, or Q-tips to apply make-up. (This took a while for me to get the hang of.)</li>
	<li>Donât re-use the applicator. If you need to apply more make-up, get out another cotton ball.</li>
	<li>Close your make-up tightly after use.</li>
	<li>Donât use old make-up. Especially eye make-up. Replace it as recommended by the manufacturer.</li>
	<li>Donât share cosmetic applicators. This means sponges, swabs, mascara wands. Donât do it. (What if it had been dropped a month ago on your friendâs carpet? What if you learn they have âpink eye?â)</li>
	<li>Test make-up in the store on your hand, not your face. (For the same reasons not to share make-up.)</li>
</ul>
Remember to smile. <em>That's</em> what makes people beautiful!

<a title="Why Bother Wearing Cosmetics During CancerÂ Treatment?" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/23/why-bother-wearing-cosmetics-during-cancer-treatment/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/23/why-bother-wearing-cosmetics-during-cancer-treatment</a>

<a title="Lips, Eyes and Nails DuringÂ Cancer" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/26/lips-eyes-and-nails-during-cancer/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/26/lips-eyes-and-nails-during-cancer</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Why Bother Wearing Cosmetics During Cancer Treatment?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/23/why-bother-wearing-cosmetics-during-cancer-treatment/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 23 Jul 2012 15:00:16 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=737</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/4848435620_753bfa404c_m1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-762" title="make-up" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/4848435620_753bfa404c_m1.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="180" /></a></strong>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for photo

<strong>Foundation/ Blush</strong>

If you get dark circles or discolored skin, concealer will do the trick. If you donât use concealer, your fist step is moisturizer. Then itâs showtime! Use a foundation color that matches your normal skin tone. Apply make-up with a clean sponge, blending the edges. I was surprised at what a difference using blush made. It can make a gray chemo face look vibrant and healthy, happy. I got pretty good with a cotton ballâhalf a ball over one cheekbone, and half over the other cheekbone. Then a light swipe down the bridge of the nose for a sun-kissed look face.

<strong>Mascara</strong>

Bit by bit my eyelashes fell outâthe ones leaving would exit falling into my eyes, bothersome and a reminder I was losing them. Then one day I noticed they werenât falling in my eyes anymore. They were darn near all gone! Tips for your mascara:
<ul>
	<li>Donât add water to mascara, and donât wash the mascara wand in water. If itâs old, get new mascara.</li>
	<li>Donât âpumpâ the mascara. Pull the wand out, and apply to the top lashes by blinking down as you move the wand slightly up. Then, gently rock the wand back and forth across the lower lashes. If you need more mascara on the applicator, put it in the tube, then remove it (still mindful not to pump air into the container.) Remove all eye make-up completely every night with gentle eye make-up remover.</li>
</ul>
Bottom line: Make-up may help you look and feel better, but it isn't who you are. I <em>always</em> got out of bedâeven if I only got to the couch. I <em>always</em> got dressed and brushed my teethâeven if it took me an hour, with lying on the couch after completing each step of the task. Until about half way through the process, I put on make-up. Then came days where I chose between putting on make-up, orÂ getting dressed. Those who saw me told me I was making great decisions!

Related posts:

    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[You're so right - there are days when makeup isn't an option (instead it's just put on whatever's possible, plus a smile). But I think if I had to choose one thing to apply it would have to be blush. During chemo my blood counts were low, making me crazy pale - a little blush helped with the complexion. 

Catherine

<item>
  <title>Lips, Eyes and Nails During Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/26/lips-eyes-and-nails-during-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 26 Jul 2012 15:00:14 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=766</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-18-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-768" title="lipstick" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-18-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="120" /></a></strong>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for photo

<strong>Lipliner/Lipstick</strong>

Itâs the same as before cancerâoutline your lips with a lipliner pencil. This should prevent your lipstick from âbleeding.â Chose lipliner and lipstick that compliment each other, from the same color family. Use moisturizing lipstick.

<strong>Eyebrows/ Eye shadow/ Eyeliner</strong>

One of the volunteers in the Look Good...Feel Better class shared that sheâd been waxing her eyebrows thin for a few years before cancer. After cancer, she had <em>super</em> thin eyebrows. Before you lose your eyebrows, take an up-close photo of your face so youâll know where to âpaint them onâ when the time comes. I didnât use much eye shadowâI did the basics, and I did them for me, not anyone else. I prioritized my energy. If youâve got the energy and are used to wearing eye shadow, or feel it makes a difference, use Q-tips and toss them out when done each day. I did use eyeliner. It gives the illusion of having eyelashes. It helps frame the eyes. Wipe the eyeliner pencil with a clean tissue after each use, or shave the pencil after each use for a fresh start the following day.

<strong>Nail Care</strong>

I looked like I had âsmokerâs nailsâ without my ever smoking. They were yellow, dry, very brittle and had deep grooves. You may want to cut your nails short so they donât catch on anything and torn ripped off. At this stage, they may even look better short. Nail polish can cover the yellow. You can find undercoats with protein. Wear gloves for doing chores; washing dishes. Never cut your cuticles (even when not in treatment.) Use hand moisturizer, even oil, and rub it into your cuticles. Do not use artificial nails during chemo. (Iâd strongly suggest avoiding nail salons during this time.) As always, tell your doctor about signs of infection, or inflammation.

Related Posts:
<ul>
	<li><a title="Cosmetics Tips DuringÂ Treatment" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/19/cosmetics-tips-during-treatment-part-i/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/19/cosmetics-tips-during-treatment-part-i</a></li>

</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Watermelon!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/02/watermelon/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 02 Aug 2012 15:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=775</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-22-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-776" title="Watermelon" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-22-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="106" /></a>

Thanks Goole Image for photo

August 3rd is National Watermelon Day here in the USA.Â  During chemo for cancer treatment, I ate one watermelon a week. Itâs important for those in treatment to eat food high in iron, and to take in plenty of liquid. (Watermelon counts as a liquid!) Enjoy.

For a look at some wild-looking watermelons you can plan to grow next year, check out the Park Seed Garden Journal blog - I bet tomorrow's post will be about . . . watermelon!Â <a href="http://parkseedjournal.com/2008/08/national-waterm.html">http://parkseedjournal.com/2008/08/national-waterm.html</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Just When You Think Youâre in Control  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/07/30/just-when-you-think-youre-in-control/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 30 Jul 2012 15:00:34 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=786</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-6-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-787" title="obstacle-6.aspx" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/thumbnail-6-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="110" /></a>

&nbsp;

Thanks Google Image for photo

Sometimes I see myself walking down a road with the path wide open! Then an obstacle manifests and appears to block my way. Iâm good at talking to obstacles, asking them to move as if theyâre a really fat person at the movie theater blocking my seat. If they donât move, I can either go around, or crawl over them without anyone spilling their popcorn.

But sometimes, in the process of getting beyond the obstacle, as I get close to it,Â  I get mad. I blast it with pent-up emotion, fear, and hidden beliefs. I've even spat rare but dark comments to cancer, âYouâve ruined my quality of life!â âYouâve taken my beauty!â When Iâm done (and rarely before) I catch myself.Â  Then a flash crosses my mind. An image of someone burned. Someone with minimal movement. Someone in constant pain. Iâm immediately transported back to that wide open path, with no obstacles. Perspective is key.

I realize and own my part in co-creating obstacles in my life. Who knows, maybe I signed a contract with an angel before I came to this life experience. Perhaps I said Iâd do this for the lesson, or I was a curious soul, wanting the âexperienceââwho knows. . . Maybe cancer <em>is </em>in the genes. (Skip jeans; wear skirts!) Maybe theyâll discover what we think to be a healthy lifestyle isnât healthy after all. It's a stretch, but if they're now saying chocolate helps with heart disease and cancerâand I was eating fruits and vegetables, it does cross my mind.

Whatever the cause, I had cancer (twice) and we donât move forward by looking in the review mirror. No one is to blame. <em>Attitude</em> is the difference between hating whatâs left, and embracing life.

If youâre hurtingâphysically or emotionally, affirm <em>the cause </em>of whatever is bothering you be dissolved.

<strong>TIP</strong>:Â  If you find yourself in sad thought, looking back, regretting. LOOK UP!Â <em>Physically</em>, look up. Your thoughts will lift. Your mood will lighten. youâll feel hopeful.

<item>
  <title>What's in Your Glass?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/06/811/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 06 Aug 2012 15:00:37 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=811</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-8-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-812" title="Glass of Water" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-8-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="116" height="160" /></a>

Thanks Google Image for photo

Love and hate are choices. You can love your body, or hate cancer. You cannot do both. By hating cancer, youâre attacking your body - and for now, cancer is in your body, finding itâs way out. Support it in leaving your body. Said another way, if we fight for something, we have to fight to keep it. AllowÂ  health. Donât fight for it.

This isnât to take a blind eye or Pollyanna view on cancer, but to remind ourselves itâs all energy. If we pour âbadâ energy (feelings, thoughts, talk, and actions) over ourselves and cancer, weâve added mud to a glass of water. If we pour âgoodâ energy (feelings, thoughts, talk, and actions) over ourselves and cancer, weâve added water to the mudâdiluting it. That doesnât mean our thoughts or words alone will heal us. Life responds to our <em>vibration</em>, not our words; otherwise, we'd see a lot more millionaires and truly loving relationships from all those workshops and seminars teaching affirmations. I'm a fan of affirmations, but I'm saying words alone don't to it.Â The process of water diluting mud can be messy, but once the muddy water rises up and over the top of the glass, thereâs less mud to deal with every time we add fresh water and we progress to further health. It's work to shift your vibration. It's also worth it.Â Ask yourself two questions:
<ul>
	<li>Is your glass half empty, or half full?</li>
	<li>Whatâs in your glass?</li>
</ul>

<item>
  <title>Eat Your Vegetables</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/09/eat-your-vegetables/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 09 Aug 2012 15:00:36 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=816</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-9-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-818" title="cruciferous vegetables" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-9-aspx.jpeg" alt="" width="160" height="116" /></a>

In a society where diets are brownie flavored shakes, âeat your vegetablesâ is boring, and a hard sell. Itâs true, drinking a shake while driving is easier than eating brussels sprouts. But Iâm sure thatâs only part of the equation. Weâve become a society used to sweets and a quick fix. If our energy drags, we grab a protein bar, or a smoothie. The smoothie may have a banana and berries, but doubtful it has broccoli, cauliflower, bok choy or turnips. These are the cruciferous vegetables containing phytochemicals, which seem to have protective effects against some types of cancer.

Cruciferous vegetables look like flowers, and âheadless cruciferousâ are the dark green leafy vegetables, like kale, and collard greens. If you know someone who scratches their headânot out of quandary, but from dry skin, tell them to lay off the red wine, smoking and instead, add dark green leafy vegetables to their diet. Theyâll notice a difference within a few days.

On the cancer front, a Shanghai study with a principal investigator of Shanghai Breast Cancer Survival Study, and a post-doctoral fellow at Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, studied the role of cruciferous vegetables in 4,886 Chinese women with stage 1 to stage 4 breast cancer between 2002 and 2006. In short, the study replicates an earlier study done in U.S. The intake of cruciferous vegetables is much higher among Chinese women than U.S. women. Neither study seems to have definitive results, but both point to a healthy lifestyle making some difference. For further reading about the study:Â  <a href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1945">http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1945</a>

The take-away from this post is not Chinese foodâunless you make it at home with fresh vegetables, go easy on the soy sauce, and share your good fortune with those around you!

<span style="font-size:1em;">Related articles</span>
<ul class="zemanta-article-ul">
	<li class="zemanta-article-ul-li"><a href="http://ladydmakeup.wordpress.com/2012/07/24/2246/" target="_blank">Women's Health: Cruciferous Vegetables Improve Survival in Women With Breast Cancer</a> (ladydmakeup.wordpress.com)</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cancer Rehabilitation  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/13/cancer-rehabilitation/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 13 Aug 2012 15:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=839</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/wecandoit.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-846" title="WeCanDoIt" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/wecandoit.jpeg" alt="" width="181" height="237" /></a>

Thanks to Google for image.

Show us your muscles, Rosie!

My bachelorâs degree in recreation administration with an emphasis in therapeutic recreation led me to become a registered and certified recreation therapist. Iâm a strong advocate of physical rehabilitation. Have you heard of <em>Cancer</em> Rehabilitation? Until recently, I hadnât. Cancer rehabilitation makes sense. It focuses on the quality of life during and after treatment, if needed.

No matter how long itâs been since your treatment ended, if youâre having lingering effects of treatment, you may want to look into cancer rehabilitation. Hereâs a list of conditions to consider: Pain. Fatigue. Deconditioning (a sense you canât do what you used to). Reduced physical strength. Reduced range of motion. Shortness of breath. Lack of balance. Difficulty swallowing. Difficulty chewing. Difficulty opening or closing your mouth. Lymphedema (swelling). Peripheral neuropathy (tingling, burning, or loss of sensation in hands, fingers, feet or toes.)

Colorado seems to be rockinâ and rollinâ with cancer rehabs. Maybe if patients can make a come back exercising in high altitude, they know itâll work anywhere! The links below are great articles re: cancer rehab, specifically in Aurora and Greeley Colorado.
<ul>
	<li><a title="What is Cancer Rehab?" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1935">What is Cancer Rehab?</a></li>
	<li><a title="Benefits of Cancer Rehab" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1953">Benefits of Cancer Rehab</a></li>
	<li><a title="Breast Cancer Rehab" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1962">Breast Cancer Rehab</a></li>
	<li><a title="Insurance Coverage for Cancer Rehab" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1969">Insurance Coverage Â for Cancer Rehab</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Check Your Attitude</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/16/check-your-attitude/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 16 Aug 2012 15:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=851</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/keepsmiling.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-852" title="KeepSmiling" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/keepsmiling.jpg" alt="" width="290" height="258" /></a>

Thanks Google Image for photo

Cancer is rough, but think of this: Can you imagine being stripped, taunted. Your parents, brother and pregnant wife have been killed in labor camps or gas chambers. Your wedding ring torn off your finger and tossed into the fire. And you stand tall, saying, âYou cannot make me hate you.â (<em>Manâs Search for Meaning</em>, Viktor E. Frankl.)Â <a title="Thoughts Viktor Frankl" href="http://www.rjgeib.com/thoughts/frankl/frankl.html">Thoughts Viktor Frankl</a>

Yes, There are really hard days with cancer, and days you could care less about attitude. The day of diagnosisâor re-diagnosis. The week you have not one visitor. But if you can catch yourself in that moment of needing attitude adjustment, youâll be able to turn it around. You are at choice. Itâs okay to give yourself an hour, or even a day of âBLAHHH!!â âThen enough. Time to commit to the greatness you are. Time to hear the call, and shine. This doesnât mean you have to walk 60 miles, or wear pink. It <em>does</em> mean re-gaining consciousness and living the life you chose. (No, you didnât consciously chose cancer, but you have it, so now what are you going to do?) You have two choices: Whine and be miserable to yourself and others, or find wonderful things on which to focus.

Did you know the mind cannot hold two thoughts at the same moment?Â Nope! So, when youâre holding a negative thought, itâs blocking a positive one. When you catch yourself (we all have dark moments, cancer or not.) gently turn it around. When we have a light thought, the dark can't come in. And just as a light match entering a dark room, the dark gives way to light. Even with the tiny bit of match-light, you can find your way in the darkest of rooms. Go to the mirror now and give yourself a smile. It's your match. Share your light.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Dreams + Permission = New Beginnings  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/20/dreams-permission-new-beginnings/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 20 Aug 2012 15:00:18 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=855</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/jean-new-smile1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-858" title="Jean-new-smile" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/jean-new-smile1.jpg?w=133" alt="Jean Campbell" width="133" height="150" /></a></strong>

<strong>Guest Post from Jean Campbell</strong>

A diagnosis of breast cancer was a show stopper for me. All the plans I had for life, the things I still wanted to accomplish, the futureâ¦ all came into question.

The time I spent in treatment for breast cancer was like traveling in a parallel universe. I lived, worked, and tried to meet the usual demands of my personal life while coping with the fears, doubts and physical discomforts that accompany breast cancer treatment. The world seemed surreal. Everyone I knew was getting on with their everyday lives and I was in this holding pattern called treatment with no guarantees of the treatment outcomes or what the future might hold for me.

AÂ few weeksÂ after IÂ completed treatment for my first cancer I joined friends for lunch. The conversation soon turned to earlyÂ retirement plans among those who had governmentÂ jobs. As I listened,Â I couldn't help wondering if planning for retirement was something I had to concern myself about. I was still focusing on getting through the days from one post-treatment follow up appointment to the other. It was easier living in each day, not projecting; getting done whatever I needed and wanted to do was enough for me.

Short-term planning, such as how to get my strength back andÂ  fulfilling personal and business commitments made prior to my diagnosis were all I wasÂ able to manage in the weeks and months that followed treatment. Long term planning didn't enter my mind; yet I knew I had to plan for the future. I began small. I started with goals that could be accomplished within six months (my time between doctor visits). My planning time expanded as the space between doctors visits grew farther apart. Six monthsÂ of planning became a year.

During the 10 years between my cancers, theÂ trick became balancing living in today with planning for the future. Not so easy when good health and years of being cancer-free made me more confident about planning. I began to plan like someone who hadÂ never had a life-threatening illness. When a second primary breast cancer was discovered,Â it was time for a refresher course in living in today, but still planning for the future.

After my first cancer, I gave myself permission to write for a living. I left a secure, full time job in nonprofit management and took a series of part time writing positions: trade paper reporter, grant writer, ghost writer. It was both scary and exhilarating. A few years later, when the chance came to âPay it forwardâ as an in-hospital patient navigator for the American Cancer Society, I took it and kept writing for publication in magazines and online publications.

My second cancer was the impetus for my starting and growing <a href="http://www.noboobsaboutit.org">www.noboobsaboutit.org</a>, and for making a 20-year dream of creating an online life skills learning center for young children a reality (<a href="http://www.candostreet.com">www.candostreet.com</a>).

My post cancer treatment-driven ventures make me feel productive. They make each day one I look forward to and feel good about.

Breast cancer, for me, has been the great teacher ofâ¦ Live it now! Make it happen now!
<p style="text-align:center;"><strong>***</strong></p>
Jean Campbell is a two-time breast cancer survivor and founding director of the American Cancer Society Patient Navigator Program in NYC.

In 2010, Jean founded No Boobs About It (<a href="http://www.noboobsaboutit.org">www.noboobsaboutit.org</a>) to help women and men newly diagnosed with breast cancer to get through treatment and get on with life.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Five Tips: How to Help Someone with Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/23/five-tips-how-to-help-someone-with-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 23 Aug 2012 15:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=862</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-2-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-863" title="5 Things you need to know" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-2-aspx.jpeg?w=150" alt="" width="218" height="218" /></a>

Thanks Google Image for graphic.
<ol>
	<li>If youâre one to easily joke, <em>know your audience</em>. Maybe youâre trying to lighten the situation. It might backfire. Maybe youâre trying to hide your fear. Whatever the reason for your jokes, if theyâre about the affected area, they may not be funny.</li>
	<li>Let the patient know theyâre in your thoughts or prayers. If youâre someone who finds this sort of conversation hard, draw a smily face on a piece of paper, write: âI care about you.â âIâm thinking of you.â Bring the person whoâs going through cancer treatment a shell from the beach,Â  a leaf from a walkâsomething from your contact with the outside world. It doesnât have to cost anything, or be something theyâll keep forever.</li>
	<li>If youâre not the main caretaker, ask that person how <em>theyâre</em> doing. Offer <em>them</em> support. Give <em>them</em> a break. Bring over a dvd movie, a piece of fruit, some cookiesâsomething for the caretaker alone, or that they can share. Give the caretaker a few hours of âme timeâ while you stay with the patient.</li>
	<li>Be specific with your offers of help. âLet me know if you need anythingâ puts the burden of thinking and organizing back into the patientâs lap. What can you do? What are you willing to do? Are you willing to drive, but not wait around? Share that. Want to run errands but not hang around more than ten minutes? Tell them. What ever you say youâll do, follow-through. If for some reason you canât do it, get someone to do it for you.</li>
	<li>When you come to visit, look around. What needs to be done? Does the trash need taking out? Dishes need washing? If you grocery shop, complete the task by putting things away.</li>
</ol>
Friends, families and neighbors are golden! Thanks for helping.

<a title="More tips on how to help." href="http://ow.ly/cVSWk">More tips on how to help.</a>

Here are two down to earth, upbeat blogs addressing breast cancer:
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.facingcancer.ca">http://www.facingcancer.ca</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.noboobsaboutit.org">http://www.noboobsaboutit.org</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The Finish Line</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/27/the-finish-line/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 27 Aug 2012 15:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=867</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-3-aspx.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-868" title="Finish Line" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/thumbnail-3-aspx.jpeg?w=150" alt="" width="210" height="210" /></a>

Thanks to Google Image for photo

Your finish line may look very different for different from that of others you come across. Some women can walk âThe Walkâ a week later. Some (most) canât. Your friends and family will see your hair grow back, or comment on your shapely figure. They may need requests or reminders even six months after the last treatment to help you with some chores.

<strong>If the last phase of your treatment was <em>chemo</em>:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>you may experience neuropathy,(hopefully temporary) debilitating numbness and pain in the fingers, hands and feet. The medication Neurontin, also known as Gabapentin is the same medication used for people coming off long term marijuana use. The medication can have an extra perk: Decreased hot flashes. It can also have an annoying drawback: Dizziness and blurred vision.</li>
</ul>
<strong>If crossing the finish line for you was <em>surgery</em>:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>You might physically look as if nothing out of the norm has happened. Limit your time with people who donât âget it.â You and others may expect to jump back into life; your body may have the plan to slowly but fully recuperate. A key after surgery to feeling good: Hydrationâand fiber. And more hydration. Keep this up for at least a week to get the medications out, and the body back to some normalcy. If you havenât been given mastectomy (or any type) of exercises before leaving the hospital, ask for them. These will reduce or prevent lymphedema, and enhance your ability to regain range of motion.</li>
</ul>
<strong>With <em>radiation as the final treatment</em>:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Like chemo, radiation fatigue is accumulative. Itâll be the heaviest toward the end of treatment. Two-four weeks after completion, youâll probably begin to feel aÂ  bit of energy come back. If youâve had all three treatments, or more than one surgery, revise your expectations. It takes some people a long time to recover. Keep in mind, your body has been through major treatmentâand youâre moving in the right direction.</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>Resources</em></strong>:
<ul>
	<li>Treatmentâs over. <em>Hooray</em>! Now what? You no longer have people stopping by to drive you to the clinic. That need is gone. You may have new needs, though. If you havenât, go visit your clinic resource room. Ask whatâs available for recent post-treatment patients. Is there a yoga class, laugher yoga, or acupuncture? Maybe a great support group if thatâs something youâre interested in.</li>
	<li>Â American Cancer Society can be an on-going resource. 1-800-ACS-2345, (1-800-227-2345) <a href="http://www.cancer.org">www.cancer.org</a>. If you have a specific question or concern, you can even ask them to connect you with a woman whoâs had a similar situation, or choice to make. They won't tell you what to do, but Â they'll be able to tell you their experience to help you through yours.</li>
	<li>The official Lymphology Association of North America (LANA) website <a href="http://www.clt-lana.org">http://www.clt-lana.org</a> has a search list of Certified LANA Therapists. Find a therapist and get measured for compression garments. Youâll need them for repetitive action and air travel.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Here are other websites/posts that address post-treatment issues:Â </strong>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.breastcancer.org">http://www.breastcancer.org</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.curetoday.com">http://www.curetoday.com</a></li>
	<li><a title="Treatment's Over. Now What?" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/06/13/treatment%e2%80%99s-over-now-what/">Treatment's Over. Now What?</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Exercising When Youâre Tired of (and from) Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/08/30/exercising-when-youre-tired-of-and-from-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 30 Aug 2012 15:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=879</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/photo-2_2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-894" title="Photo 2_2" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/photo-2_2.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="177" height="132" /></a>Â Stay-cation with Apple Photo Booth

Here's an excerpt from my guest post "Exercising When Youâre Tired of (and from) Cancer." The post includes some tips and is onÂ Jean Campbell's site:<a title="Exercising" href="http://www.noboobsaboutit.org"> No Boobs About It</a>

Iâm not a fan of pushing beyond what you think is in your best interest. Having said this, know your body. Yes, youâll be tired. Exhausted. But the activity will help you feel <em>better</em>. Physically and emotionally. You may sleep even more after some activityâand youâll feel youâve earned it! you may eat more, too (so now it becomes a matter of being conscious of what youâre eating.) You must decide whatâs in your best interest. Where do you want to be? How will you best build the bridge to get there from where you are now?

To read more, go toÂ <a title="Jean Campbell" href="http://noboobsaboutit.org">Jean Campbell</a>'s site:Â No Boobs About It]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>All in a (cancer) Day's Work</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/03/all-in-a-cancer-days-work/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 03 Sep 2012 15:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=899</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/img_2350.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-900" title="Labor Day" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/img_2350.jpg?w=112" alt="" width="204" height="274" /></a>Photo by Claudia Mulcahy

It's Labor Day. Your job is to do your bestâwhatever that may look like. Sometimes that means resting. Forget the "to do" list. Others will figure out what's for dinner when they realize you're not making it tonight. Maybe today's work is walking a quarter way around the block. Or, if you're a friend of someone who has cancer, maybe today's labor of love is dropping by for either the person with cancer, or someone else needing a "high-five."

If you aren't working today, find a way to express your gratitude for those who are, and for those who made this day what it is. Are you driving to the beach? Who made your car? The road? Who tended the food you'll eat? It can become a game to see how long the list grows.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>Antidepressant Relief From Neuropathy  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/06/antidepressant-relief-from-neuropathy/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 06 Sep 2012 15:00:58 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=902</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts3-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4783554885126842id8bc663219f87a13f1b4b01c522885621.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-903" title="cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts3-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4783554885126842id8bc663219f87a13f1b4b01c522885621.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="112" /></a>

&nbsp;

Photo credit: Google Image

Some patients experience neuropathy as a result of chemo therapy. Their hands and feet are numb, tingle and have a burning sensation. Neuropathy can develop anywhere from weeks to years after treatment. The majority of cases completely resolve. Just as they manifested, the damaged nerves can take weeks to years to heal. It can take longer for the feet on taller people to heal because the feet are the furthest away from nerves on the spine.

Currently, the antidepressant Cymbalta (duloxetime) is approved for treating diabetic peripheral neuropathy. According to a stage three study, Cymbalta has also proven effective in treating chemo therapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN). The drug didnât work for everyone, and the most common side effect was fatigue. For more on this study, Antidepressant Works in Treating Painful Neuropathy: <a href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1940">http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1940Â </a>

Another option for helping deal with CIPN could be Neurontin (gabapentin). It also has some side effects, but with gradual increase of dose, the body adjusts, and the side effects tend to be minor.

<strong>Related Posts:</strong>

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/08/neuropathy/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/08/neuropathy/</a>

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/08/neuropathy/">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2011/12/12/neuropathy-continued/</a>

<item>
  <title>Chocolate Covered Cancer </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/10/chocolate-covered-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 10 Sep 2012 15:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=908</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts4-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4928879384331011ide41cd87fe2f5f3deb9b69f51c4329f87.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-909" title="http-::ts4.mm.bing.net:images:thumbnail.aspx?q=4928879384331011&amp;id=e41cd87fe2f5f3deb9b69f51c4329f87" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts4-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4928879384331011ide41cd87fe2f5f3deb9b69f51c4329f87.jpg?w=114" alt="" width="216" height="284" /></a>Â image credit - Google

Perhaps I havenât eaten enough chocolate in life. As a kid, I liked white chocolateâwhich â<em>They</em>â (whoever â<em>They</em>â are) say isnât chocolate at all. Then, I actually went a few years in my late teens not touching any chocolate at all. It had nothing to do with acne or weight; it was just my way.

I have a confession:

A few weeks ago, I bought a chocolate bar. I broke off a few pieces every day. I didnât share with anyone. There I was eating dark chocolate. Mid-day. Alone.

Iâd just returned from an oncology appointment. After three years, I was told, âYouâre cancer free.â I came home and read âbreaking newsâ about chocolate (here we go againâsoon followed by a study of red wine, Iâm sure). â<em>Chemical compounds in chocolate may protect against cancer.â </em>Iâm thin. I eat well. I enjoy the gym. As I read this article, I saw phrases like: <em>may</em> protect, <em>still</em> under investigation, <em>more</em> research is needed, and these beneficial compounds are <em>also found in</em> green tea, grapes, berries and âah-ha! Red wine. Stunning. Is this were cancer funding goes?

The article in <em><a title="Chocolate, Cure Today" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1950">Cure Today</a>, </em>a magazine I enjoy and respect,Â elaborated on the <em>amazing</em> compounds (catechins and proanthocyanidins) of chocolate and cocoa. I spiraled into an even more analytical mode. Chocolate? Dark chocolate? Cocoa? Arenât those from the cocoa plant?âa <em>drug</em>? And in an obese society weâre hoping science saves us through chocolate calories? Wasnât the last cancer study about sugar, and how we ought to steer clear? Oh, maybe itâs the <em>form</em> of sugarâand in the form of chocolate itâs okay.

I grabbed my wallet and walked to the store. Better get there before the health nuts buy all the chocolate bars! I mean, gotta celebrate, right?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Today is a Good Day  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/13/today-is-a-good-day/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 13 Sep 2012 15:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=913</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/img_5194.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-914" title="Sunrise," src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/img_5194.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="328" height="245" /></a>

<strong>Â </strong>Sunrise. Strata Cumulous Clouds. Photo by Claudia Mulcahy

I love photography. I love to take it, and love seeing the glory of nature through the camera lens of others. The moment I opened my eyes in the morning, I saw gorgeous clouds. I jumped into shorts, a top and flip-flops. I clipped my hair up, and grabbed my camera. Hygiene and beauty can wait thirty minutes.

Later in the day, I received this video of Louie Schwartzberg on <em>Gratitude</em>. It was sent to me a few days before my last cancer related surgery. As I watched it, I decided to view this as my prayer of gratitude. The videoâs about 10 minutes long and worth every one of them. Thanks Mr. Schwartzberg!

No phone. No T.V.. Not much money. By societyâs standards, the guy must have been miserable, right? As he puts it, he had âtime and a sense of wonder.â In the video, Schwartzberg mentions people react to his photography with, <em>Oh. My. God.</em>

He then asks the audience, âHave you ever wondered what that meant?â The <em>Oh</em> means, it caught your attention. It made you present, and mindful. The <em>My</em> means it connects with something deep inside your soul. It creates a gateway from within for something to be heard. <em>God</em> is that personal journey we all want to be on. To be inspired. To feel like weâre connected to a universe that celebrates life.â His current project, <em>Happiness Revealed</em> gives insight to this very idea. Enjoy his photography and the message. Â <a title="Gratitude" href="http://ow.ly/dpEhK">Gratitude</a>.

Is gratitude your mantra? What are you exploring? Are you activating your imagination?

âIf you learn to respond to each day as if it is the very first dayâand the very last day of your life, then you will have spent the day well.âÂ  âFrom the man in the video.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Having Cancer is Like Learning to Swim.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/17/having-cancer-is-like-learning-to-swim/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 17 Sep 2012 15:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=917</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts2-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4761654859204189id9a82a9eafc2b93a48f629ee73dabb41e.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1032" title="Float" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts2-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4761654859204189id9a82a9eafc2b93a48f629ee73dabb41e.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="247" height="163" /></a>Â photo credit: Google Image

When youâre learning to swim, youâll learn a few things real fast.

<strong>Donât fight the water. Lean into it.Â </strong>
<ul>
	<li>If you fight it, youâll certainly drown. To float well, you must relax, even tilt your head back a bit. If you kick aboutâyouâre going down. With cancer I learned early on I had to get ahead of the fear. I had to tell cancer to go back to itâs nothingness. Disclaimer: By saying I got ahead of the fear âearly onâ is not intended to sound like I walked out of the doctorâs office with composure. (Well, actually I <em>did</em> walk out of the office with composure, but as soon as my foot hit the hallway I had the big, loud, messy melt-down!)</li>
</ul>
<strong>Trust no one around you will let you drown.</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Youâll flail your arms, your head will bob up and down, and some days those on whom you rely wonât be available. Even so, Â you will be safe and provided for. I had a neighbor I didnât know knock on my door saying she was going to the store. My medical team listened to me and my list of side effects, then made changes or suggestions accordingly. Support shows up even if it's not from where you expect. Stay open. Don't outline who will help, when and how. Know it's working out to your advantage.</li>
</ul>
<strong>People on the pool deck are cheering you on.</strong>
<ul>
	<li>People you donât know will give you thumbs up, winks, verbal compliments, and physical help. Others you donât know but have seen will start conversations where before they felt no need. Some friends and family show support by gifting, sending cards, or doing acts of service like running errands, cooking, or staying with you during or after chemo and surgeries. People do want you to succeed. They are rooting for you!</li>
</ul>
<strong>There's an ice cream bar waiting for you when you get out of the pool</strong>.
<ul>
	<li>Itâs okay to use âwater wingsâ (anything to help you through the cancer experience.) Listen to your swim instructors (medical team, and spiritual inspirations.) Youâre all suiting up, but <em>youâre</em> the one in the water. Metaphysically, water symbolizes consciousness. When I was first diagnosed, I had a scene appear to me during meditation. I was swimming across a river. Half way across, the water got extremely rough, tossing me about. During this meditation I felt, and on an energetic level heard Â the words, <em>Trust. Float.</em> Not much later another image came during meditation. Again, I was in the water floating, leaning my head back into large white wings, as if they were my swimming instructorâs hands. (Remember how well you leaned your head back into your swim instructor's hands? Trusting? Floating?) What better instructor to trust than big white wings? The part I find most amazing is that for most my life, swimming was not enjoyable, and was a source of fear for me, not comfort. Here I was, pulling strength and peace from water images.</li>
</ul>
<em>Trust. Float.</em> ItÂ became my mantra. Half way through chemo, I realized the meditation from weeks previous was spot-on. I knew Iâd get to the other side of this storm if I continued, without wavering. <em>Trust. Float. Trust. Float.</em>Â  Ultimately, I made it to the other side. So will you.

What helps you get across the stormy waters?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Choose your helpers wisely</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/20/choose-your-helpers-wisely/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 20 Sep 2012 15:00:32 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1036</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts1-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq5063938932802204id63dbe41eadf6da7712e1f45e9a3241f3.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1038" title="it's your choice" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts1-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq5063938932802204id63dbe41eadf6da7712e1f45e9a3241f3.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="201" height="121" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Not only are we known by the company we keep, we <em>become</em> the company we keep! Be careful. Be conscious. Make sure that you surround yourself with people who believe in you and your dreams, and who want to work to make <em>their</em> dreams come true as well. Otherwise, you become their focusâperhaps their project. Everyone needs encouragement, not <em>fixinâ.</em>

The emphasis is on benefit. I got some flack when I turned some "help" offers down during cancer. I needed help, but also knew some individuals were not beneficial to me. They wanted an ear, counseling, a conversation, or to âhang out.â I wasnât doing any of it. Iâm sure a few just wanted to get a peek at what cancer looked like.

I actually had a very strange experience when Iâd gone to get the final stubs of my hair shaved off. I was at my momâs stylist. A woman from the community my mom knew was there before us, leaving. The woman gave me a look that said, <em>I see your head scarf, which would mean you are bald, so what was I doing at a hair stylist?</em> I was the last client of the day to avoid anyone from straining their necks to watch. The woman left. About ten minutes later she came back in. Nosed around, <em>looking</em> for us (we'd moved) and popped her head in the partition! Wow! These are some of the types who offered to spend time with me. Iâm just suggesting you choose wisely. Yeah, itâs not really a big deal. But, itâs none of their business, and I work to keep my home filled with good energy.

So, what to do?

Surround yourself with like-minded, positive, people who want to help you, <em>and</em> who are of benefit to you. Some saw my motive as rude, being picky who helped me. I saw it as protecting my energy, privacy and sanity from those I knew could not meet me at the level I needed. I believe it was in everyoneâs best interest for me to say, âNo thank youâ to those offers, rather than a mutual using of each other; no one truly getting what they wanted, anyway.

Learn to make a stand. It doesnât have to be a loud, direct hit to someone, but could be a simple re-direct. With cancer, people are constantly asking, âHow do you feel?â I had a friend with cancer whoâs husband would ask her that question every single morning. She asked him to stop because sheâd begin every morning comparing herself to feeling better or worse rather than allowing the day to unfold without jumping into <em>scan mode</em>. She asked him to âreadâ her, and allow her to bring up the issue if needed. She rarely did.

By setting boundaries, you honor everyone. People like to know what to do. People want to help you. Let them know. Give them feedback when they really help you, too.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Gummy Bear Implants</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/24/gummy-bear-implants/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 24 Sep 2012 15:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1048</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/gummy-breast-implant1.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1050" title="Gummy Breast Implant" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/gummy-breast-implant1.jpeg?w=150" alt="" width="215" height="215" /></a>Image credit: Google

Iâve never been sure how to use the calendar with cancer. âThe journeyâ could begin with the firstÂ  visit, âHmmm. This looks suspicious.â Or the return visit, âYou have cancer.â Or when it sinks in at the second opinion appointment, âYou have stage three cancer.â

The calendar is just as blurry for marking an end to the journey, especially if thereâs been recurrence. Some say, <em>Done</em> more than once. I have. This time my <em>Done!</em> includes a new FDA approved, âGummy Bearâ implant. The name is Sientra, but itâs been dubbed âGummy Bearâ because it feels like that chewy cutie. (On the outside, anyway.)

My previous implant kept slipping. I had a revision, and within a month it slipped again. Even with my following all the rules and suggestions, like wearing a bra 24/7 for a month, the implant rolled and inched toward my axilla (armpit.) Wearing the bra was excruciating, hitting scar tissue, and fresh sutures. Iâm pretty sure the symbolic idea of bra burning in the 60âs was the brainchild of post-mastectomy/implant recipients!

Iâve got the new implants now. They're textured for the muscle to grip the roughness, to help prevent slip and slide. Immediately, there are some aspects I donât like (they feel heavy!) Part of that may be due to my being thin. Throughout the cancer journey, my complaints have been answered with, âWe hear that from thin women.â Since I remember the adjustment period of the other implants, itâs still too soon to say much about my new trophies.

What are your "Begin" or "Done" moments of cancer?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>It Starts With a Feeling</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/27/it-starts-with-a-feeling/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 27 Sep 2012 15:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1054</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-www-canadatop-comuploadsgarden_488.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1056" title="http-::www.canadatop.com:uploads:garden_488" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-www-canadatop-comuploadsgarden_488.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="173" height="129" /></a>Â image credit: Google

If weâre not consciously tending to our garden of feelings and thoughts, weâre subconsciously allowing weeds to take over.

Are you happy? (Yes, you can still be happy in the midst of cancer.) If not, what would feeling happy feel like if it were in your experience right now? Feel the <em>happy</em>, not the not-happy for not having xyz here and now. Do you remember the commercial, âCalgon take me away!â? The scene switched from busy day and loud kids to the woman sitting in her bathtub, where she was âoff in some tropical paradise.â Same for you! Donât focus on wishing the kids werenât screaming. Focus on âbeing in paradise.â Whatâs that <em>feel</em> like?

When I was first learning this type thinking on a deep level, Iâd notice at conferences others had an almost supernatural high energy. Theyâd say theyâd never felt better, and were so sad to leave the conference. I enjoyed the events, but never hit the high they did. I brought this to the attention of my spiritual director. She told me, these people were going to conferences for the energy and feeling, not necessarily to <em>live</em> the lessons taught. When these people left the conference they went home and energetically crashed, not having hundreds, or thousands of others whoâve done the work to skim from. By doing your work, youâll know your feelings. Youâd be amazed how many donât know their true feelings. From feelings come thoughts; from thoughts come beliefs; from beliefs come actions.

By being in the present, we stay in power of our experience at all times. Yes. Got cancer. No. Not happy about it. Yes. Can be happy anyway. This doesnât mean cartwheels, clown acts, and brushing over the feeling of loss, angerâor whatever. Nor does it mean youâre happy for cancer, but that you <em>can</em> find happiness. It means you choose not to give your power to the outer circumstance (in this case, cancer.)

I invite you to get serious about monitoring your feelings, thoughts and self-talk. Tap into your feelings without kidding yourself. âOh itâs all fine.â Maybe it is. Maybe it isnât. I dare say, if youâre in this boat, something has been lurking knownâor unknown to you beneath the surface. I donât believe we <em>always</em> need to know the cause of the situation, but if weâre willing to ask ourselves, a higher power for good, etc. weâll know the cause if itâs needed for us to heal the cause of a situation. Otherwise, we can still heal without knowing the cause.

When youâre monitoring your feelings, ask yourself, âDoes this feeling bring me close, or pull me away from what I want to experience?â If the answer is <em>pulls me away</em>, immediately draw your attention to <em>where you want to be</em>. It isnât about a <em>fake itâtil you make it</em>. Itâs about being real with where you are at any given moment, and making the commitment to do the best you can to get where you say you want to be. If you feel lousy, do what you need to do to help yourself feel better. Saying, âAll is wellâ may be True on a spiritual level, but if you feel otherwise and need anti-nausea medication, itâs not the best time to practice a belief you canât buy into. On the other hand, affirming âI feel lousyâ is no help either. You can feel lousy <em>and</em> find something good on which to focus. (Even if itâs âHooray, I have anti-nausea medication!â) By doing this, youâre admitting where you are on a vibrational level, and doing what you can to honestly move forward.

Quick! Run! Get a vase for the flower-thoughts! They are <em>beautiful</em>!

<item>
  <title>Whatâs Truly Important to You?  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/01/whats-truly-important-to-you/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 01 Oct 2012 15:00:59 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1059</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts2-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4690981186306441idd3cdd3415b61b626cfe93919f5dd00a4.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1062" title="nap" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/http-ts2-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4690981186306441idd3cdd3415b61b626cfe93919f5dd00a4.jpg?w=150" alt="" width="244" height="187" /></a>Â Image credit: Google

It doesn't take having cancer to be tired, but having cancer will seal the deal in becoming tired. Â Maybe you're at the point in treatment or recovery where you're tired of being tired, and are pushing to do more. It's time to ask, whatâs <em>truly</em> important in your life? If everythingâs a priority, then nothingâs a priority. Donât allow the small stuff to throw you off course. And donât worry about the big stuff, because thereâs a 50/50 chance. It willâor wonât happen.

If youâre overwhelmed, write down your <em>To-Do</em> list. Itâll keep you focused, and you may feel a surge of success when checking off the completed chore. Or, at very least, a wave of peace. Plan on getting 1-5 of the chores done on your list a dayânot 25 of them. If you write down 25 things, just know the list will roll over for about a week.

Keeping a list helps when memory is challenged with medications and chemo fog. A list can also help people who come over wanting to help you. Theyâll see: trash out, send birthday card, make dinner, buy yogurt, pay bills. They can take out the trash, go get the yogurt, or stamps for sending the birthday card or bills. Maybe they can take you to the store and help you shop.

I remember mopping my small kitchen floor for the first time after chemo. I went to ring-out the mop and didnât have any strength to push the metal lever against the sponge. I used my knees to squeeze the lever as tight as I could, realizing the floor was going to look more like a flood occurred than anyone having mopped. That was the <em>only</em> thing I did that day, but it got done. I cried in shock for how weak I was, and laughed as I trudged off to bed, leaving a swamp behind me to dry on its own.

Bottom line. Itâs your time to heal. Worry doesnât heal. Being overwhelmed doesnât heal. Regret or resentment add to what needs healing. Focus on the important stuff. Itâs seldom getting todayâs mail, or having vacuum lines on the carpet for guests. If itâs important to you, donât complain about it. If itâs not important to you, itâll wait. Even pre-cancer, I had affirmations, quotes and uplifting reminders around my place. One Iâd anchor into during treatment is a quote from Lou Holtz, Notre Dame football coach. Heâd ask his players, âWhatâs important now?â (W-I-N). Sometimes, W-I-N means getting up and eating a few spoonfuls of food, orÂ takingÂ in liquid because itâs on the hour, not because you want to.

whatâsÂ <em>truly</em>Â important in your life?]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Change </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/04/change/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 04 Oct 2012 15:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1064</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/dandelion.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1065" title="dandelion" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/09/dandelion.jpeg?w=150" alt="" width="196" height="129" /></a>Â Image Credit: Google

A man goes to buy a hot dog. He gives the vendor $10.00 and gets his hot dog. Then stands there, waiting for his change. The vendor moves on to the next customer. The man speaks up, âHey! I gave you $10.00. Iâm waiting for my change.â Surprised, the vendor turns to the man, âChange? Change comes from <em>within</em>.â

Some say people donât like change. Put your hand on a hot oven burner. When the pain outweighs the pleasure, youâll welcome change.

What isnât working for you in your life? How would you like it to look? What are you willing to do in order to have that (experience, relationship, health, item. . .) Sometimes itâs as simple as stating it out loud, and hearing the words and intention come out of our mouth with conviction. Other times, we realize when we go to state it out loud, that we <em>thought</em> we knew what we wanted, but we canât formulate it into words (meaning we really donât know what we want, and thereâs work to do.)

Itâs not magic dust. This is the foundation of working with your subconscious mind. The subconscious mind works 24/7. If you fall asleep in front of the late night news and television ads, your subconscious mind is taking them in. (Not that youâll wake up destined to buy a set of Gensu knives for $19.99), but youâll have slept more soundly without the negative-spin news, and bombarding of messages that you <em>need</em> this because . . . . Turn the TV off and focus upon what IS working in your life before falling asleep.

If you make this a habit, you'll be grateful for the change you do receive back.

<item>
  <title>Attitude of Gratitude</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/08/attitude-of-gratitude/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 08 Oct 2012 15:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1068</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts3-mm-bing-netthidi-4714298593446594pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1069" title="attitude" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts3-mm-bing-netthidi-4714298593446594pid15-1.jpg" alt="" width="340" height="136" /></a>

image credit: Google

Attitude of Gratitude. There's lots of talk about it. But how do you do it if it's new to you, or when you feel low?

Keep a list or journal. Make a daily (or hourly) habit of gratitude. If itâs new to you, put it on your âTo-Doâ list. Otherwise, youâll (subconsciously) find ways to keep you busy with familiar, âsafeâ things. This may be a challenge at first. Do it anyway. Donât block anything from the list. Being thankful for clean, safe drinking water, and indoor plumbing is just as valid as being thankful for the neighbor who checks in on you, or food, or life. No judgment when doing this list. Some say they are grateful for cancer. Some are grateful for all the good that came out of itâthe help, the health, and lessons learned.

If you know you wonât get up and get the journal if youâre not feeling well to read or write, put it somewhere with easy access. If youâre a television watcher, put it on the t.v. screen when the t.v.âs not on. Iâve shared this before, I had my âwall of gratitudeâ on the living room wall. I'd lie on the couch and read the wallâand always feel better after doing so. (I'd also think of more things to add to the list.) Where do you hang out? Whatâs the easiest for you?Â Set yourself up for success. I knew I'd never get up and go get a journal to read, or write in on days I didn't feel well. I knew my list had to be up and "in my face" for me to use it daily. I knew that, and it worked for me.

Add to the list daily. There were a few daysânot many, but a fewâ where I sat down and told myself I wasn't allowed to move until I added at least one thing to my gratitude list. (I also had a "rule" that I wasn't allowed to write the same thing twice. If I wrote something like, "Mary for driving me to chemo" I couldn't write it again when she drove me again.) One particular dark day, I had a real tough time coming up with any one thing to add to my list. Then, I shifted my thinking from me to others. Several things came to my mind. It made me laugh, and I got to add one more thing to my list, "my awareness of people/things/events for which to be grateful." Yes. When it's dark enough, you can see the stars.

One last thing. Remember, youâre not always a treat to be aroundâcancer or not. It takes no effort to say, âThank youâ to your family, friend, grocery store worker, stranger, Higher Power, dog or cat. Even if youâre exhausted beyond words, a nod, slight smile gets the message across. You may not wake up grateful for life everyday, but you can thank those in it for making your life that much more enjoyable.

âAnd with an attitude of gratitude, t<em>hanks</em> for reading this blog!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Anger</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/11/anger/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 11 Oct 2012 15:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1072</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-5024201897871049pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1073" title="mood" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-5024201897871049pid15-1.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Cancer. Anger. Anxiety. Depression.

Ask your medical team if the cancer treatment you receive can trigger emotional change. Some medications have side effects of possible depression, anger or anxiety. Itâs much easier to deal with these new emotions when you know where itâs coming from. In addition to medication, anger can arise from the process of menopause. Youâre not crazy. Youâre not a horrible person. Your body is used to a certain amount of estrogen and progesterone, and now thatâs gone. Itâs a triple-quadruple whammy: Chemo, surgeries, medication, menopause. (Itâs enough to make you scream, isnât it?)

Some say anger helps them through cancer. Iâve met some very angry people. Their anger may help <em>them</em>, but that doesnât mean<em> I </em>need to be their target or audience for inappropriate dealings of their anger. Iâm all for tying to understand frustration, and supporting others when we can. This coin has two sides: People encouraging each other. People practicing the life they want.

Having said this, when someoneâs depressed, they cannot just turn on the switch to joy. It takes time and effort on everyoneâs part. When I was diagnosed with cancer, in factâwith every change and every surgery (6) I found myself at the bottom of the emotional ladder. (Even if it was a new level, I'd be at the lowest rung of that level.) Iâve been a New Thought minister and know the ropes around positive thinking. But, some days I had to allow others to lift me, knowing I was being dark and miserableâand knowing at some level, someday Iâd return to âme.â My mantra was often, âTrust. Float.â (We donât float in water by fighting it. We float by relaxing into it.)

As I often point out, this isnât about stuffing or internalizing emotions. If youâre angry, go aheadâswear at cancer, punch a pillow, cry, shake your fist at God. Do what feels good. <strong>Then</strong>, move out of anger. It will not serve you to <em>stay</em> there. But, if youâre angry, fearful or sad and you ignore it, youâre asking for trouble. Be present. Know how you feel. Only then can you make a shift to a better feeling. Even just by saying, âI want to feel better.â Itâs like an alert to your body that youâre ready to shift gears. After making that announcement, you can continue with a list of (start with five) things for which youâre grateful. I covered my walls with shelf paper and used felt tips pens for my âWall of Gratitude.â I knew I wouldnât seek out a journal to read or write when I felt awful. This way it was in my constant view, and Iâd get lost in it, reading and thinking, <em>Yes! I really am grateful for that!</em>

Lean into friends, family, neighbors, support groups, medical team, and counselors. Notice the support around you. I received incredible support from grocery store cashiers, and the general public. Not long after completing chemo, I was at Costco one night in December, buying one box of smoked salmon. That's it. Nothing else. A woman in the line next to me pointed at me, and loud enough to cross the checkout lanes said, âYOU ROCK!â At first I smiled, âThank you.â She said it again with emphasis. I teared up. She understood the absurdity. Costco. Night shopping. Christmas time. <em>One</em> item.

Cancer is often accompanied with feelings of isolation and loneliness, intensifying with anger. You may storm in and out anger during the few years of cancer treatment. It may continue after treatment is over. Many patients focus on getting back to âthe way it was before.â It may happen, and if not, maybe the change in the long run will be spectacular. As you get fresh air, good sleep, exercise, and healthy food, youâre raising the bar for the new norm. If you need to, get angry. But direct it appropriately, and move on.

<strong>Related Resources:</strong>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.cancer.org/index">http://www.cancer.org/index</a></li>
</ul>
1-800-227-2345 English, Spanish, Asian and Pacific Languages. They also have a chat line.

	<li><a href="http://www.cancer.gov/global/contact">http://www.cancer.gov/global/contact</a></li>
</ul>
1-800-4-cancer 1-800-422-6237Â  English, Spanish. They also have a chat line.]]></content:encoded>
