    <wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Kathy Ellis]]></wp:comment_author>
    <wp:comment_author_email>kathy730@hotmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
    <wp:comment_author_url/>
    <wp:comment_author_IP>166.205.68.47</wp:comment_author_IP>
    <wp:comment_date>2013-01-16 18:44:32</wp:comment_date>
    <wp:comment_date_gmt>2013-01-17 02:44:32</wp:comment_date_gmt>
    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Great advice, just when I'm needing it. Can I dump just a moment? Six years ago dx with brain tumor, had surgery, couldn't get all, about 85 percent, 21 months of chemo, no change in MRI's. Went back to work, life was going on, controlled by seizures, doctor appts, fatigue and so on. Then this past June the seizures stepped it up a few notches. May's MRI had been stable, so they didn't go to the tumor angle first. In October went in for a 5 day EEG, MRI showed progression.
Can't say I was surprised. Too many signs from before the 1st dx. This time, inoperable, can't have radiation. Treatment is very limited. We haven't began yet. 
We are treating symptoms and watching to see how quickly it is growing. 
But back to your post, I managed the 1st round with little to no depression, pity parties. This time is becoming tougher. My support group is "distant". Have to admit I am pulling away.
I am glad to have found your blog....need to start one myself, maybe it would help others as well.
Thank you for time.
Kathy]]></wp:comment_content>

    <wp:comment_id>624</wp:comment_id>
    <wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Claudia]]></wp:comment_author>
    <wp:comment_author_email>claudia@cancerwhattodoorsay.com</wp:comment_author_email>
    <wp:comment_author_url>http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com</wp:comment_author_url>
    <wp:comment_author_IP>99.11.20.228</wp:comment_author_IP>
    <wp:comment_date>2013-01-25 09:50:52</wp:comment_date>
    <wp:comment_date_gmt>2013-01-25 17:50:52</wp:comment_date_gmt>
    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hi Kathy,

Thanks for taking the time to leave a comment on my blog, and good for you for considering starting your own blog! I'm sorry to hear you're going through this. I hope you continue to come back to this blog and find it a safe, comforting place, and maybe one you can even share with your support group to help them help you. Funny - Even people with cancer don't know what to do or say when they find someone else's situation has changed. I'm sure they are scared, and confused, not knowing what to say to you, if they're not stage four. "What can I do for you?" "I wish I knew what to say. I'm so shocked, sad right now." Instead, they go into analytical mode, and do and say nothing.

Allow those close to you, and those who can support you, to come in closer. For them, if not for you, allow yourself to focus on the joy of your relationship. This isn't to be Pollyanna, but to not waste time on worry and disappointment. It's to focus on your breath. A cloud. A bird chirping. May I suggest one more thing: I notice your wording "I can't say I was surprised [for tumor progression]" "and .."watching to see how quickly it is growing." Look at the other side of the coin. The second time, my tumor was also monitored. Not focusing on it's growth, but would it continue to grow? Would it stay the same? Would it shrink? When people would ask me why, I'd tell them we're waiting for the tumors shrink. I see it as a mindset, with doctors standing by to celebrate. - No, it doesn't mean it will shrink for everyone, but by expecting it to grow, and watching for tumors to grow, the seed is planted for growth.

Be kind to yourself. Be gentle.
Peace.]]></wp:comment_content>

<item>
  <title>Clinical Trials</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/15/1076/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 15 Oct 2012 15:00:39 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1076</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-4828183934927153pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1077" title="Clinical Trials" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-4828183934927153pid15-1.jpg" height="160" width="145" /></a>Â image credit: Google

If youâre interested in taking part in clinical trials, you may need to be the one who speaks up first. Donât wait for an invitation, let your interest and desires be known. Just because your doctor doesnât mention or know of a study, doesnât mean itâs not out there. <i>The</i> <i>Journal of Oncology Practice</i> published a 2011 survey: 44% of 213 trial-eligible cancer patients didnât recall discussing trials with their doctor. There may, or may not be a clinical trial going, and it may or may not be the right fit for you.You wonât know until you ask.

Itâs not just a matter of finding a trial, you need to know what that entails for you. According to The National Cancer Institute and The American Cancer Society, here are some questions you may want to ask before you jump into risks and benefits of a trial. They are taken from the website below:

Why does the research team think the experimental treatment will work?

Who has reviewed and approved the trial?

Who is sponsoring and funding the trial?

Will some of the trial participants receive a placebo rather than active treatment?

What are the treatments, scans and other procedures participants can expect to undergo? Which ones are experimentalÂ  (specific to the trial) and which are normal care?

What are the short-term and long-term benefits and risks to the treatment?

Who will supervise the participantâs therapy?

What expenses, if any, will the insurance provider or the participant have to pay?

Where is the study site, and how often will participants have to visit it?

How long will the study last?

How will the study affect the participant's daily life?

There should be a phone number listed with the clinical trial summary. Call and ask to speak to the research team directly. Theyâll able to tell you if you meet the study criteria.

For the related article to the above questions:<a title="CureToday" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1936"> CureToday </a><a href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1936">
</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Will Power has nothing to do with mental healing</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/18/will-power-has-nothing-to-do-with-mental-healing/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 18 Oct 2012 15:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1081</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/pict0105.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1082" title="photo by Claudia Mulcahy" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/pict0105.jpg" height="438" width="584" /></a>

photo credit: Claudia Mulcahy

&nbsp;

It is our conviction, not our concentration that directs the Law of Nature. We donât force anything, we don't have to beg, either. We allow Creative Mind to work and demonstrate through, and for us.

If something tough (cancer or otherwise) comes up for you, maybe that situation came into your life to be healed. Or, some other life lesson comes from it. It's no one else's business but your own, although many will tell you metaphysically tell you why you got cancer. Life is 100% FOR you! God (whatever that may be to you) is here right now and always working at 100% optimization. This is <em>your</em> personal project. The Essence of Life WANTS you to heal; to be in balance. Your part is to say, âYES! I AM READY. I am going to allow the Universe to work in, around, through and for me. The Universe brought me right up to the door. I'm knocking. YES! Â I am open and receptive to all my good! I let go of my false beliefs and begin to celebrate now!â

Let go like youâre letting go of a balloon. Itâs easy. Itâs done. Itâs your conviction, <em>not</em> your concentration. Spirit does the heavy lifting. We only need to allow the work to be done. Repeat this process as often as necessary, but don't force Â it, and make it rote. Conviction for health should be fun! Make it light. Be the child letting go of the balloon. Let your heart be light. If you need to go dark for a while - do it. THEN COME BACK!!! Healing happens in the light. The light always overtakes darkness. (But you have to allow the crack of light in. It'll expand. It'll push the dark into dawn. Then focus on your heartbeat, a bird's song, and allow the day to unfold into glorious moments.

However it resonates with you: Let go; let God. Let it be. Thank you. Om. Aum. And so it is. Amen. Shalom. Praise Allah. Peace.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cells get happy!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/22/cells-get-happy/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 22 Oct 2012 15:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1084</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[This is an amazing Ted video with Edith Widder: The weird, wonderful world of bioluminescence.

While this video isn't about cancer, it reminded me of a meditation I'd do during cancer treatment. I'd envision cells in my body moving around as if they were happy individuals at a party. They were colorful, and had smiles. Some would laugh and zoom around. They'd multiply, replacing the "party pooper" cells that would fade away into nothingness.

Enjoy the stunning activity of deep sea and try a "happy cell" meditation.

http://www.ted.com/talks/edith_widder_the_weird_and_wonderful_world_of_bioluminescence.html

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>How did cancer effect your career?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/29/how-did-cancer-effect-your-career/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 29 Oct 2012 15:00:37 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1089</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/norway-ukraine-06-226.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1092" title="cancer and careers" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/norway-ukraine-06-226.jpg" height="438" width="584" /></a>

Image credit: Claudia Mulcahy

780,000 of us return to work after cancer treatment each year. What is/was your experience?

My first back to work experience was five months after I ended chemo. I gave a three-hour workshop. I knocked it out of the park for the first hour and gradually slid from there. I vividly remember watching the clock for the last 45 minutes. Countdown: fifteen minutes. Fourteen. Thirteen. . . Chin over the bar! âThank you for attending. Good byeâ âimmediately shooing out attendees, racing to my car, and petal to the metal home where I dove onto the couch for a nap.

Two years since that workshop Iâve inched upward on the employment ladder. However, with each increase in hours, I feel I slide down two rungs. Rather than three hours workshops, I currently teach or present in one or two-hour sessions either not covering as much, or holding a second session. I still sit during some of the lecture, and still come home exhausted.

I have more than one job. None of them are consistent in hours or schedule. For me, this has been more helpful than not. I may teach a two-hour class for seven weeks (if enough students sign up) otherwise the class is canceled until the following semester, when itâs offered again. At best, I do this three nights per week, but usually itâs one or two.

Then thereâs daytime employment. The morning after evening classes is grim. I did land a three-hour gig smack in the middle of the day. I began as a substitute teacherâs aide in special education, but seldom did more than three days a week, as Iâd come home on day two coughing, and feeling sick. The immune system is lower after cancer. It just wears down faster, and repairs slower.

Recently, I came home from subbing and had an invitation to interview for a âpermanent part timeâ position as a teacherâs aide. I decided to go. I was the last and sixteenth interview of the day. As I left, one of the panelists said, âThank you for your energy.â I stopped in my tracks, stunned at what I heard. Thatâs a phrase <i>I</i> use. I knew I had the job and now wondered if I had what it took to work everyday, Monday through Friday, even if only for three hours a day. I did get the job. I do worry about my endurance, and health, and still feel pulls and minor pains from my final reconstruction surgery two months ago.

It looks like Iâll begin in a few weeks. With any of this, the paychecks havenât been at pre-cancer levels, but if I focus on my progress and nothing else, Iâm hopeful.

[vimeo http://vimeo.com/33552347]
<ul>
	<li><a title="cancer and careers" href="http://community.breastcancer.org/blog/recommended-resource-cancer-and-careers">Cancer and Careers</a></li>
	<li><a title="Looking for work after cancer" href="http://www.cancerandcareers.org/en/looking-for-work">Looking for work after cancer</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Believing is Seeing </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/10/25/believing-is-seeing/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 25 Oct 2012 15:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1095</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4722304426836889pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1096" title="Believing is Seeing" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4722304426836889pid15-1.jpg" height="108" width="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Yes. <em>Believing</em> is seeing. The wind blows, but you cannot see it. You see <i>evidence</i> of it by the leaves on the trees moving. You feel the cool air on your skin. You may even hear rustling noisesâbut you donât <i>see</i> it. âIâll believe it when I see it.â No! Youâll see it when you believe it!

You donât see the wind, does that mean the wind doesnât exist? It can blow buildingsÂ  down, and it can supply energy for cities. Wind power can be a sailorâs dream, or deadly nightmare.

What could you see in your life if you believed in it? I believe we are channels for the Universal Power at all times. Itâs impersonal, but <i>we</i> personalize It.

I think this story is about Edwene Gaines, but weâve all had something similar. As the story goes, she identified with prosperity and abundance when she had almond-stuffed green olives. They were expensive, and it was a rare treat to have them. Opulence!

A friend invited her on a cruise, already paid for. At the time this was a big, extravagant event for her. She went and set the intention to feel the energy of abundance. To take in the wealth, and <i>feel</i> rich!

One night at dinner, her plateânot the plate of anyone elseâs at her table, but <i>her</i> plate had an almond-stuffed green olive on top of her meal. To her, this was the pinnacle of feeling the abundance all around her. Not only around her, but <i>for</i> her. For <i>her</i>!

How in tune are we with abundance? We say we want it, but do we think, talk and act like it, or do we wish, hope, and bemoan what isnât in our hand right now. If thereâs a feeling of not having, itâs a feeling of lack, and that pushes what you want further away. Think of it this way: when you daydream of living a certain life, you catch yourself smiling, and feeling great. When you wish, or look back with regrets, you catch yourself frowning and feeling sad. Both activities are directing the universe. Which scenario do you want the Universe to answer? It will answer the stronger lead.

The same is true with health. We say we want health. Do we talk health? Do we live healthy thoughts, and actions? Not just not smoking, not eating fatty foods, but what do we do in the affirmative to live health, not just avoid non-health? To me, itâs not about fighting cancer, itâs about embracing health on all levelsâ mental, emotional, financial, social, physical and spiritual.

Believing is seeing.

<a href="http://www.edwenegainesseminars.com">http://www.edwenegainesseminars.com</a>

<a href="http://www.drwaynedyer.com">http://www.drwaynedyer.com</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Mental Health for Oncology Patients</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/01/mental-health-for-oncology-patients/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 01 Nov 2012 15:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1098</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4786539935302969pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1100" title="mental health for oncology patients" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4786539935302969pid15-1.jpg" height="300" width="252" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Itâs normal to have a strong emotional response to a serious diagnosis. The first step in good mental health for oncology patients is to know that strong emotions are part of the grieving process and itâs common for patients, and those close to them to have very strong emotions, and shifts from stage to stageâand back again. Denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance are the five stages of grief. (Taken from The Grief Cycle model first published in<em>Â On Death &amp; Dying</em>, Elisabeth KÃ¼bler-Ross, 1969.) The stages are all natural to experience, and will vary in degree from person to person.Â Â These strong emotions surface at different times during the cancer experience, and can surface from the patient, and those taking close care of them, too.

Tell your doctor if worry interferes with your life. There are several options: counseling and medication to name the most common. Also, organizations like American Cancer Society and National Cancer Institute have phone lines open 24 hours a day to help you in English, or Spanish.
<ul>
	<li>ACS: 1-800-227-2345</li>
	<li>NCI: 1-800-4-CANCER, or 1-800-422-6237</li>
</ul>
Some people prefer to talk about their situation. There are support groups, one-to-one counseling, and those close to you with whom you may find support. Others find journaling helpful, and some prefer visiting websites, on-line chat groups, message boards and blogs. Here are some reputable cancer related sites: <a href="http://www.caring">www.caring4cancer.com;</a> <a href="http://www.caring">www.breastcancer.org;</a> Â <a href="http://www.caring">www.cancer.gov; www.cancer.org.</a>Â Whatever site you visit, donât take any information as absolute truth. Situations are individual. What may work for one person, may not work for another. I strongly suggest to get your medical information from your medical team. Surfing random websites will create fear, and some wild, incorrect information. Don't buy into scary stories. Focus on all the good that can happen from your treatment, not the "Well, I heard. . ." stories. Mental health for oncology patients is curtail Â for a complete healing. Take a stand on who you'll allow share your space, your journey, your future.

&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>From Reconstruction to Braces</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/05/from-reconstruction-to-braces/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 05 Nov 2012 16:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1106</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4924623124432799pid15-1.jpg"><img title="reconstruction to braces" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4924623124432799pid15-1.jpg" height="136" width="160" /></a>

One month after my having plastic surgery (a revision of a revision for my breast implants) I noticed my retainer for my teeth didnât fit. Still in my âafter surgery braâ I decided to get partial braces to straighten my lower teeth that had shifted. My teeth hadnât shifted that much, but enough for me to know I didnât want to pay for a retainer to hold them in crooked alignment.Â  The process will be four to six months. After three years of cancer treatment, this seems like a snap.

Iâd met the orthodontist a few days before my braces went on, when I did an unannounced drop by visit to check out the office and staff. I trusted not only this new crew, but my new dentist, whom Iâve seen only twiceâduring my cleanings. Theyâre all delightful, skilled and less expensive than what Iâd grown used to. Jack pot!

Brace yourself: Before my mouth filled with appliances effecting my communication, I told the staff I understood sometimes they needed to lean into a patient to get at the angle they needed. Following that with a big, â<i>But</i>. . . I recently had reconstruction surgery. If bumping or leaning on my chest can be avoided, Iâd <i>really</i> appreciate it!â They were thrilled Iâd given them a heads-up, and never even came close to bumping me.

A young teenager and I shared the spacious four-chair room with a great outdoor view. She was also getting braces. I looked over at the teen and told the dental assistant, âSome women get plastic surgery to feel younger. I get braces.â I get them tightened this coming week, and may even go for glow-in-the-dark bands! Movies anyone?

&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>Cooked versus Raw Veggies  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/08/cooked-versus-raw-veggies/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 08 Nov 2012 16:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1112</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts1-mm-bing-netthidh-4636710040699372pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1113" title="Veggie Art" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts1-mm-bing-netthidh-4636710040699372pid15-1.jpg" height="160" width="156" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Raw veggies. Cooked veggies. Some say, <i>Go raw</i>! Others say, <i>Cook</i> <i>âem</i>! As long as you donât deep fry or dip them in high calorie sauces (cheese and ranch come to mind...) the difference boils down to this: eating vegetables raw or cooked (not shriveled) is better than not eatingÂ  them at all. Some vegetables have higher nutrient content when eaten raw; some have higher nutrient content when cooked.

An example of a huge increase in vitamins by cooking is found in broccoli. The daily value of vitamin A goes from 43% (raw) to 87% (cooked); vitamin C jumps from 110% (raw) to 303% (cooked); vitamin E and K have 0% (raw) but 20% vitamin E and 494% vitamin K when cooked.

For more examples of <a title="raw vs cooked veggies" href="http://community.breastcancer.org/livegreen/to-cook-or-not-to-cook-that-is-the-question/">raw and cooked vegetable nutrient content</a>:

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#008000;"><strong><i>~ Celery raw is good for the jaw, but celery stewed is more quietly chewed ~</i></strong></span></p>]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

<item>
  <title>Cancer. You Can Help</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/12/cancer-you-can-help/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 12 Nov 2012 16:00:06 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1117</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4829450961158371pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1118" title="Helping out" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4829450961158371pid15-1.jpg" width="160" height="147" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Know someone with cancer? Want to help them?Â WhetherÂ someone has cancer, or needs help for another reason, you can have a big impact without knocking yourself out. Reach out to an elderly neighbor, a sick co-worker, or someone you know going through a rough time. You donât need to know the person well, or the details about their situation. The type of cancer doesnât matter if youâre offering to be a driver. <i>What type of cancer?âIf you donât mind me asking.</i> That falls under the category of nosy. Itâs about you fulfilling your need to know. If asking allows you to better serve, ask. If (like driving) it doesnât matter if the person has a cold or cancer, it makes no difference, so let them guide the conversation. You may even want to offer to stay quiet during the drive. some days I'd talk with my driver, other days I'd just close my eyes and soak in the silence. Depending on my driver, some Â could pick up cues, others couldn't. Some understood when I asked for a break from questions. Others filled the quiet moments with chatter, comforting themselves. Just be aware. Sometimes you know who can best serve you. If you have two people who offer the same job, and one is a better fit for how you're feeling, honor that. But also be aware that some days that specific person may not be available, and you'll need to adjust to a new type of help. Key words: Adjust and Help. You adjust. They help.

Caregivers, offer what you can do: take their trash cans out - or bring them back in. Bring them their mail. Run errands. Rides to the doctor. . . Iâd have people say, âIf you need anything, let me know.â Iâd let them know, only to learn they didnât drive beyond a ten-mile radius, or didnât cook. These same people who offered âanythingâ could have said, âI donât drive, but I know someone who can. Iâll ask them.â Or, âI donât cook, but what are you craving and I can order for you, and bring it over.â

What can you do to make a difference?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Clinical Studies</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/15/clinical-studies/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 15 Nov 2012 16:00:53 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1121</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts1-mm-bing-netthidh-4642267746336964pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1122" title="Clinical studies" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts1-mm-bing-netthidh-4642267746336964pid15-1.jpg" height="130" width="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google</em>

Before a drug is approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), it must progress through three stages of clinical trial studies to prove the drugâs safety and effectiveness.

<b>Phase One:Â </b>The drug is tested on humans for effectiveness and to ensure there are no serious side effects. During Phase One testing, the drug is also tested on other ailments, and in other dosages. If side effects are limited, the testing moves on the next phase.

<b>Phase Two:Â </b>During Phase Two, the drug being researched is tested on one specific disease in a larger group of patients than used in phase one testing. Pre-determined doses are used, with the focus on how well the drug treats and how well itâs tolerated by the patients.

<b>Phase Three:Â </b>Phase Three is where âblind testsâ are often preformed. This is where the patient isnât informed which treatment theyâre given. During this process, the drug being tested is compared with the existing drug(s). The new drug is again studied for itâs effectiveness, how well itâs tolerated, and itâs safety. The question in mind is, how, if at all, is it better than existing drugs? If the drug makes it to the end of this phase, results are submitted to the FDA for evaluation and approval. This phase can take years, because it involves manyÂ  patients and results can often be subtle, or working in favor of some, but not all patients.

When a drug enters Phase One clinical trials, analysts figure it has a 10%-20% chance of becoming marketable. As each phase is successfully completed, analysts may increase their estimation of the new treatmentâs marketability. Investors are interested in bidding on the odds of hopeâcancer research, specifically biotechnology. According to Kiplingerâs Personal Finance Magazine, 12/2012 biotechâs disappointing history for stockholders is a thing of the past. With new cancer-drug development being tested, biotech could be the win weâre all waiting for. If youâre interested in company specifics, there are seven biotechnology companies and their progress is in the 12/2012 issue of Kiplingerâs Personal Report. Your library may have a copy.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Holiday and Cancer Tips </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/19/holiday-and-cancer-tips/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 19 Nov 2012 16:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1128</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4618572411439731pid15-1w160h106.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1129" title="holiday eating and cancer" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4618572411439731pid15-1w160h106.jpg" height="106" width="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Iâm not one to live via paranoia, but I learned to take precautions during cancer treatment. Because of making wise choices, I never had to postpone any treatments. I went straight through, my eye on the prize of an end date, never getting sick. Here are some ideas that may help during the holiday season:
<ul>
	<li>You might need to nap more during the go-go of the holidays. If youâre visiting, or have company, let them know how often and for how long you nap. Itâll give give them some down time, too.</li>
	<li>If you canât avoid potÂ luck or buffet style food, try to get in line first. If you donât trust the hygiene standard of someone or the look of a dish, skip it.</li>
	<li>Make sure there are spoons for unwrapped snacks like candy and nuts, or toothpicks for cheese cubes and either skip chips and popcorn or get them in your own personal bowl before others begin digging in with their hands.</li>
	<li>If youâre having guests over for a holiday meal, or want to bring a side dish, bring something easy - like instant mashed potatoes or a green salad.</li>
	<li>If you go to a spiritual service or cultural event where people stand to sing or pray, stand seated if youâre tired. Itâs okay.</li>
	<li>If you want to gift people for a birthday or holiday but donât have energy to shop, make a top ten, twenty-five, fifty, or one hundred list. âTop 100 Reasons Why I Love You.â I made three lists: momâs, dadâs, and a friend. Each list included memories specific to the person and what theyâve done for me over my life.</li>
	<li>Someone comes over to visit and theyâre sick. Ask them to postpone the visit. If you donât feel you can do this, have someone else do it for you. If youâre in a metaphysical community, someone may toss out the line, âItâs consciousness. If you donât think youâll get sick, you wonât.â Well. . .Â  First, theyâre sick. Second, you have cancer. They have germs; you have a lowered immune system. No matter how awesome the usual health consciousness each of you may have, neither of you have it at this moment. Iâm very metaphysical, but we <i>must</i> live within our consciousness. (If you and a friend are sitting in your car in a dark parking lot and you donât feel safe, lock your door.) Itâs not about willing anything, or talking yourself out of fear in the moment. (Thatâs actually denial, masking it, rather than going to the cause of it and pulling up the entire root, not just the weed-thought.) Itâs a matter of shifting your consciousnessâand that tendsÂ  not to happen in the midst of feeling poorly. My point being: if others donât understand your situationâif they donât honor you, you must honor yourself enough to speak up, take action.</li>
</ul>
Peace, Health, and Happy Holidays!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title/>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/22/1131/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 22 Nov 2012 16:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1131</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4909487689238063pid15-1w160h120.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1138" title="Happy Thanksgiving" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4909487689238063pid15-1w160h120.jpg" height="120" width="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Happy Thanksgiving!

We are blessed beyond measure. Be grateful. There are so many people in war, in poverty, without a home from due to a storm, or another unforeseen situation. Give thanks for all that has brought you to this point in time. All the tears, the fear; the pain. Give thanks for the joy, the love, the laughter. Your friendsâpast and present. Every job you've held, even the ones you didn't fully enjoy. Bless your home, your food, your country and your life. Can you fill a page of paper with your gratitude? Life is good. Breathe it in.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cancer Awareness</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/cancer-awareness/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 26 Nov 2012 16:00:34 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1142</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4891629234488551pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1143" title="Cancer Awareness" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidi-4891629234488551pid15-1.jpg" height="264" width="264" /></a>image credit: Google

Iâll never forget walking into Vons grocery store October 1<sup>st</sup>, 2009. Less than a month out of chemo, I was still wearing my scarf, covering my bald head. About two steps into the store, my jaw dropped; I stood frozen. <i>Oh my gosh! How do they know Iâm having a bi-lateral mastectomy in three days? Howâd they know Iâd be here today? Am I their Mascot?</i> Then came the over head speaker recorded promotion. âDid you know one in eight women will be diagnosed with breast cancer. . .â I felt everyone was looking at me. The store had pink balloons and ribbons of hope <i>all</i> <i>over</i> the store. Just the day before, Iâd gone to the store and didnât feel self-conscious at all. Thirty more days to go.

Later in October, after surgery, I was back at Vons. In just the short time Iâd been away, my favorite cashiers whoâd seen me go through changes, and cheer me on werenât there. New cashiers didnât know me. Theyâd never seen me before. They didnât know I walked to the store almost daily, and always gave to their âcausesâ âbutÂ  not every day. At check out I was asked, âWould you like to donate to the cause?â I got a blank stare when I answered, âI gave at the office.â

The cancer awareness campaigns. Have they sparked vital conversation? Have the fundraisers, campaigns, products helped raise money for research? My complaint about having a month of breast cancer awareness is, it felt like being picked out; weâd never dare to have âdermatology awarenessâ at a high school. I never wore pink, a ribbon of hope, used cancer as an out, or for sympathy. On the other hand, I hear complaints from people with other types of cancer who feel theyâre overlooked. Do you know what cancers the color teal represents? How about white? I say, letâs do a month of âCancer Awareness.â âBut I realize thatâs not much of a money-maker. Marketing is about making money. âProceeds go to _______.â How <i>much</i> of the proceeds? Itâs a bit like California years ago promising schools a big win from lottery tickets sales. Maybe the schools do get money; I sure donât see it. And now schools are saving Box Tops for help. Iâm just a bit hesitant with all the âcancer awareness.â Letâs see some cancer <i>education.</i> Tipsâprevention, precaution, exams, phone numbers. My oncologist is now in the office an extra day every week. âThereâs been a cut back on funding for research.â If your intention is to help cancer research funding, ask about proceeds, where and how much goes to research (not administration, marketing, etc.), Check out websites like

<a href="http://charitynavigator.org">http://charitynavigator.org</a> or <a href="http://charitywatch.org">http://charitywatch.org</a> Note: Pay attention when searching for theses sites! There are some with same/similar names. The two sites Iâve listed are both âdot. orgâ sites. No hyphens. No plurals. âCharity Watchâ logo has a red dot with a black dog in front of it. Itâs tag line is â<i>American Institute of Philanthropy - Helping you give wisely to charity.</i>â âCharity Navigatorâ has the tag line, â<i>Your guide to intelligent giving.</i>â The logo is a teal compass.

Hereâs a link to Â <a title="bella online.com" href="http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art63546.asp">BellaOnline.com</a>Â  -Â a good article: Breast Cancer and the Psychology of Marketing]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Faith, Belief and Surviving  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/11/29/faith-belief-and-surviving/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 29 Nov 2012 16:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1148</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4611253799551853pid15-1w154h160.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1149" title="faith, hope, believe" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-4611253799551853pid15-1w154h160.jpg" height="160" width="154" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Belief is in our mind. Faith is in our heart. When you were diagnosed, did you anchor or lose your faith in someone, or something? Did your belief and faith match, or contradict each other?

If youâre interested in meditation, and are not familiar with Ram Dass, I encourage you to find his book, <i>Journey of Awakening</i>.

In this three-minute video, <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b30LSiFVxPM&amp;feature=related">Ram Dass talks with Oprah Winfrey</a> about his stroke. It crosses over to any major event, such as cancer: <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b30LSiFVxPM&amp;feature=related">
</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1148</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2012-11-29 08:00:31</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2012-11-29 16:00:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>faith-belief-and-surviving</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

<item>
  <title>Active After Cancer  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/03/active-after-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 03 Dec 2012 16:00:32 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1154</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1155" rel="attachment wp-att-1155"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1155" alt="Active after cancer" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts2-mm-bing-netimagesthumbnail-aspxq4511498824058101idef3cb15bcdd253530e4434fb22a5509f.jpg" height="88" width="160" /></a>

A few months after I completed chemo, my friend was diagnosed with diabetes. He called me in a panic, âSend me some salt substitute! Pop in the mail tomorrow!â He wasnât joking. His diet of bread, wine and candyâand to cover all food with saltâwas crashing in. In our relationship, I was the healthy, active oneâthe âletâs take the stairsâ person. He preferred the couch when he wasnât working evenings and weekends.

A few days ago I got an email from this friend. I now read his emails shaking my head at how tunes can change. In his recent correspondence, he mentioned his now playing tennis, going to the gym, and taking vigorous walks. <i>Who was this man? </i>He knew the States where on holiday, but made mention of my going to the gym, and how much progress Iâm making after three years of cancer treatment.

I responded saying, âYes, Iâm back at the gym. Last month I made it there once a weekâfor fifteen minutes each time. Front desk staff must think I swing-in to use the restroom! Last week I went to the gym for forty-five minutes! It felt like it, too. For twenty minutes I biked three miles with resistance, then lifted three and five pounds, and worked on my balance.â

My friend responded, <i>thrilled</i> at the jump of endurance from fifteen to forty-five minutes, adding, âI know youâre on holiday, but I know youâll get to the gym this week.â He and I were both amazed. His amazement is more uplifting than mine. . . Itâs an honor to have people believe in you when you canât believe how far south youâve moved from what you used to call the norm.

I got his email Friday night. I decided the pressure of his faith in me was good for me, and Saturday I headed to the gym. Again, I worked-out, solid forty-five minutes. Elliptical machine fifteen minutes with decent resistance, chest machines (clearly not ready for thisâit hurt, pulled/stretched my new implants that drag under my pec muscles whenever I move my arms in big motions - think sand paper.) Again I lifted three and five pound hand weights for biceps and triceps, then worked on my balance.

Saturday 7:30 p.m. <i>WHAMM-O! </i>I couldnât keep my eyes open. I gave in and went to bed. Waking-up Sunday 9:30 a.m., I felt every muscle in my body was sore. Roll call: <i>Advil</i>? Here. A<i>lpha Lipoic Acid</i>? Here. <i>Arnica</i>? Here.

Today the day is cold and cloudy.Â  A good day for cozying-in, and maybe a few toe-touches (putting on socks and shoes, that is.)

Some are able to walk <i>the</i> walk, or get on the bike and ride after cancer. Some arenât. Get off the comparisons. Physically, it can be hard to see where you <i>were </i>then, with where you <i>are now</i>. This is when practicing being present really helps. Youâre doing the best you can. Focus on the here and now. <i>This</i> is the moment that matters.

Breathe in.

Rest in the holy instant between breaths.

Breathe out.

Rest in the holy instant between breaths.

Repeat.

&nbsp;

<a title="activity quiz" href="http://www.aicr.org/reduce-your-cancer-risk/physical-activity/reduce_physical_quiz.html">Quiz: Are you active enough?</a><a href="http://www.aicr.org/reduce-your-cancer-risk/physical-activity/reduce_physical_quiz.html">Â </a>

<item>
  <title>cancer support </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/06/cancer-support/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 06 Dec 2012 16:00:36 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1158</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1159" rel="attachment wp-att-1159"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1159" alt="Support" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/th.jpeg" height="160" width="106" /></a>Â image credit: Google

I recently read an article in <a title="supporting the man with prostate cancer" href="http://curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/blog.showIndex/guest/2012/11/19/Supporting-the-man-with-prostate-cancer-The-ground-rules">Cure Today </a>on prostate cancer. Supporting the man with prostate cancer: The ground rules. Thereâs very little difference in what the person with a new diagnosis needs, even if the diagnosis is very different.
<ul>
	<li>Bring someone with you to the appointment. This is a great, but there are people who can ask doctors questions, listen and take notes at doctor appointments. They may opt to have their doctor appointment independently. Itâs how some of us are wired. Know what works best for you. If you want someone to be with you, ask them. Be wise about who you choose. Can your partner listen? Are they good note takers? Do they help you come up with questions to ask your medical team?</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Get your information from your medical team, not the internet; not even the health food store. If you do hear information floating around, talk with your doctor if that informationâs relevant to your situation. It may not be! I had numerous times when well-meaning (but not actively aware) people would tell me stories. Often these people had not even had cancer, or known someone close to them who had! They just knew the story to pass on. Warning: The story is often scary and wrong.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>No matter how much you like your first doctor, get a second opinion. You can always go back. Ask them each your treatment plan.</li>
	<li>Â Be present with your friend/family member. You donât have to follow them around like a puppy, but realize theyâll need you, and if youâre working as a team, theyâll value your input. Iâd recommend you listen before sharing your opinion, but if invited in, sharing their process is a vital role to their health and the health of your relationship.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>Happy Birthday!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/10/happy-birthday/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 10 Dec 2012 16:00:32 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1163</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1164" rel="attachment wp-att-1164"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1164" alt="IMG_1992" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/img_1992.jpg" height="438" width="584" /></a>

Birthdays. Iâve always felt having a birthday is a privilege, even if itâs a rough day. When people complain about getting older, I think (and sometimes say) âAnd the alternative?â

One year, a friend and I got together for my birthday. We walked the botanic gardens with the evening holiday lights. It was a rare, stormy night in San Diego but no rain fell while we were in the gardens. Then, we then got in my car and drove to dinner. On the way there, I shared I was feeling a bit down. Iâd had a good year; I see a birthday as celebration, not something to dread. I couldnât put my finger on it, but there was a heavy felling I hadnât been able to shake that week.

We talked then drove in the silence. In our silence, the rain began to absolutely pour down. I was paying very close attention to the road and cars around me. There were three lanes heading west. I was in the middle lane. A truck came from behind me to the lane on my left, then got in front of meâonly to get in the lane on the rightâand immediately take the freeway exit north!

When the truck got in front of us, I burst out laughing. On the back window of the truck in thick colorful paint: HAPPY BIRTHDAY! YOU ARE LOVED!! We then sat in silence again, before my friend said, âDo you get that, Claudia?â My energy shifted. I got it real clear.
<p style="text-align:center;">Â ***</p>
Â I have a dear friend who avoided birthdays for years. He wouldnât answer the phone, or tell anyone at work it was his birthday. He wouldnât celebrate at all. Very few people knew when his birthday was.

One year I was so mad at his attitude, I sent him a plant (I knew heâd love this) from a florist â to arrive while he was at work on his birthday. I called him the following day. He said, âIt was incredible timing.â I thought he meant it arrived on his birthday (duh!) No. It arrived when he was the only one in the office, and he hid it under his desk until leaving late that night, after everyone else had left.

Along came my cancer. We were both keenly aware that his girlfriend before me, and his girlfriend after me had both died. Neither of us wanted door number three. I donât think I was the reason, but he now does allow his day to come and go without resistance.

Birthdays. If weâre lucky, we have them. Celebrate your life. Celebrate those who love you.
<p style="text-align:center;">***</p>
Do you think of your birthday differently after cancer? Do you have new rituals such as meditation, or giving thanks for your life as you reflect? I just light another candle. As usual, I thank my parentsâfor life, love, and all the support theyâve each given me in so many ways. Iâm blessed with wonderful neighbors and friends who honor me with cards, dinner, flowers, and reminding me who I am. Life takes twists and turns. Heartache happens. So does incredible good. Open to the good. Embrace life as if everyday is your birth-day (because it is!)

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Pain Management  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/13/pain-management-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 13 Dec 2012 16:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1171</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Feet, hands, back, arms. Got pain? Post surgery; post treatment. The pain seems like it will never go away, but it usually does at least lessen. One-third of cancer patients continue to experience long-term pain after cancer treatment. The degree of pain can vary from mild to severe, and may last months to years.

Complimentary treatment can help ease the pain. Things like hypnosis, reiki, or massage can help â although it may be best to have <i>lymphatic</i> massage instead of a deep tissue one. Since cancer, Iâve stopped getting acupressure, but have found relief with acupuncture. Yoga can help, too, but again, be careful. If itâs too much for your lymphatic system, itâs not in your best interest. Soon after completion of treatment, a friend and I set out in our head scarves for our first and only yoga class. I sat through most the class as it was beyond my endurance level at the time. That night, my friendâsÂ  arm puffed up due to her stressing her lymph system during the âmodifiedâ yoga class. Just as when you go to the doctor, you must be your own advocate with complimentary treatments. Just because everyone else can do it, or is willing to listen to the teacher and not their own body, doesnât mean your body is ready or willing to do certain things anymore. Pay attention.

I would get down with the pain because it never seemed to lift. Iâd have treatment,Â then surgeryâanother treatmentâanotherÂ surgery . . . this went on for quite a while. As soon as I felt I was ready to get back into life, pain would set inâor another treatment, or surgery.

Be patient. Be loving to yourself. Be hopeful. I was one of those who a year out looked back and said, âI did all <i>that</i> for <i>this</i> level of living? <i>No</i>!â âAnd had what could be considered moments of regret, and depressionâfear for the unknown lifestyle I had before me. Iâve learned not to compare with what was, or the person next to me at the gym. I am a miracle just by waking up each day. (The truth is, we all are - with or without cancer!) So, if you wouldnât give your best friend grief about how far theyâve come, lighten up. Get off your own case. Move forward. Hereâs a link re: <a title="chronic pain after treatment" href="http://www.curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/article.show/id/2/article_id/1979">chronic pain after cancer treatment.</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Asking Questions to Cancer Patients</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/20/asking-questions-to-cancer-patients/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 20 Dec 2012 16:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1180</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1181" rel="attachment wp-att-1181"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1181" alt="Things People Say" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-4916475637989865pid15-1h160w160.jpg" width="160" height="160" /></a>

Cancer. It seems to come with a sign over your head: Ask Me Questions! That's great. It means people aren't afraid like they used to be. âBut theirs a downside. Some people ask questions that are none of their business, and in fact, rude. The barrier of being a stranger seems to vanish, and your personal life becomes fair game for their inquiring mind. If this happens to you, set your boundaries, especially if you're low on energy.

When I was bald and wearing a scarf, I ran into a neighbor of mine. She has a developmental disability. She hadnât seen me since Iâd lost my hair, and knew nothing about my having cancer. After a short chat, she said, âWhatâs up with?â âpointing to her head. I told her I had cancer.

A few weeks later she told me she was having a rough day at school. âIt would make you pull your hair out! âWell, not you; you donât have any hair.â I had to laugh, mainly because it wasnât meant to be edgy and she continued right on with her story.

Then there were the stupid comments from people who function at higher levels. These comments came from complete strangers. This tells me one very important thing: The people with whom I associate are intelligent and perceptive.

âWere you shocked when you were diagnosed?â If I hadnât been so shocked when I was asked this from a man Iâd never met before, I may have said, âNope. It was on my calendar. Cancer is such an inconvenience when it comes unexpectedly.â I was asked the <i>exact</i> same question by another man who lived in my apartment complex at the time. Perhaps these men where trying to express some empathy. Maybe they had never known anyone with cancer. The answer is yes. Donât ask it.

Women arenât immune from this, either. Iâd usually getâwith little discussion beforehand, âWhat kind of cancer?â <i>I donât know you. Why does the type of my cancer matter?</i> One time, I did in fact step back when a woman I didnât know who asked me how my cancer was discovered. âDid you, or did your doctor discover it?â I must have worn my thought on my face. She said, âIâm a nurse.â I replied, âNot mine.â (Nor was she an oncology nurse.)

Then there are the health tips you may get from well-meaning, but uninformed people (or at least uninformed from sources I'd accept as valid information.) I don't care how marvelous they tell you hydrogen peroxide is, do <em>not</em> drink it, or bathe in it. It will not cure or prevent cancer. When there is a cure for cancer, it will be on front page news, radio, and T.V.

For me, it largely depends on the person asking the questions, and how they ask them. If someone is genuinely wanting to be educated, Iâll answer anything. How about you? What strange questions or comments did you/do you get? How do you feel about getting those questions?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>An Affirmative Prayer for Inner Peace</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/17/an-affirmative-prayer-for-inner-peace/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 17 Dec 2012 16:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1200</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1235" rel="attachment wp-att-1235"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1235" alt="Prayer for inner peace" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4994278967738623pid15-1h160w160.jpg" width="160" height="160" /></a>

Please take a few minutes to join me in this spiritual, not religious, affirmative prayer for inner peace.

In America, there's lots of heart ache right now. We're in the midst of the season of love, joy - the season especially for children. For those who've been touched by the school shooting last week â wether in person, or through news, there's lots of healing to take place. It won't happen over night, but my prayer is that it will happen.

Below is an affirmative prayer. It's actually part prayer, part meditation, and part teaching someone who's not used to prayer or meditation what they can do to bring themselves inner peace. It is only by raising our personal energetic vibration that we can shift the energies around us, the collective consciousness. Thanks for taking the time to read this. It isn't "religious" but written for all.

There is One power. It is God, the good. This presence of good is in all. There is no separation. We can <i>think</i> weâre separate, we can <i>act</i> as if weâre separate, but God, the good is in us, as us. It is closer than our very next breath.

Just as a drop of the ocean has all of the ocean within it, we have all of God within us. Not one person has more God than another. Some may study or practice It more, but God is within us 100% â all the time âwaiting for our recognition and acceptance of It to activate into glorious fulfillment.

When thereâs pain or confusion, turn to the peaceful power within. It never left. Things just got noisy and the still, quiet voice was muffled.

Stop. Breathe. Turn off the T.V. or radio. Stop the monkey-mind chatter. Leave your troubles at the door or at your feet. If you want the troubles back when youâre done sitting still, you can consciously pick them up againâor notâbecause youâll be of clear mind, and able to decide they donât serve you.

Look for good. Are you frustrated about how people are driving? Look for the good drivers! Bless them, thank them as youâre on the road together, creating a safe atmosphere for everyone. Look for spots of beauty. Consciously acknowledge it! âIsnât that a gorgeous cloud!â

Listen to God. Itâs speaking to you all the time. The nudge, the gift, the comfort in times of pain and confusion.

Even in incredibly tough times, there are shards of light for which to be grateful. Give thanks. What did or didnât happen in the midst of chaos? Who was or wasnât there that made it a bit better. The whys may never get answered. We may need to create our own answers to âwhyâ, or move forward without having them answered.

Let go. When someone dies itâs often like a rope burn. Theyâve been pulled from our grasp. We mourn, heal, mourn more; heal more. The memories keep us company. We hope and trust the pain will soften.

Be gentle on you, on others,

Peace. Deep Peace.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Celebrate the Light within You</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/24/celebrate-the-light-within-you/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 24 Dec 2012 16:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1252</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[If you celebrate it, Merry Christmas!

âWhen the things you have are more important than the things you don'tâCheers!

If you don't celebrate the birth of Christ, celebrate the birth of Light within you. The spark of good, the sacred place within that can never be hurt, lost or ill. Nurture that spot. Allow it to expand as love, hope and health.
<ul>
	<li>Smile. Smile to strangers, smile to yourself in the mirror, smile when you're on the phone.</li>
	<li>Laugh. Laugh with life, laugh with others, laugh at your absurdities.</li>
	<li>Love. Love yourselfâwherever you are in the process of life. Love othersâthey are sacred messengers. Love the Universal Energy of love itself.</li>
</ul>
<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1253" rel="attachment wp-att-1253"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1253" alt="IMG_0734" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/img_0734.jpg" width="584" height="438" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>What if cancer comes back?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/31/what-if-cancer-comes-back/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 31 Dec 2012 16:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1263</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1264" rel="attachment wp-att-1264"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1264" alt="re-diagnosis" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts3-mm-bing-netthidh-4716450460599878pid15-1h160w160.jpg" width="160" height="160" /></a>Â credit: Google image

I heard so many with cancer worry, âWhat if it comes back?â

I was asked (always by a stranger, which I found odd), âWhat if it comes back?â

I knew it could happen. I was in remission. I was happy. I had no worry of âwhat if. . .â

Some would say, âWell. . . **it happens.â

Two years and two days after my first diagnosis, I was re-diagnosed. It came back. If there is a second time, on the plus side, you know what to do. Youâve done the drill before. On the down side, youâre familiar with what this journey requires of you, and you may not feel up to it a second time. You may feel you gave it your best on the first go around, and youâre not back to that level yet.

Give it a good cry; a string of cussing and the best pep-talk youâve ever given yourself. My doctors got more push-back from me the second time than they did the first. Another thing that changed: Prior, I didnât keep anything cancer related after my last day of cancer treatment (no photos, pink, etc.). I still have affirmations and photos from my last day of treatment in clear view

Donât fear âWhat if it comes back?âÂ  It will, or it wonât. Donât waste your time, energy or head space with it. Either way, you have the tools.

<i>Keep moving in the direction of your dreams</i> - (Henry David Thoreau).]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>New Year's Mantras and Meditations</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/12/27/new-years-mantras-and-meditations/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 27 Dec 2012 16:00:46 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1268</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[Thich Nhat Hanh's four Mantras onÂ Super Soul Sunday with Oprah Winfrey

[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UEUxFNkISnU]

Happy New Year! Or, is it Happy newÂ <i>here</i>! If youâre tired of loud holiday parties with way too much food and alcohol, maybe youâd like to consider ringing in the new year in a quiet way, full of intention.

There may be a world peace meditation going on near you. Itâs set at Greenwich, England meantime 12:00 noon on Jan 1. If youâre on the west cost in the states, itâs true commitment: 4:00 a.m. on Dec 31. You go to bed Dec 30, and wake up super early on Dec 31. If you still want to see in the new year, itâs possible if you take a nap after meditation.

New thought churches are where Iâve always found world peace meditations. If you decide to do it on your own, and perhaps at a different time, you could invite a few friends over who understand the intention youâre setting. Itâs a bit of a game changer when someone thinks party, and gets quiet meditation. You can always have breakfast and conversation afterwards!

Whenever and however you do this, donât get stressed out. Even if you donât do a full hour. Maybe you can read something peaceful, sing your favorite peaceful song, or put together a vision board with the focus being peace.

If your intention is peace, you canât go wrong. One new yearâs at midnight in New Zealand I lead a small group of us at WWOOF (willing workers on organic farms). Their English was limitedâbut not as much as my Korean. The lights on the Christmas tree were beautifulâin any language. Somehow we figured it out: I found a globe, and we sat there in quiet, bathing the globe in white light and peace.

The only way to world peace is through personal peace.

Below are some more meditation links:
<ul>
	<li><a href="//www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ul0jwF7ZJTU&amp;feature=related"><strong>Deepak Chopra begins this 14 minute video talking about meditation, then it goes into music and visuals to watch if you choose to meditate with your eyes open</strong></a></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://ow.ly/fJoiu">Â </a><b><a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NMldMnEfxX8&amp;feature=related">Asking for Nothing, and Receiving Everything Meditation</a></b></strong></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Food Meditation</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/03/food-meditation/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 03 Jan 2013 16:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1272</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1275" rel="attachment wp-att-1275"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1275" alt="Mindful eating" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts4-mm-bing-netthidh-4776799048239167pid15-1h109w160.jpg" width="160" height="109" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Before you eat, do you bless your food? Do you think of all the ways the food before you supports your existence? From the sunshine and water, to the farmers, truckers, store clerks, and if it has a wrapper on it, the designer of the package and the person who bought, prepared, and about to eat the food? We could even go out further to prove to ourself the support of all the universe by including our dishes, the chair on which we sit, the drink weâre about to have with the meal. . .

Can you eat in total silence? So many people eat fast. They donât even know whatâs in their mouth at any given point. Try this: Eat with someone and out of the blue ask: Whatâs in your mouth right now? Describe the taste, and texture. Some people have to stop and think what food is in their mouth! And their hard pressed to describe it.

<a title="appreciating the food we eat" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Emd9q6_o6Z0">Appreciating the food we eat</a> doesnât just mean, âThank youâ. Itâs about being aware. Hereâs are two links about <a title="mindful eating" href="http://www.theworld.org/2012/02/mindful-eating-thich-nhat-hanh">mindful eating</a>. <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Emd9q6_o6Z0">
</a>

This is about Thich Nhat Hanhâs meditation center in southern France. If youâre in southern California, there is a Buddhist monastery that allows the public to join the monks on certain days for mindful eating. (<a title="Deer Park Monastery" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4CsDi9TbChA">Deer Park Monastery</a>, Escondido, California.)]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Another Cancer Study</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/07/another-cancer-study/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 07 Jan 2013 16:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1281</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?attachment_id=1282" rel="attachment wp-att-1282"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1282" alt="another cancer study" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/http-ts1-mm-bing-netthidi-4568991354914340pid15-1w136h160.jpg" width="136" height="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google

Every once in a while I come across a study that makes me want to get together with the researchers. I realize every person is individual, and every cancer is different, too. Perhaps this is what makes me shake my head the most when I read these studies.

This most recent study I read claimed, â<i>Science is finding links between diet and disease. The right combination of foods helps prevent cancers. What to eat and what to avoid</i>.â The head of Harvard School of Public Health states, âDozens and dozens of studies show that people who are overweight or obese have higher rates of many different cancers. Itâs not just one study or two, thereâs a massive amount of evidence.â

I used to believe the information about weight and diet more than I do now. I'm tall, thin, and have always been somewhat active and eaten healthy foods. Not a big drinker; never a smoker âyou get the picture.

The study done by National Institutes of Health and AARP followed half million people over the age of 50. The study began in 1995, and looked at the connection between diet and cancer. Like a kid at the fair, Iâm under the measurement line. Canât join AARP yet. I do know folks who are AARP age, and gave me the study to read.

Iâm weary of studies with convincing wording like âstrongest evidence to dateâ âlinks between diet and cancer.â Weâve read it all beforeâthen it changes. Remember coffee? It used to be bad for you. Bad. Bad. Bad. Now âstudies showâ women who drink more than three cups of coffee a day are 35 percent less likely to be diagnosed with endometrial cancer. Men and women who drank four or more cups of coffee a day (either decaf or regular) had lower risk of colon cancer compared with non-coffee drinkers. Iâm not a coffee drinker. Maybe thatâs why I ask, âIs this irresponsible journalism?â I know a woman who drank coffeeâ<i>lots</i> of it. Hot coffee; iced coffee; any coffee. She all-of-a-sudden died one night while at a neighborhood party (but, she didnât have endometrial or colon cancer!)

On to meat. Now pork and lamb count as red meat, and the cancer risk with meat âcould be tied to the naturally high iron content of red meat.â Itâs now suggested that 18 ounces of protein a week come cooked red meat. Funny, thatâs much closer to where I was before getting cancer and being told to increase my protein intakeâspecifically from red meat. âFor cancer prevention fill two-thirds of your plate with plant-based foods: vegetables, beans, whole grains and nuts. No more than a third of your meal should be animal-based, such as chicken, seafood, lean beef, or low-fat dairy products.â I find this sort of âstudyâ crazy! Isnât this common sense? Where do they get their funding? How much money is going into gathering these tried and true, already known facts?

But onto another study. Just in time. Donât get too comfy with your health knowledge regarding fruits and vegetables. Researchers now say, âWeâve over-sold their protective qualities.â WHAT? Yes. If you tell people they wonât get cancer if they eat fruits and vegetables, then youâve over-sold it. If you tell people this is a healthy life-styleâan aspect of cancer preventionâbut no guarantee, then you are presenting the facts in a responsible way. In my view, this would also include giving up studies on chocolate and wine. Tell people, especially if thereâs weight gain, to follow the moderation rule with all food and drink, and have researchers donate the money saved on the study to something other than food related.

By the time I finished reading the study on cancer and food, I was madâwhich is sort of funny, because I know being mad isnât good for anyoneâs health! If youâre interested, thereâs more to the study. If you have access to a paper copy or online at AARP.org/bulletin December 2012. The article ended with, âConsider your total diet...The more colors the more nutrients.â From now on, I suggest reading only the last paragraph of all studies, and promoting future action-based studies. What about taking care of our soil, getting rid of extreme use of pesticides and lessening our reliance/acceptance of processed foods. What if knowledge of the power of our minds was introduced early and mainstream, not esoteric? Sort of like âeat your fruits and vegetables.â]]></content:encoded>

    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Yes. We live in 7/24 news bits, so the faster the betterâand if it's wrong, say so later. I'm not bashing science at all. It is, after all, what has helped us come this far in cancer, and what will help us even more. Thanks for your input and for giving science a thumbs up. Keep your love of science - it's an amazing, wonderful field! We have so much for which to be grateful.]]></wp:comment_content>

    <wp:comment_date>2013-01-07 09:41:09</wp:comment_date>
    <wp:comment_date_gmt>2013-01-07 17:41:09</wp:comment_date_gmt>
    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I think part of the problem is the highly competitive nature of research. You're only "valuable" as a researcher if you publish a lot, and you/your institution gets paid (grants) and pays you based off of how much you publish, publish, publish! This can lead to people wanting to get out information faster than the next person can, or even publishing smaller parts of a study at a time to have more publishable findings. Then, we can get sometimes confusing things like this. Other times, it's true that certain food products in specific amounts reduce the risk of one health problem, while increasing the risk of another in other amounts, or even in the same amount. Science is weird, and I think that's why I love it, but it can be quite frustrating. It's mostly just a very long series of educated guesses.]]></wp:comment_content>

    <wp:commentmeta>
      <wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
      <wp:meta_value>a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1359134996.4543559551239013671875;s:7:"message";s:49:"bookoftips changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:10:"bookoftips";}</wp:meta_value>
    </wp:commentmeta>
    <wp:commentmeta>

<item>
  <title>Got Cancer. Any Questions?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/10/got-cancer-any-questions/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 10 Jan 2013 16:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1285</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-5011746633025641pid15-1h160w118.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1286" alt="Questions" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-5011746633025641pid15-1h160w118.jpg" width="118" height="160" /></a>Â image credit: Google

After my oncologist told me I was an extremely healthy individualâwith cancer, I asked, "How did I get this?" "How long have I had it?" He said, "We just don't know. The best thing you can do is move on from here." That was so helpful for me to hear. I knew it already, but to hear it from my oncologist gave me peace. There was no blame. Just the facts, maâam (and with cancer, thereâs lots of gray area.)

I frequently see the phrase, âStupid cancerâon blogs, tweets and shirts. Cancerâs not stupid but some questions about it are. Some folks are sleep walking through life. They donât set out to be rude or pry into your personal affairs, butâ<i>wow</i> do some of them miss the mark! If someone asks you âHowâd you get this?â or in metaphysical circles, âWhat did you do to create this?â you could always answer, "By asking too many questions." I bet itâll stop further questions!

I like to educate people, but there are times Iâm tired, fed upâand yes, sometimes when Iâm not patient or willing enough to be non-judgmental about the person asking the question. Some ask questions out of curiosity. From strangers or gossips, I have low tolerance for that. Some genuinely want to learn. Iâm more than willing to open up for them.

Hold your head high. If you want a break from questions about cancer, say so. Let your friends and family know cancer doesnât define who you are, and that you need a break from it. Offer a new topic of conversation. You donât have to blast people, but set your boundaries in how much talk-time and emotion you give to cancer when youâre not at your doctor appointment.

If strangers are asking you questions, think of it as being a movie star. Iâm sure stars get it all the time. âHowâd you become famous?â âHow much money do you make?â If you can give an answer, I think thatâs best. <i>THAT</i> is cancer awareness moving into cancer education. Q: âHowâd you get cancer?â A: âScience still doesnât completely know how people get cancer.â âI have no idea.â A bit more flippant, âWe all take turns at something.â

I had people ask about my finances. Not open-ended, âIf you need financial help...â âAre you financially okay?â The questions were specific for information, and didnât come from my closest friends, but from casual acquaintances. âHow are you paying your bills?â is just one of the many you may be asked. No matter who it is, you have every right to not answer. You can ask <i>them</i> why they need to know. I promise theyâll say, âIâm concerned.â That would bring another question to my mind: How does their knowing the answer help me? I learned this strategy after the third person asked me. I said, âAre you offering to pay my rent?â Itâs no oneâs business unless theyâre offering to help you.
<p style="text-align:center;">Â Got cancer.</p>
<p style="text-align:center;">âAny questions?</p>]]></content:encoded>
