<item>
  <title>Healthy Eating Habits After the Holidays</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/14/healthy-eating-habits-after-the-holidays/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 14 Jan 2013 16:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1291</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-3.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1292" alt="After the Holidays" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-3.jpeg" width="160" height="131" /></a>Â Image credit: Google

Holidays are over. Time to get back on track with good eating habits. If youâre in treatment for cancer, or have a decreased desire for food, here are some ways to get the most benefit out ofÂ food without feeling force-fed, stuffed, then skipping a meal. The purpose of this is to be healthy, not eat now; starve later.

If youâre not eating many fruits, make a fruit smoothie. Even if itâs now and then. Most people make a smoothie in the morning, but if youâd rather have it for lunch, then make one for lunch. Do eat breakfast, though. Itâs called breakfast because it breaks the fast youâve had over night. Eating breakfast gets your metabolism going, so by eating breakfast, you burn calories, too. By not eating a healthy breakfast, your body wonders when the next meal may be, and begins to hold on to what fat it has, âjust in case.â

Focus on what to eat rather than what not to eat. Rather than a list of what you canât eat, shouldnât eat, or donât like to eat, make a list of what sounds good to you. What healthy good are you craving? When I was in treatment for cancer and I craved something, Iâd go and get it right then, or ask someone to get it for me. I craved foods high in iron. Our bodies are pretty smart. They usually know what we need. Look at what youâre eating.

If your appetite has decreased, eat vegetables at lunch so you donât have to fit them all in at dinner. Snack on veggies. Cook them slightly and sprinkle seasoning on them, add maybe a *pinch* of cheese on top. You donât have to eat cups of them; just eat them. Many people know they donât eat the recommended daily allowance of fruits and vegetables, so they tend to even eat lessâknowing theyâve missed the mark already. Some is better than none. Learn how to prepare them in a way you enjoy. Hopefully youâll decide to save sauces, dips and cheeses for special treats. Just be conscious. . .

Older adults require more protein than younger adults. 30 grams of protein at every meal is recommended to boost muscle mass and strength. It could be an egg, peanut butter, or low-fat yogurt. Greek yogurt is high in protein. Lean meat leftovers such as fish, or chicken can be made into salads for lunchâtoss a small handful of nuts or a spoon of beans on the side, and youâve got yourself a healthy meal.

If youâve never been a nutrition label reader, start reading them after treatment. It takes some getting used to, and may vary between people if theyâre looking for something specific. I was too tired during treatment to use my energy reading labels, and I had years of label reading behind me, so pretty much knew what was high in salt, sugar, fat. Compare brands, too.

It may mean bringing reading glasses with you, and taking a bit longer to read while others reach in front of you, or weave around you with their cart. Donât worry. Look in their cart! Iâm always happy with my choice of health when I do.

This may be the beginning of you making your <i>own</i> pasta sauce and pizza! âAnd being happier with eating nutritious, minimally processed foods. If not, just learn how to make wise choices.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

      <wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
      <wp:meta_value>a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1359136285.216393947601318359375;s:7:"message";s:49:"bookoftips changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:10:"bookoftips";}</wp:meta_value>
    </wp:commentmeta>
    <wp:commentmeta>
      <wp:meta_key>_elasticsearch_indexed_on</wp:meta_key>
      <wp:meta_value>2013-01-21 01:50:29</wp:meta_value>

<item>
  <title>Weight Change During and After Cancer  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/17/weight-changes-and-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 17 Jan 2013 16:00:04 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1295</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-4.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1296" alt="Healthy Apple" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-4.jpeg" width="160" height="120" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

American Institute for Cancer Research <a href="http://www.aicr.org">www.aicr.org</a> and Dr. Bradshaw report results from a new study. Results found that women whose weight changes after a breast cancer diagnosis have lower survival rates. Dr. Bradshawâs study followed 1,436 women diagnosed with breast cancer between 1996 and 1997, and included follow-up interviews until 2005. During the follow-up period, 11% of the women died from their cancer. 3/4 of these cancers were estrogen-receptor positive, and therefore likely to be influenced by fatty tissue.

Findings from this study:
<ul>
	<li>Both weight gain and weight loss after breast cancer diagnosis decreased survival.</li>
	<li>Women in the first two years after diagnosis were especially at risk.</li>
	<li>Women who gained more than 10% of the their pre-diagnosis weight after a breast cancer diagnosis died nearly 3 times faster from their cancer.</li>
</ul>
âThese findings underscore the importance of maintaining a healthy weight,â says Dr. Bradshaw, âespecially in the immediate post-diagnosis period when chemotherapy may disrupt eating habits and appetite. He advises, âWork with your doctor to find an activity plan that lets you be as active s possible.â

If you begin to notice a weight gain, watch what you eat. Be conscious of what and when you eat. Move more. You donât have to walk <i>The Walk</i>, but move your body. Get up, get out, get movinâ.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1295</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2013-01-17 08:00:04</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-17 16:00:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>weight-changes-and-cancer</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

<item>
  <title>Eating during Chemo  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/21/eating-during-chemo/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 21 Jan 2013 16:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1300</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-5.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1301" alt="beans" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-5.jpeg" width="160" height="106" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

Itâs tough when you donât want to eat during cancer treatment, but you know you need to. Here are some ideas. If youâre too tired, ask someone to make some for you:

Egg - scrambled, sunny side up, easy over. Pancake. Waffle. French toast. One piece of bread. One tortilla with some cheese. Cottage cheese. Yogurt. Ice cream. Apple sauce. Banana. Smoothie (I love plain yogurt, a bit of cranberry juice and a banana. If you wonât hold it against me, may I suggest adding a big scoop of vanilla ice cream? Yumm!) If the smoothie is more for riding the medication constipation, hands down itâs chard, banana and water. Yes. It sounds and looks awfulâbut it works!

Green beans. I ate 'em right out of the can. Fresh green beans may hurt if you have mouth sores, and chemo changes the taste.Â Brown beans. Black beans. White beans. I dumped out of the can and made a salad with a bit of tomato, onion, parsley or cilantro, and cumin. I'd shake things up by changing the color of bean, the seasoning, and adding what looked good. Maybe one day adding frozen peas and corn.

Popsicles. Ice cream. Pudding. Watered down juice. Soup - split pea soup is high in iron. Macaroni and cheese. Soft taco. Watermelon - is high in iron.

Go for a walk. Even if itâs around the block, or three times to the mailbox.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Don't Worry</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/24/dont-worry/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 24 Jan 2013 16:00:31 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1313</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-6.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1325" alt="attitude" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-6.jpeg" width="160" height="100" /></a>Â Image credit: Good Search

Years ago I read this and every now and then it pops up as a reminder: <i>If you worry, pray. If you pray, donât worry. </i>Change is inevitable. Sometimes the change is fast and incomprehensible. How we <i>respond</i> is our choice. Weâre never alone. We can <i>feel</i> alone. We can push aside our spiritual beliefs, or refuse to believe in a Higher Power. Even that doesnât work. The Higher Power is <i>within</i> us, and through us. It is always for us.

Whateverâs going on, itâs not about a Higher Power dissing you. It can give us nudges, signs, and put helpful people and things in front of us. Even with arrows pointing the way, we must figure out whatâs helpful, and what to do when âthe signâ is presented before us.

Weâre the ones who direct the flow of Infinite Intelligence. Whereâs your attention? If itâs on sickness, the Universal Flow brings you more. If your attention is on healing, Itâs on its way. See the difference? Itâs like focusing on loneliness when you want friends. Why would you focus on loneliness? Donât. Focus on what you want to experience. Friends, laughter, good times. See a loving couple enjoying each otherâs company in the store? Say, âThatâs for me!â

Whatever weâre affirming, weâre directing Infinite Intelligence to work in that direction for us (and in some cases, against us.) The more aware and more allowing we are of Itâs work, the more our receptivity to It continues to increase. The better we know how to work with It, the happier we are.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>About Nut Midline Carcinoma</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/28/about-nut-midline-carcinoma/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 28 Jan 2013 16:00:42 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1329</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-10.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1331" alt="NMC" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/th-10.jpeg" width="160" height="122" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

I recently received a comment from someone who included some information about Nut Midline Carcinoma. If you are familiar with this aggressive cancer, and want a blog that focuses on it, here's a link.

<a href="http://stridesforstephenstepstocurenmc.wordpress.com/aboutnutmidlinecarcinoma/">About Nut Midline Carcinoma</a>.

http://stridesforstephenstepstocurenmc.wordpress.com/stephensstory/

<item>
  <title>Gentle Exercise</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/01/31/gentle-exercise/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 31 Jan 2013 16:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1333</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-4987312591342217pid15-1h160w120.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1335" alt="gentle exercise" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidh-4987312591342217pid15-1h160w120.jpg" width="120" height="160" /></a>imageÂ credit: Good Search

Energy = A body in motion stays in motion. During cancer treatment youâll hear, âStay active.â You may not feel like being active, and you may argue, âI canâtâ, âIâm <i>tired</i>!â I hear you. Prior to cancer, I was active. During cancer, my oncologist would tell me to exercise. Iâd go on short walksâten minutes max. When I completed treatment, I was willing to push myself, but during treatment I was at the end of my rope, hanging on, tying a knot so I didnât slip off. If this sounds like you, I suggest a real honest talk with your oncologist and yourself. If youâre âtiredâ âwell, thatâs part of the deal, isnât it? But can you push it a bit without getting sick? Know your body. Respect your body. Sometimes that means moving it. Sometimes it means restingÂ it. Itâs a delicate balance.

If youâre not walking 20 minute walks, are you walking to the mailbox 1-2 times a day? Is a neighbor a few doors down whom youâd like to visit? Can that neighbor come get you and join you for a 10 minute walk? Itâs not about being the athlete. I remember mopping the floor for the first time after treatment. I was so weak I couldn't squeeze the water out of the mop sponge! So, I used my leg to brace the mop and was able to wring it a bit. My floor was sopping wetâbut clean! At this point, exercise is more about circulating blood, counter swelling, and brightening moods. You may even sleep even more, which was my concern, because I was sleeping 19-21 hours a day. Indeed, I did sleep more when I exercised, but eventually, my strength allowed me to do more in my waking hours, and sleep like a champ.

Do some gentle stretching, and short walks. Itâs like making a deposit of energy and strength into your health account. You can bank on it!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Building relationships during cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/11/building-relationships-during-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 11 Feb 2013 16:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1341</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/support-group.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1348" alt="Beary good friends" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/support-group.jpg?w=300" width="300" height="199" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Talking things out helps many women, especially during cancer treatment, when emotions are stirred and hormones are effected by treatment, medication and surgery. You may not have family or friends who understand cancer or what youâre going through.Â  Even if someone you know once had cancer, they may have experienced it differently than you.

Maybe you find your strength at a spiritual center, through a friend, family, a support group, or one-to-one counseling. No matter where you find it, support can really improve your quality of life. Support groups can be found at hospitals, clinics, advocacy organizations, and spiritual centers. One of my greatest moments of empowerment through a support group was when I requested American Cancer Society (ACS)to connect me with a woman my age, my situation, and what they decided with the decision before themâand why. ACS searched and finally found three close cases. I gave approval for the women to call me. They did. Each of them shared with me their situationâeach similar to mine, and each made different choices. They were awesome, not telling me what to do, but sharing why they did what they didâwhich is what I requested to hear.

I also had benefited from one-to-one counseling with an intern at the cancer center. It gave her practice, and me a sounding board. There are options out there. If your insurance doesnât cover counseling and youâre interested in it, try some support groups, ask about an intern, check outside of the clinic and see what the community has to offer. Maybe thereâs a support group somewhere out of the hospital setting. You may find you donât want a support group, or counseling and get plenty of support from family and friends. Whatever you choose is right for you, if it helps you through the process.

One thing that may help move through cancer is to give thought to life <em>after</em> cancer. To aim and think of when youâll feel well, and return to normalcy. This was one of the biggest carrots for my Â healingâto focus on the direction I wanted to go. Iâd see it, feel it, and breathe it in. What do you do?]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Stress Reduction for Cancer Patients</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/07/stress-reduction-for-cancer-patients/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 07 Feb 2013 16:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1351</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/deep_breath.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1352" alt="deep_breath" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/deep_breath.jpg?w=291" width="291" height="300" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Cancer. A positive attitude will help, but donât put an added weight on your shoulders by expecting always be happy, chipper and having the energy, or body of Wonder Woman. It'll just add to the stress of it all.

Knowing stress-reducing activities can help. Find activities you enjoy. I requested people to pick up comedy and travel DVDs from the library that I could watch while on the couch. I also listened to CDs of music and books, and downloads of hypnosis for pain reduction, to which Iâd often drift off to sleep. Iâd also drift off during meditation, or prayer.

If you donât know how to meditate, but think it may help you, donât make a big deal about it. Try breathing deep, slow breaths when youâre lying down, trying to fall asleep. For me, It would help to say a positive affirmation or short prayerâone word with each inhale. It means a short phrase will take a long time, and you may forget the next word, or get tired enough from the deep breathing that youâll fall asleep during the process. If you choose to do short affirmations, it may go something like this:

Lower your shoulders. Even when we're lying down, we have them raised, which is a state of stress, not relaxation. Deeply inhale in as you mentally say, âI.â When you fully inhale, thereâll be a moment where you pause into the nothingnessâneither inhaling or exhaling, without holding your breath. Your body will know when to begin the exhale. After completely exhaling, thereâll be another moment where you pause into the nothingnessâneither inhaling or exhaling, and not forcing your breath out. Your body will know when to inhale, and as you inhale, mentally say, âAm.â On your next inhale, you might mentally say, âHealthâ or âPeaceâ or âComfortââWhatever comes to you. If âWatermelonâ comes to you, allow it, and continue with your breathing. Itâs about release, not control or judgement. You can begin with âIâ on the next inhale.

When I used a prayer, I almost always fell asleep around the tenth word, which was what I used on purpose to help me fall asleepâand I believe falling asleep to a peaceful mind is setting the stage for healing during sleep. I also believe some of us sleep to heal. Anytime Iâve gotten sick, if I could get sleep, I recovered pretty quickly. I figure my healing Guides get me out-of-the-way so they can do the healing.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Pink Time Outs Program</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/04/pink-time-outs-program/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 04 Feb 2013 16:00:23 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1356</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/jean-new-smile.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1357" alt="Jean-new-smile" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/jean-new-smile.jpg?w=266" width="266" height="300" /></a>

Some of you may know Jean Campbell. Sheâs behind the blog <em>No Boobs About It</em>. Sheâs got a passion about spreading the word, and helping others -women and men- whoâve experienced breast cancer. Her latest accomplishment is <em>Pink Time Outs Program</em>.

The Pink Time Outs Program provides women and men, who have recentlyÂ finished active treatment (surgery, chemo, radiation) for breast cancer,Â with funded short getaways from all things breast cancer.

The Pink Time OutsÂ© Program is about using short getaways to put closureÂ on the end of active treatment and facilitate the transition to life as aÂ survivor. The goals of this program are simple:
<ul>
	<li>A physical and mental break from all talk, sights and routines thatÂ remind us of breast cancer</li>
	<li>Â The opportunity to feel refreshed in mind, body and spirit</li>
	<li>To enjoy a much-needed time out to recreate and participate inÂ normalizing activities</li>
	<li>The freedom to think about something other than breast cancer, to beginÂ thinking about what comes next as a survivor.</li>
	<li></li>
</ul>
TheÂ first Pink Time OutsÂ©Â funded getaway is April 2, 2013 at the Biltmore Estates inÂ Ashville, North Carolina. To see the details of the trip, please go toÂ <a href="http://noboobsaboutit.org/pink-time-outs/">http://noboobsaboutit.org/pink-time-outs/</a>

The winner and companion will be chosen by lottery drawing.Â The Biltmore Estates getaway is the first of many getaways planned in theÂ months to come across the U.S. and Canada.Â Individuals who qualify for this lottery event can take part and be the winner of a much needed get away.

If you or someone you know is interested in this fabulous treat, go check out her blog listed above. Good luck! Enjoy - and Thanks!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Love. Love. Love.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/14/love-love-love/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 14 Feb 2013 16:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1359</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/candyhearts.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1360" alt="CandyHearts" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/candyhearts.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="438" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Love. Love. Love.

Quick! Run to the nearest mirror and look deep into your eyes. Say out loud, âI Love You Unconditionally!â Not âI love you when you have make-up onâ or âI love you when you have your act together.â I love you now. I love you always. Bald, gray faced, sad or mad; worn out caregiver.

If itâs hard for you, do it three times a day. Each time, say it three times (a total of nine times a day.) Use your name, and include the word âunconditionally.â

If youâre not sure you believe it, <i>ask</i> yourself to believe it. Say<i> </i>out loud, âHelp me<i> </i>to feel as loved as I truly am.â Youâll be amazed what unfolds during your day. You may get a much needed phone call, a gift, a card, a kind stranger. Expect love to show up. Accept it when it does.

You <i>are</i> loved.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Dry Mouth During Cancer  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/18/dry-mouth-during-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 18 Feb 2013 16:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1362</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/hobbes.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1363" alt="hobbes" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/hobbes.jpg" width="280" height="180" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Lots of people in treatment for cancer are affected by dry mouth. Sometimes, dry mouth can last beyond the end of treatment. The medical term is <i>xerostomia</i>, from the Greek words <i>xeros</i> (dry) and <i>stoma</i> (mouth). Dry mouth happens when the mouth tissues dry out due to a lack of saliva. Salivaâs important because it reduces the germ level in the mouth, helps cleanse the mouth, removes food debris and maintains health of the tissues lining the mouth. All of these functions help prevent cavities, too.

If dry mouth becomes severe, people can develop chewing, swallowing, tasting and talking problems. Itâs most common in patients whoâve been treated with radiation for head and neck cancer.

Some symptoms of dry mouth include:
<ul>
	<li>Mouth sores, where you get little white or red spots in the mouth.</li>
	<li>Increased mouth sensitivity. Your mouth may hurt, especially while eating.</li>
	<li>A change in taste. You may have a âfunny tasteâ in your mouth.</li>
	<li>Gum soreness.</li>
	<li>Tooth decay and bad breath. Saliva helps prevent these, so use mouth moisturizers, or medication that make up for lost saliva.</li>
	<li>Difficulty swallowing. Dry or crumbly foods may be especially difficult.</li>
</ul>
Whatever your cause, tell your doctor if youâve begun to experience dry mouth.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Keeping Your Mouth Healthy</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/21/keeping-your-mouth-healthy/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 21 Feb 2013 16:00:52 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1366</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/keep_healthy_mouth.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1367" alt="keep_healthy_mouth" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/keep_healthy_mouth.jpg" width="300" height="228" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Cancer treatment can be rough on your body, including a side effect of dry mouth. The very best thing you can do is take steps to prevent and reduce dry mouth as much as possible. Here are some tips for managing dry mouth, and mouth sores:

If you can, see your dentist before cancer treatment begins, especially for a cleaning and fluoride treatment to help avoid cavities. After treatment, see your dentist on a regular basis. Tell your dentist when youâll begin treatment, and what type of treatment (chemo, radiation) youâll have. If you wear dentures, see your prosthodontist for issues related to proper fitting.

Avoid tobacco, alcohol, and products like most mouth washes that contain alcohol. (Biotene is an alcohol-free mouthwash made especially for dry mouth. They also make a mouth moistening gel.)

Use a soft bristle toothbrush. Run the bristle under hot water to make them even softer. Make sure youâre changing your toothbrush every three months, or if it falls on the floor, touches something dirty, etc. Oral sponges may an option if your mouth is extra sensitive.

Floss, but do it gently.

Drink plenty of fluids.Â  Water is best. Avoid all types of carbonated drinks. If you drink fruit juice, water it down. During mouth sores, the juice may be too intense, and by watering it down, it will be easier on your mouth, and better for your teeth. Sip drinks throughout the day. Fluids are extremely important not only for dry mouth, but for any cancer treatment. Theyâve done the job, now flush them out of your system.

Rinse your mouth out several times a day with one-quarter teaspoon of baking soda and one-eighth teaspoon of salt dissolved in one cup of warm water. In the midst of mouth sores, I did this every hour, and took medicated mouthwash three or four times a day. My mouth sores where minor, and gone relatively quickly. I caught them right awayâwhen I thought they <i>may</i> be mouth sores, but not sure. .Â  . . I called my oncologist and immediately began taking prescribed mouthwash, and rinsing with baking soda, salt and warm water.

Avoid breathing through your mouth. It dries out the mouth. Breath through your nose if you can.

Talk to your doctor about a zinc supplement. If you have a funny taste in your mouth, zinc may help. Ask your doctor first, to make sure it doesnât interfere with your treatment.

For more on Dry mouth, see the post: <a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/18/dry-mouth-during-cancer/">Dry Mouth During Cancer</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>What counts as a liquid?  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/25/what-counts-as-a-liquid/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 25 Feb 2013 16:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1375</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/71397_large.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1376" alt="71397_large" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/71397_large.jpg?w=300" width="300" height="300" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Maybe before cancer you could drink eight glasses of water a day with ease. Cancer will make that harder. Youâll feel bloated, and wonât want to drink much. There may be times you decide between eating for calories and nutrients versus drinking for hydration.

My medical team pushed liquids. It wasnât about drinking, but about getting hydration into my body. The purpose was not only to maintain health, but to flush out the chemo and radiation once it does itâs job. (Itâs done its job as soon as that treatment is over that day.)

Liquids arenât just drinkable. They include things like:

Pudding, jell-o, tapioca, popsicles, apple sauce, yogurt, cottage cheese, ice cream and soup. Juice, tea, and coffee are obviously liquids, but water down your juice to lessen the amount of sugar, and talk with your doctor about drinking coffee or tea. I was asked to avoid tea, especially herbal tea. I donât drink coffee, so that wasnât an issue for me. I know Iâm in the minority on that one. Drinks with caffeine, and other heated drinksâeven water donât hydrate the body as well. If you fill-up easily, these drinks donât serve you at this time. Spend your efforts hydrating your body.

Having said this, I had most of my treatment in the Summer. Even when I got cold, I could, for the most part, go outside to warm up. If youâre cold and a warm cup of something satisfies you, consider a cup of hot Ovaltine (made with water or milk) instead of hot-coco. That way, youâre at least getting some vitamins, and no caffeine. Talk it over with your doctor.

Another way to warm up and get your liquid count is by having a bowl of soup. Iâd eat split-pea soup a few days before my chemo to get my blood-cell count up so I wouldnât have to postpone any treatments.

Donât let feeling bloated get in the way of obtaining liquids. Eat and drink slowly. Eat and drink a little bit, but frequently. Eat and drink things that count as liquids and also provide some nutrients. Just a note about the straw. . ..Using a straw, you may drink more than you thinkâgetting full later. If you use a straw, sip. Crazy-Straws aren't known for inducing that!

&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>Dry Mouth, Trouble Swallowing</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/28/dry-mouth-trouble-swallowing/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 28 Feb 2013 16:00:09 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1393</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/sword-swallow.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1394" alt="sword swallow" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/sword-swallow.jpg?w=389" width="389" height="584" /></a>image credit: Good Search

By having a healthy diet during cancer treatment, you can help avoid getting sick, or getting infections. By staying healthy, your treatments can come to closure without interruption.

If you have dry mouth, especially if youâre having trouble swallowing, youâll need to temporarily modify your diet to make foods easier to eat. Eat soft, moist foods such as Cream of Rice, or Cream of Wheat rather than toast or dry cereal. Eggs or soup will be easy on the mouth, but make sure theyâre not hot. Your mouth will be extra-sensitive. Smoothies (add yogurt, milk, or ice cream for protein and calcium.) Canned fruits and vegetables may be easier on the mouth than most fresh fruits or vegetables. Canned peaches were my favorite at this stage.

Youâll notice dry, crumbly foods like crackers, pop corn drop off your desire-list. If you do have dry foods, moisten them with a dip or sauce, but ones that arenât spicy.

During this stage, you may also find foods like rice, or couscous are difficult to eat, and may induce gagging, coughing, even choking. The pieces are too small for now. Itâs a great excuse to have some mashed potatoes instead!

Spices and salt may irritate your mouth. During this stage, I gave up yogurt. It stung when I ate it, so I switched to apple sauce.

If you need to, blend your food to make it easier to swallow. I even ate baby food, and Jr. baby food for a few weeks. For me, living alone and low on energy, a jar to snack on during the day was easier than blending something, and cleaning it up.

Chew sugar-free gum sweetened with xylitol. Doing this between meals will help keep your mouth moist, and the xylitol found in sugar-free gum and candy can even help stimulate saliva production (which is what is missing when you have dry-mouth).

Dip cookies in your drink to soften them, and have treats like pudding, or ice cream rather than cakes.

Try a meal or snack of Boost, Ensure, Carnation Instant Breakfast type drinks. Have someone look around and read the labels for you. Name brands can be twice the price for the same product, or in some cases have more sugarâall other things being equal.

Keep your medical team informed with your situationâease and difficulty of eating, swallowing, and let them know what you are and arenât able to currently eat.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Meals for the Caregiver</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/04/meals-for-the-caregiver/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 04 Mar 2013 16:00:09 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1400</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/bringing-food.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1401" alt="bringing-food" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/bringing-food.jpg" width="180" height="240" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Are you a caregiver who's tired? In a hurry? Don't have an idea for dinner tonight? Or, maybe you want to bring a meal to a caregiver and want an easy, inexpensive idea that will make your dinner as well as theirs.

Last week I bought a pre-cooked whole chicken from the store. I took the meat off, put the bones aside for soup. I had some of the chicken for dinner, then I shredded the left over chicken. The next day I made enchiladas with most of the shredded meat. I made them the super easy wayâlike a lasagna, layering ingredients: corn tortillas, chicken, and just enough enchilada sauce to cover each layer. Sprinkle shredded cheese (go easy) and if you want, include in layers some sautÃ©ed onion (in a tiny bit of olive oil). I serve the enchiladas with plain yogurt rather than sour cream. Make sure top layer of tortillas is covered with sauce or foil, or theyâll dry out. Cook about 25 mins at 350. Start cleaning up, then begin to make the rice and a green salad on the side! Itâll all be done in perfect timing. During cancer treatment, this may not be a meal you enjoy. It may be something to enjoy after, or if youâre a caretaker and want a quick, easy meal for you or others who may drop by. It freezes well.

You're putting lots of your time and energy Â into helping someone else get healthy again. Even when you're tired, try to keep <em>your</em>Â lifestyle healthy with eating habits and getting plenty of sleep, too. If you can't do it on your own, ask for help. People will be happy you asked, and you can even suggest an easy, healthy recipe.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Easy Changes to Your Daily Routine </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/07/easy-changes-to-your-daily-routine/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 07 Mar 2013 16:00:20 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1405</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/sign_sameoldway.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1406" alt="sign_sameoldway" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/sign_sameoldway.jpg" width="440" height="282" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

By making a few changes in your daily routine, you can reduce your risk for developing cancer. Here are some guidelines for cancer prevention, or for getting (back) into a healthy lifestyle after cancer:
<ul>
	<li>Look at your plate. Are most of the food plat based? Try to have 75% of fruits/vegetables and grains, and 25% or less animal protein. Check the American Institute for Cancer ResearchÂ  <a href="http://www.aicr.org">www.aicr.org</a> for the New American Plate program.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Being fit doesnât mean you have to run marathons. ButÂ walk, dance, cycle, garden. <i>Move</i> your body.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Burn more calories than you take in if your goal is to lose weight. Even a loss of 10% of your weight can have a healthy effect on your body.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If you want to lose weight, use common sense. Avoid diets. Donât starve yourself. When you do skip meals, you actually train your body to hang on to itâs weight, because youâve become an unreliable source. So your body says, âHey, man, Iâm holding on to this food, because I donât know when this person is going to feed me again!â By focusing on healthy eating, you focus on health rather than what you <i>canât</i> have, and you learn to have healthy food around rather than having to use your will power around junk at home. Focus on the pleasure of eating, rather than the fastâgulpâ now back to work meal. Make the atmosphere enjoyable. Clear off the table. Light a candle. Sit down. Turn off the news. Listen to nice music, have a nice conversation or practice a silence meditation while eating.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If you're not in the habit of reading food labels, it's a healthy habit to begin. Look at the serving size and how many servings are in the product. If a bag of chips lists about five chips as a serving, can you stop at five chips? I recently sat down with a bag of popcorn. Curious, and almost finished with the bag, I turned it over and noticed what I considered my personal bag of popcorn contained <em>three</em> servings! Another part to pay attention to on labels is the fat content. If the calories from fat are more than one-third, put it down and step away (or at least know on a conscious level the choice you're making.) If it's a treat, it's not the end of the world. It's when that "treat" happens often that a bad habit is being formed. Form a good one!</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Variety is key. Learn to cook an updated casserole, lessening the salt, or meat. Casseroles are easy to make, and you can put leftovers aside in the freezer. These are meals you can take out of the freezer in the morning, put them in the refrigerator and when you come home from work, heat them up. Add a side salad, fruit or vegetable, and maybe some rice or bread on the side.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Watch your portions. It may help to use a smaller plate. (Itâs a visual trick; we tend to fill a plate no matter what the size.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Go easy on sugary drinks and alcohol. They both have lots of calories. Iâve know people who cut out only wine from their daily habit, and they lost the weight they wanted. Outside of weight consciousness, keep alcohol to a maximum or one a day for women and two a day for men.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Add some raisins or fruit to your cereal or oatmeal in the morning.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Limit your salt intake.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If you smoke or chew tobacco, stop.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Preventing Cancer Through Diet</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/11/preventing-cancer-through-diet/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 11 Mar 2013 15:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1409</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/healthy_food.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1410" alt="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/healthy_food.jpg" width="442" height="332" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

According to the American Cancer Society, nearly one-third of cancers are preventable through healthy dietary choices and regular exercise. Thatâs not an excuse to beat yourselfâor othersâup, but it is a good reason to get healthy habits into place.

Eating healthy doesnât mean you have to eat organic, or make every single thing from scratch. It does mean taking responsibility for what and how you eat.

Elissa Epel, PhD, is an associate professor in the department of psychiatry at U.C. San Francisco, and sheâs also the director of the aging, metabolism and emotions lab. She says, âItâs about making wise decisions because weâre not eating mindlessly, which is our usual default mode.â With colleagues Jean Kristeller PhD, founder of the mindfulness-based eating awareness training program, and Jennifer J. Daubenmier, PhD, Ddr. Epel studied chronically stressed, overweight and obese women. Half were assigned to mindful training and practice.

This training was nine weeks and the trail group learned how to reduce stress, and become more aware of theÂ eating experience by recognizing hunger, fullness and satisfaction. Think of that. Do you recognize when youâre hungry? Or all of a sudden you feel famished, and scarf down food until youâre stuffed. If we recognize that, <i>hmmmm, I feel hungry </i>feeling and recognize the sensation of fullness (versus stuffed) weâre well on our way to weight control. The other part of it is being in tune with taste and satisfaction.

The women in the nine week trial were trained to notice when they were angry, for instance.âAnd not automatically react based on habit to reach for food, even candy. In just a few weeks of being mindful, real changes took take place in the weight of these women.

For more on healthy eating, and mindful eating, check the next post. Iâve just had breakfast and am on a roll... (Sesame seed?)

Here's the link to a food website I really like:Â <a title="Food Hippie" href="http://www.foodhippie.com/mindful/">Food Hippie</a>

<item>
  <title>Mindful Eating on Day of Pi (3.14)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/14/mindful-eating-on-day-of-pi-3-14/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 14 Mar 2013 12:00:02 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1412</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&amp;v=qsjrjPquqiA]

Today is March 14. (3.14) Happy pi day! Eat responsibly.

Life long healthy habit building. The key is making the effort to pay attention everyday when we eat. Before you eat, check-in with yourself about your level of hunger. Eat mindfully, even if you remember half way through the meal. Better yet, post a note. Pause before eating, whether itâs for prayer, one minute meditation, or to take a breath and lower your shoulders.

Stop forÂ a moment â

We become aware of whatâs around us. We make better choices. (One reason of many why I dislike/ <i>hate</i>? - stores with loud music. It invades my space, my thinking, my peace. Which means I must be even more vigilant to stay on task to be true to my body, my wallet.)

By eating mindfully, we change the way we eat. That changes our eating experience. We eat more slowly. If we partake in a silent meal, we may feel more connected to those around us. Or, if we talk during the meal, the experience may become more social, rather than just, âPass the ketchup, please.â

Before eating, turn off the TV, computer or other electronic devises. Allow your body peace so it can digest the food youâve chosen to ingest. Be at one with the food that supports your existence.

Whatâs your environment like? Itâs hard to have candles and flowers at the table at work for your lunch, but you can get up from the place associated with work, and go into a place as a respite. You can eat under a tree with a view, or go to your car, taking mindfulness with you. At home, clear off the table, set the atmosphere of peace.

Prepare your meals for all senses. Itâs a big enough leap for some to slow down and taste their food, and now Iâm saying to include other senses? Yes. What does it look like? Smell like? I donât mean grease, I mean fresh, fruit or vegetables, warm bread, cold salad... Whatâs the aroma and whatâs the texture? Itâs part of being mindful. If your plate has a variety of colors and textures, itâs a fair bet itâs a balanced meal.

Pay attention to how you feel before and during eating as well as how hungry you are before and as you eat. Notice when you start to feel satisfied with the amount youâve eaten.

If youâre a fast eater, make yourself chew each bite 25-30 times. It will slow you down, for sure! It will also aide digestion.

Use smaller plates. It gives the illusion of being a larger portion. If you make desserts, put them in small cups/bowls. Iâve even heard of using espresso cups. Or, have fruit, seconds on the green salad, or skip dessert unless itâs a special occasion.

American Cancer Society states nearly one-third of cancers are preventable through healthy dietary choices, and regular exercise. Did you know if you eat fatty foods, youâll have a harder time resisting them in the future? Just by limiting your exposure to fats, youâre helping your mindful, healthy choices turn into life long healthy habits. Our society has forgotten that some foods are for <i>special</i> occasions, and eating those foods in moderation add delight to the occasion. Many people have misconstrued âhealthy eatingâ as âpunishmentâ, or âdenying themselvesâ from their good.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Why volunteer for a clinical trial?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/18/why-volunteer-for-a-clinical-trial/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 18 Mar 2013 15:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1420</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/zellweger_syndrome-3.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1421" alt="clinical trial" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/zellweger_syndrome-3.jpeg?w=584" width="584" height="321" /></a>image credit: Good Search

For many cancer patients, taking part in a clinical trial is a way to contribute to cancer research, and receive some hope for their own improvedÂ treatment of cancer. Despite advances made, there is no cure for cancer. Not yet, anyway.

Many clinical trials aim to increase longevity of the patient, while others focus on the patientâs quality of life, lessening side effects of cancer or its treatment. Some trials can offer state of the art, cutting edge care that if successful, wonât be available for several years down the road.

A clinical trial is a structured research study with human volunteers. These volunteers take and evaluate a new drug or treatment before that drug or treatment can be offered to the general public. According to the National Institute of Health, more than 56,000 clinical trials are currently underway in the U.S., and<a title="clinical trail volunteers" href="http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials"> 13,000 trials are recruiting volunteers.</a>

After approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, there are three steps to clinical trials:
<ol>
	<li>Volunteers test the drug, treatment or product safety.</li>
	<li>Volunteers test the drug, treatment or product efficiency.</li>
	<li>Volunteers test the drug, treatment or product effectiveness. This is the most complicated of all the steps in a trial. This is the stage where dosages, populations, and standard of care are compared.</li>
</ol>
If the drug is approved and marketed by the FDA (Food and Drug Administration), a fourth stage may occur to test long-term use of the drug, treatment or product.

<strong>Â Why volunteer for a clinical trial?</strong>

When treatment for your cancer or other disease isnât promising, or when treatment for a rare disease isnât known, or ifÂ you want to contribute to research.

<strong>Where to find possible clinical trials searching for volunteers:</strong>

<a title="National Institue of Health website" href="http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials">National Institute of Health</a>

<a title="Leukemia &amp; Lymphoma Society website" href="http://www.lls.org">Leukemia &amp; Lymphoma Society </a><a href="http://www.lls.org">
</a>

Many hospital or clinic websites also list clinical trials. Or ask your oncologist. (But keep in mind they or may not know of clinical trials outside their hospital.)

Not all drugs, treatments or products tested are approved by the FDA, and not all patients in the clinical trial receive the new drug, treatment or product. But even the volunteers receiving standard care (as opposed to testing) are monitored, perhaps even rigorously, to compare with the clinical trial.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

<item>
  <title>Caregiving can be Stressful</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/21/caregiving-can-be-stressful/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 21 Mar 2013 15:00:29 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1429</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/stress-zebrastripes-240x300.gif"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1427" alt="stress-zebrastripes-240x300" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/stress-zebrastripes-240x300.gif" width="240" height="300" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

You love them, so you take on the role as caregiver. As visitors leave, they tell you, the caregiver, to take care of yourself. Here are some tips how:
<ul>
	<li>Make all-in-one meals. Stew, soup with meat, beans and vegetables, casseroles. Crock pot meals, where you can dump things into the crock pot, and come back later to eat, and put the rest in serving size freezer containers. When others ask how they can help you, request them to make a simple meal for you to freeze in to portions. Chances are, the person youâre taking care of isnât eating the same as you, and youâre more likely to make sure they have their needs met than your own.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>I recently gave a training on stress in the workplace. I was amazed how many individuals had never meditated. Based on that finding, we did a one-minute meditation. If you can give yourselfÂ <i>one</i>Â minute. Pick a quiet time. Maybe the person youâre caring for is sleeping. Maybe youâve arrived to an appointment early. If the other person is open to it, invite them to join you in silenceÂ  Â  in the car before you go into the appointment. If theyâre not likely to support you, do it aloneâeven in the bathroom if needed! Just close your eyes and breathe in, and out. Lower your shoulders. Feel your face muscles relax. Your mind will wander, gently bring it back to your breath.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If you do the one minute with ease and want do get more into meditation, move up to five minutes, ten, or twenty. According to UCLA researchers, twelve minutes of daily meditation can improve mental health of family caregivers. The study used chanting yoga (Kirtan Kriya) everyday for eight weeks and saw 50% improvement on a depression-rating scale. Meditation has been known to increase telomerase activity, which slows cellular aging.</li>
</ul>
This is one of my favorite meditation videos.

[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6eFFCi12v8]
<ul>
	<li>Keep your energy levels up with healthy food that you can eat on the go, if necessary. Bananas, apples, cheese sticks, nuts, crackers, raisins, hard-boiled eggs, carrots, celery with peanut butter - maybe some raisins (isnât that known as âants on a logâ?), a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. They all travel pretty well. Yes, you could grab a granola or protein bar of some type, but the sugar is quite high and true heath benefit not equal to ârealâ food.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If youâre up to your eyeballs in caregiving, maybe you need to volunteer somewhere.Â <i>WHAT</i>? Some find, volunteering - away from the person for whom they provide care, is energy-giving, not zapping. Maybe once a week at the animal shelter, or art gallery. Know your limits, and what feeds you. It may serve you to volunteer, or to meditate, or walk with a friend every day.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>I recently heard someone claim, âI have a magical bed! When I lie down on my bed, I remember all the things on my to-do-list!â Be purposeful in your aim to get a good nightâs sleep. Set yourself up for a restful sleep by having some good sleep habits. Keep distractions like TV, phone, and books in other rooms. Your body will recognize the bedroom as a place to sleep. Disturbed sleep depletes your energy and when youâre sleep deprived, anxiety sky rockets 60%. Youâve got enough going on without increasing anxiety.</li>
</ul>
<h6>Related articles</h6>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://nbclatino.com/2013/02/18/9-tips-for-caring-for-the-family-caregiver/" target="_blank">9 tips for caring for the family caregiver</a>Â (nbclatino.com)</li>
	<li><a title="caregiver" href="http://www.cultivatedcaregiver.com">http://www.cultivatedcaregiver.com</a></li>
	<li></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Second-Line Cancer Treatment  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/25/second-line-cancer-treatment/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 25 Mar 2013 15:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1438</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/options-web.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1439" alt="options-web" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/options-web.jpg" width="255" height="160" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Youâre uniqueâJust like everyone else. Sometimes a medication, or cancer treatment works for one person, but not another. Some people have several switches in medication before finding one that works for their cancer. It doesnât make the second (or third, or fourth) line treatment inferior. It just makes it different. Sort of like vanilla works better on my taste buds than chocolate, even though I know most people go for chocolate. I still go for vanilla.

Okay, thatâs not exactly cancer talk. Tamoxifen is a medication widely used by women with breast cancer. It didnât work for me (the tumors grew.) Neither did Femara (the tumors stayed the same size.) The third-line treatment, Aromasin did work (the tumors shrunk.) The side effects ofÂ  Tamoxifen and Femara were easier on my mind and body, but they didnât shrink the tumors. If Aromasin hadnât worked, I wouldâve been back to I.V. chemo for a second time. Iâm not crazy about the side effects I get. (Speaking of ice cream, if youâre on Aromasin, take lots and lots of calcium. Ice cream counts, but then go be active!)

The reason your oncologist may suggest moving you to a second-line therapy is because the first one didnât work for you. Together with your oncologist you can decide the pros and cons about making the move. You may want a more aggressive treatment, where someone else may prefer a less aggressive one thatâs easier for them to handle day-after-day.

Consider getting a second opinion. Itâs common, especially when dealing with cancer. A second opinion may help you feel more confident about the need to switch therapies, or about the second-line treatment suggested by your oncologist.

You may want to check around for clinical trials.
<ul>
	<li><a title="National Institue of Health NIH" href="http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials">National Institute of Health</a></li>
	<li><a title="leukemia &amp; Lymphoma society" href="http://www.lls.org">Leukemia &amp; Lymphoma Society</a></li>
	<li><a title="Caring4Cancer" href="http://www.Caring4Cancer.com">Caring4Cancer</a>Â then enter âclinical trialsâ</li>
</ul>
Also, ask your oncologist. They may, or may not know of trials away from the hospital/clinic where they work. Ask, but donât give up if they donât know of any.

Keep in check with your emotions. Just because one treatment didnât work, doesnât mean none of them will. Some patients say hearing treatment isnât working is harder for them to hear than hearing the original diagnosis. Acknowledge your feelings, take care of yourself, and seek support, either socially, through a cancer support group, blogs, spiritual center, or friends and family. Keep in mind, your friends and family may be grappling with what to do or say, and dealing with their own emotions. It may be an opportunity for clear, compassionate, open heart discussions, or seek a professional counselor, therapist, or your medical team, saving non-cancer topics for friends and family. Only you will know who can support you, and who canât. Youâll know by body language, tone, words and actions done, and not done...

Questions to ask your oncologist if they suggest a second-line treatment:
<ul>
	<li>How do you know my treatment isnât working?</li>
	<li>What are my options?</li>
	<li>What side effects might this new treatment cause?</li>
</ul>
You may know your treatment isnât working by the size of a tumor being larger, but ask why the switch anyway. Always ask what your options are. There may not be a magic wand near by, but usually the doctors have a âplan Bâ in their pocket. And, I recently heard âIf âplan Bâ doesnât work, there are 24 other letters in the alphabet.â There are two ways to view knowing possible side effects before they possibly happen. I take the view of tell me, so if in the middle of the night I experience a nerve-racking one, I know itâs just a side effect. Thereâve been a few big ones that really caught me off guard. I called the doctor and would find, âOh. Thatâs a really rare side effect, but yes.â Some people would rather not know. Itâs for you to decide how to approach.

Complimentary therapies are so mainstream nowÂ days, you can say you meditate, go to yoga, massage and acupuncture and no one will cock their head and cross their eyes when you walk away. Ommm.

&nbsp;

<item>
  <title>Ways to Manage Anemia  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/03/28/ways-to-manage-anemia/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 28 Mar 2013 15:00:01 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1441</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/redbloodcells.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1442" alt="RedBloodCells" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/redbloodcells.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="467" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body. When there are too few number of red blood cells to carry oxygen your body needs, itâs called <i>anemia</i>. You may feel short of breath, weak, dizzy, faint or very tired. Your heart has to work harder and you may feel your heart pounding, or beating faster than usual. Youâll most likely become anemic during chemo.

Here are some ways to manage anemia:
<ul>
	<li>Get plenty of rest. Sleep 8 hours at night <i>and</i> takes naps (1-2 hours) during the day. Itâs a bit like wearing a belt and suspenders, but by taking extra precautions, youâll come out ahead.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Stand up slowly when you get get up from sitting, and when getting up from lying down, sit a while before standing, otherwise youâll feel dizzy, and have a greater chance of losing your balance, and falling - or at very least feeling awful until dizziness calms down.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Â Prioritize activities that are important to you. Youâll be tired, so chose between doing this or doing that. Honor yourself by not piling to-do-lists, or activities up.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Accept help from others. If they offer, say, âYes! Thank you!â If they donât offer, ask. Is your childâs friend getting picked up from school by someone you know? Ask them to pick your child up, too. Who can cook? Who drives? Who can do chores, or errands for you?</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>You donât want to eat, but do, and eat for calories and protein to keep your weight up, and repair tissues damaged by treatment. Anemia can cause your red blood cells to fall so low that a transfusion is needed. Rather than that, eat foods high in iron. split pea soup, watermelon, red meat, Braunschweiger spread (liverwurst) on crackers. Some of the cravings youâll have will be way out in left field, but some of them are your body guiding you to iron, and calories. Just be cautious of calorie building that can easily form into unhealthy habits after the needÂ  to keep your weight up is gone.</li>
</ul>
A link to <a href="http://www.whatisanemia.info/">more info on anemia</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Commit to lasting health</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/01/commit-to-lasting-health/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 01 Apr 2013 15:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1446</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dump-the-diet.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1447" alt="dump-the-diet" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/dump-the-diet.jpg" width="191" height="263" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

When it comes to food, commit to lasting health. The word âdietâ tends to evoke thoughts of food restriction. Almost immediately cravings and a sense of loss set in. With most diets, temporary desired results (weight loss) may be evident, but so may increased hunger and poor health habits. (What happens when you go off the chocolate brownie flavored weight loss shake?) Or, maybe you've sworn yourself to small plates of salads for lunch after skipping breakfast. You're temporarily starving yourself rather than overeating. Itâs a matter of time before you return to previous eating patterns.Â What about common sense, good-for-you eating habits?

If youâre seeing a doctor, run it by them. This is my take:
<ul>
	<li><b>Dump the diet</b>. Pick-up lifestyle changes. Itâs not new information, but information seemingly put aside in favor of restaurants and processed meals. The non-diet is all about changes thatâll lead to lifelong healthy habits, and ultimately improvements.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Skip the scale</b>. Itâs not about the amount you need to lose. Itâs about forming healthy, lasting habits. This includes eating mindfully. It doesnât mean you have to eat rare or organic foods. Eating healthy doesnât have to be a hassle.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Move it. </b>This doesnât mean you have to run a race, or walk The Walk. If you donât have weights at home, pick up two soup cans, or bags of flour, or potatoes. Find a weight you can lift with some challenge, and use it. Weights are good for bone health and muscle-building. Get some cardio activity in your life. Donât have a dog? Maybe your friend or neighbor does. Go with them on a walk. Hike, bike, swim. Get your heart talking happy-talk to you. Itâll help build your endurance and lung capacity.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Focus on your health â not the lack of it</b>. When you focus on healthy physical, mental and spiritual care of your body, your body feels it and responds. Think, âwhat can I do?â versus âwhat must I decrease?â or âwhat do I have to give up?â If you think, âI need to give up fats, sugars and alcoholâ youâll feel deprived, and it becomes a diet, not a lifestyle â and it wonât last. Instead, pay attention to adding healthy aspects into your life. Drinking more water. If you donât like plain water, add a bit of lemon, or cucumber, or a sprig of mint. Focus on attaining five servings of fruits and vegetables a day. Think of the variety of fruits and vegetables there are to eat! If you donât like a certain food, thatâs fineâfind another one, or another way to prepare it. Try something new. Talk to people about easy ways to prepare it.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Eat</b> <b>slowly</b>. Chew. Chew. Chew. Mellow out. Eating isnât a race. Give your body a treat to experience the meal.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Love yourself unconditionally</b>. Many people are overweight because theyâre trying to hide an aspect of themselves. Appreciate your body! It does wildly amazing things for you. Breathing, heart beat, eyes blinking, eyelashes, nose and ear hairs to help keep dirt out. Taste buds! Glorious taste buds.</li>
</ul>
Commit to changing from diets to lasting health. Donât try to do-it-all at once. Get good in one area, when it becomes a habit, add another aspect.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Four Quick Cancer Facts</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/04/four-quick-cancer-facts/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 04 Apr 2013 15:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1454</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li>More than 1.5 million Americans will be diagnosed with some time of cancer this year.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>According to stats from <a title="ACS" href="http://www.cancer.org">American Cancer Society</a>, the four most common cancers (other than skin) are breast, prostate, lung, and colorectal. Each year in the U.S. there are 102,480 colorectal, 288,190 lung, 238,590 prostate and over 192,000 new breast cancer diagnoses. An additional 2,000 men are diagnosed in America with breast cancer every year.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>The secrets of long-term cancer survivors are that they go to <a title="best ranking cancer hospitals" href="health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/ranking/cancer">academic medical centers</a>. They enroll in <a title="clinical trials" href="cancer.gov/clinicaltrials">clinical trials</a>. They ask about new drugs; they choose smart surgeons. (AARP, Dec/Jan 2013)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>One of every four deaths is from cancer. Every 57 seconds, someone in America dies of cancer (about 1,500 people a day.) This year 1.5 million Americans will get cancer. Almost 600,000 Americans will dieÂ of the disease. More children ages 3-14 die of cancer than of any other disease.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>four-quick-cancer-facts</wp:post_name>

<item>
  <title>What is Locks of Love?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/08/what-is-locks-of-love/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 08 Apr 2013 15:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1459</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/img_5424.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1460" alt="IMG_5424" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/img_5424.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="778" /></a>Â Photo Credit: Claudia Mulcahy

During a conversation with a co-worker in 2007, the topic of haircuts came up. I had shoulder length hair and was talking about shortening it. My co-worker asked if Iâd ever heard of Locks of Love. I looked it up and liked what I read. My main reason for deciding to grow out my hair to donate was because Iâd always loved my hair. The thickness, the texture, color, waveâeverything about it. I knew it was a gift, and one I could share.

<a title="locks of love" href="http://locksoflove.org">Locks of Love</a>Â is a non-profit organization that provides hairpiece to kids with long-term medical hair loss from any diagnosis. (<i>Note</i>: Thereâs a difference between Locks <i>of</i> Love and Locks <i>for</i> Love.) The latter one is commercial, for profit. They sell wigs from donated hair. Locks <i>of</i> Love donates them.

In 2008, I donated the minimum length: ten inches. My hair was THICK. It had to be cut in pigtails because a ponytail was too hard for my stylist to cut through.

2009: I was diagnosed with cancer. It made me realize what a gift my hair donation had been. After my cancer treatment, when my hair grew back, it came in different. It grew ever so slowly. It was thin, fine, and straight. It took three years to have a spare ten inches, having only two trimmings for haircuts.

Last week I donated another ten inches to Locks of Love. For me, my hair donations were like bookends for my journey of cancer. My haircut came a week before my last* surgery. (Iâve written âlast surgeryâ beforeâthis time itâs for real. Maybe more in an upcoming post...) I saw this haircut as closure for me. I even teared up when the skinny ponytail was off with just a snip-snip. My emotion wasnât about the haircut. It was the sound and speed of it happening that made me realize the long hair days are overâand so is cancer.

If you have long hair, if you know of someoneâmale or female, please consider donating at least ten inches of your hair to <a title="locks of love" href="http://locksoflove.org">Locks of Love</a>. The requirements and directions are on their website. Be sure to follow them.

Thanks!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Garden Your Way to Health  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/11/garden-your-way-to-health/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 11 Apr 2013 15:00:14 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1464</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/158919187.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1466" alt="kidsgarden" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/158919187.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="328" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Remember planting a seed in a cup as a kid? I took an immediate liking to radishes. They grew so fast, I could see the results of my attention and effort of watering the soil and making sure it had âgood lightâ.

Energy flows where our attention goes. As an adult, my radish success wasnât as memorable. Iâd toss the seeds on the soil, not paying much attention to how deep in the soil, or if their location in the garden was sunny enough. Water. Donât forget to water. Even when you donât see green leaves spout up a week later. And no matter how much you like a full-sun plant, if all you have is shade, it's not going to grow in there. (Thus my plethora of fern!)

When I knew I was going to have chemo, I got rid of any plants that didnât look healthy. I had no intention to have a reminder of frailty or death. I quickly learned I wouldnât have the energy to spare on needy plants or people. If Iâd had kids, I think I wouldâve encouraged them to have a garden during my chemo. For the same reasons I didnât want to tend to one, Iâd promote it for kids having a parent or friend going through cancer. If theyâre interested, that is. It can double as a way to teach good nutrition, cooking, and a chance to get in the dirt and play all while having an exchange of positive, life-force energy of nature.

If children around you can get excited about cherry tomatoes, theyâll eat more of them. Depending on how interested and involved your young charge gets, they can sit down with you and a seed catalog, look on-line, or make a trip to the garden center to see what seeds are in season. They may get involved with planting, weeding, and harvesting. Even a big planting pot can be their garden to tend. This may be your opportunity to have them try something new. Even if theyâre picky, if it came from their garden, they just may eat it! Or, maybe itâs a garden of wonderful smells or textures.

The opportunity for kids to garden brings their focus to lifeânot your wilting, or drooping. Their garden may also remind you to drink more water, or to eat fruits and vegetables. Depending on their age, the garden may need little of your oversight. If they offer you some of their harvest, accept the gift of life, the gift of love. Hereâs to your health and well-being.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Berries and Cancer Prevention </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/15/berries-and-cancer-prevention/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 15 Apr 2013 15:00:20 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1473</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/blackberry_cluster.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1474" alt="Blackberry_Cluster" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/blackberry_cluster.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="596" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Berries contain polyphenols. There are two polyphenols especially important to cancer studies in that these two compounds work together. Theyâre anthocyanins, a flavonoid that gives berries their awesome color, and ellagitannins, the source of ellagic acid.

Weâre aware berries are high in manganese, fiber, vitamin C and antioxidantsâwhich prevents cell damage that precedes cancer. Whatâs new is that berries are now found to affect the genes associated with inflammation and cancer growth.

Dr. Gary Stoner is a professor at Medical College of Wisconsin. For more than 20 years, heâs been studying berries and their potential to prevent cancer. In one study, he found a diet of black raspberries or strawberries freeze-dried and ground into a powder could inhibit esophageal cancer in rats 30-70 percent, and colon cancer up to 80 percent.

In another study, Dr. Gary Stoner worked with patients diagnosed with an inherited condition that increases their risk for colon cancer. Patients were given black raspberry powder mixed with water to drink, and in the form of rectal suppositories for nine months. This study found a thirty-six percent regression of rectal polyps in these patients. (This just begs me to add: Consult your doctor and donât try this at home.)

Blueberries, blackberries and the effects on estrogen-positive breast tumors were the focus of studies done by Dr. Harini Aiyer, a post doctoral research fellow at Lombardi Cancer Center, Georgetown University School of Medicine.

A six month diet of black raspberries reduced breast tumor volume in rats seventy percent. Blueberries reduced tumor volume by sixty percent during a six-month period.

In Dr. Aiyerâs cell culture studies, she found that adding ellagic acid to estrogen-positive cells treated with tamoxifen made the cells less likely to become resistant to the effects of the drug. This makes it seem like ellagic acid (the berries used) act like anti-estrogen. Many more studies are needed for this.

A few things to keep in mind: The studies look promising. Youâre supposed to eat plenty of fruit anyway. Fresh, unsweetened frozen or canned berries are all good choices. Donât forego other healthy food groups for a diet of berries only, and you may want to mix berry types to get that cross-training feeling.

Link:Â <a title="berries and cancer prevention" href="http://www.aicr.org">American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR)</a>]]></content:encoded>
