<item>
  <title>Tips for Cancer-Prevention Dining  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/18/tips-for-cancer-prevention-dining/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 18 Apr 2013 15:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1491</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/healthy_dining_medium.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1492" alt="healthy_dining_medium" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/healthy_dining_medium.jpg" width="300" height="274" /></a>image credit: Good Search

I make fish tacos at home and love them. I tend to use bass, halibut or cod with lots of shredded cabbage, some hot sauce and a blop of plain yogurt wrapped in flat bread. Recently, I was taken to a Mexican restaurant for brunch. I ordered the fish taco combo. What a surprise when a <i>huge</i> deep-fried pice of fish took up most of my plate. âDeep friedâ hadnât even crossed my mind, and it wasnât written up in the menu as such. I scraped away the breaded shell until discovering a <i>tiny</i> piece of fish.

Iâm conscious of what, and how much I eat. Here are some healthy tips you may want to consider before eating out, where it can be more difficult to keep things in moderation.
<ul>
	<li>Drink a glass of low-sodium vegetable juice before starting your meal (or before you leave for the restaurant.) Itâs healthy, and will fill you up a bi</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>When you have something like ice cream, an alcoholic beverage or a deep-fried item, âtrade offâ by passing the bread, chips, or mashed potatoes.Â  (Or, if youâre like me, youâll skip the ice cream and alcohol so I can have my carbs in peace.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Eat the good-for-you-stuff. I must admit, I do not like restaurant veggies, but I do still eat them, as small as the portion of them is. Theyâre over cooked, sitting in butter, and they just donât taste right. Iâve heard some restaurants add sugar to them. Iâll usually eat an apple before going to a restaurant. (Thatâs one of those âtrade-offsâ mentioned above.) Other ways to eat the good stuff is to look for dishes with fruit, whole grains, lean proteins. Some include fish, chicken, tofu, cottage cheese and beans. Beware, many restaurants, especially Mexican use lard in their refried beans, and some other beans are high in calories. No need to be paranoid, just be conscious of your choices.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Share your meal, or take half of it home. NO BODY needs an 18 oz piece of steak, or fish for that matter. Three ounces of protein a meal is what you need.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Skip the appetizer, or share it. Or, make it your meal with a salad or soup.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>If the menu lists the calorie and fat count, read it. Fat from calories shouldnât be more than one-third of the total calorie count. If calories per serving are 300, fat from calories should be less than 100. Here are some numbers from the <a title="Am Inst for Cancer Research" href="www.aicr.org ">American Institute for Cancer research</a> (AICR).Â Aim for your meal to be 400-500 calories.Â  (If you Supersize your meal at one of those take-out places, youâre almost at your entire daily calorie count of 2,000!) In general, avoid trans fat. Keep saturated fat to 20 grams or less a day, or at least aim for low numbers. Sodium should be kept to 600 milligrams or less per meal. (I find this per meal number high.) Fiber: do you get 25 grams per day? Most people donât.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Eat slowly. Chew your food. Chew, then talk; not both at the same time. If the music is loud or fast, youâll have to be more aware of your eating pace.</li>
</ul>
These are just a few of many tips you can incorporate into a healthy, cancer-preventative, social lifestyle.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>After Another Surgery</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/22/after-another-surgery/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 22 Apr 2013 15:00:08 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1495</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/gummy_bear_surgery_05.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1496" alt="gummy_bear_surgery_05" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/gummy_bear_surgery_05.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="523" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

&nbsp;

Well, here I am again. Recovering from another surgery. This makes it seven. Iâve said, âDoneâ so many times, that this time I felt more comfortableâif only to side-step a jinx to leave surgery-recovery as quietly as I could, drugged up and dry-heaving.

&nbsp;

Stage four, no evidence of disease. Thatâs a celebration in itself. Six months ago I had the much talked-up newly FDA approved gummy bear implants. After that surgery, I was much larger than I wanted, and I hurt far more than after other reconstruction surgeries. The pain after the much touted gummy bear implants was unbelievable. I cried from slightly shifting my body, or breathing deeply. I couldnât stand up straight. The implants where too heavy for me, and pulled my back muscle to the extent of being given muscle relaxers. In addition to being in pain,Â my posture was slantedâwhich I found horrifying, as I have great posture. I felt matronly and frumpy. Hugs hurt not only me, but the other person. It was like having two bricks in my shirt pocket. People would repel from me in shock.

&nbsp;

Enough. I didnât go through all this cancer stuff to be disappointed with my new equipment.

&nbsp;

I got a new surgeon. Our first meeting was me telling her I expected to be listened to. Our second meeting was her drawing on me, where sheâd cut. Iâm now smaller in implant size, far more comfortable, and I have the frame of a tall, thin woman with great posture again.

&nbsp;

There arenât many choices of styles and brands in breast implants, so do the best you can in communicating with your surgeon. If they say something that doesnât make sense, call them on it. I did this time and time again. Iâm not sure where my surgeon and I fell out, but I do know it was early on, and I stayed with them too long. I was told thinner women were more comfortable with this new implant. That was absolutely not true for me. I was also told the new implant wouldnât have a âstepâ appearance. (I didnât have one the implant being replaced, so it didnât mean anything to me.) With the <i>new</i> implant, I had a âstep.â I was also told the âteardropâ shape looked more natural. I hated it. âNaturalâ was code for low-hanging fruit. Doctors sometimes tell a patient, âYou know your body.ââand disregard it. I hope you have a great surgeon/patient relationship. They donât need to be your buddy, but they do need to listen to you. If youâre having communication break down with your surgeon ask the office what other surgeons there are like. Ask other patients.

&nbsp;

<strong>related post: <a title="gummy bear implants" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/24/gummy-bear-implants/">gummy bear implants</a></strong><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/09/24/gummy-bear-implants/">
</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Gene Markers for Cancer Risk </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/25/international-efforts-uncovering-signposts-in-dna/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 25 Apr 2013 15:00:01 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1527</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="300"]<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Metastasis_sites_for_common_cancers.svg" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured" title="Main sites of metastases for some common cance..." alt="Main sites of metastases for some common cance..." src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Metastasis_sites_for_common_cancers.svg/300px-Metastasis_sites_for_common_cancers.svg.png" width="300" height="481" /></a> Main sites of metastases for some common cancer types. Primary cancers are denoted by "...cancer" and their main metastasis sites are denoted by "...metastases". List of included entries and references is found on main image page in Commons: (Photo credit: Wikipedia[/caption]

In an article from March 2013, the Associated Press, Internationally, there are more than 100 institutions and 200,000 people taking part in genetic testing. Through this collaboration, dozens of signposts for disease in DNA have been found. The primary risks studied have been for breast, ovarian, and prostate cancer.

<i>What does it mean for the average person?</i>

There are genetic tests now, for instance, testing for BRCA gene mutation. If a woman tests positive, she has a higher risk for breast or ovarian cancer. These mega-collaborative studies may mean that one day there will be genetic tests that help identify a woman who has the most to gain from having a mammogram, and men whoâd benefit most from PSA tests, and prostate biopsies. And, those tests may lead to genetic hints of new treatments.

The thinking behind these studies is if a person has a 20 percent risk of a certain type of cancer in their lifetime, genetic markers could identify those at higher risk, say 60 percent, or people who exceed 80 percent from those whose risk is 20-50 percent. The difference this could bring may mean someone choses to monitor their lower risk rather than opt for surgery as a preventative method (such as women having healthy breasts removed.)

The three markers found reveal hints about the biology of these cancers, and the hope is these underpinnings will pay off as better therapies the future. As studies go, this is encouraging, but more research is needed to see how helpful this would be in guiding a patient.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1527</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2013-04-25 08:00:01</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2013-04-25 15:00:01</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>international-efforts-uncovering-signposts-in-dna</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="cancer"><![CDATA[cancer]]></category>

<item>
  <title>I dust. I shred papers. I wash laundry.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/04/29/i-dust-i-shred-papers-i-wash-laundry/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 29 Apr 2013 15:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1567</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/spring-cleaning1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1568" alt="spring-cleaning1" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/spring-cleaning1.jpg" width="400" height="494" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

Let me preface all this with, if you've got someone helping you out get ready for surgery, <em>AMEN</em>! For me, cleaning on my own is a way to keep my mind off surgery, and I count it as exercise, knowing I won't be doing much for a while. (Like lifting over ten pounds for six months.)

Stock up on food you can storeâcanned tuna or salmon, vegetable broth, pasta, canned or frozen vegetables (you wonât want to chop much.) Make things in personal serving sizes if you live alone, or if youâre bringing food over to someone who lives alone. Keep one in the refrigerator, and freeze the rest. A large container is too heavy after surgery and takes up too much freezer space, and too much time to thaw. <a title="fiber muffins" href="http://ow.ly/d4WEb">Make fiber muffins</a>Â and freeze them or get a box of Belvita breakfast bars (blueberryâs their best.)

Stock up on water if you buy in bottles, juice and something like prune juice, 7-Up, or some other taste. For me, nothing taste good for several days after surgery. Iâm more comfortable having broth and Saltine crackers (I love the fresh stack pack, packaged in smaller portions.) Drink lots of liquid, and keep food low salt, low-fat/grease. (I forgot and this time had chicken broth instead of vegetableâand it didnât stay down. it was too greasy for me.) Things like pudding or Jell-O will feel good going down your throat after surgery.

Paced over two weeks, and dog-tired at the end, the count-down for surgery and an incredibly clean house (all 600 square feet of it) begin. This last time I even re-arranged my bedroom. A deep clean never goes as quickly as planed, does it? Usually, I prepare for surgery by sticking to the normal house cleaning, keeping in mind that after surgery I may not be able to much of it for a month or more, and I enjoy clean surroundings as much as my guests do.

I dust. I shred papers. I do laundry and hand wash sweaters that have hung on a chair far too long because I couldnât be bothered to hand wash anything before. Windows and mirrors get clean. Plants get watered. Toilet paper. I stock up, and move some to a lower shelf, and in the front. As the chores check off and the calendar approaches surgery, I notice things like the floor isnât as clean as it should be, and decide to get creative. I discover things like baking soda work better than Method, or other floor cleaners that havenât done their job, even though Iâve been using them for years. One-third across the floor, Iâm exhausted, but proud of how great that floor looks! Hint: If you do this, go easy on the amount of baking soda, or you will re-do the floor with a sponge and water to pick up the grit you left behind. A clean bathroom floor only shows the outer tub/shower needing attention, and while youâre on your knees, you may as well dust behind the toilet.

Itâs not like I plow through these chores one after the next. I pace things out. Work top to bottom. Nap. Each chore triggers a thought of something else to clean. The vanity, the oven and oh, better remember to vacuumâwhich gets done three times in two days. I love those vacuum lines on the carpet! Itâs at this point I realize nerves, not necessity have stepped in-charge.

Stop. Breathe. Meditate. Pray. The eve of surgery: Allow calm. I enjoy listening to soothing instrumental music and fading in and out of meditative thoughts. Letâs be real. . . . This is also the time to eat as much as you want until midnight! Before I get ready for bed, I post my NPO signs (Nothing Per Oral, reminders not to eat or drink anything) on my water bottles, the counter and refrigerator. My very last eve of surgery ritual is to clean my kitchen sink. Wipe, wipe, wipe. Man, it sparkles!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

      <wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>

<item>
  <title>Health Coverage and Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/02/health-coverage-and-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 02 May 2013 15:00:55 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1573</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/cancer-treatment.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1574" alt="Cancer-Treatment" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/cancer-treatment.jpg" width="328" height="398" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search</p><p>I received a comment on Facebook requesting I address post-diagnosis health insurance coverage. I sat with it for bit, thinking I wasnât qualified to take it on as a blog post. Then I thought again: Yes. What about health coverage for post-diagnosis of cancer?</p><p>Before I was diagnosed, COBRA health "coverage" wouldâve cost me over $1,200. a <i>month</i> for "pre-existing" conditions <i>and</i> COBRA wouldnât have covered anything those areas of my body e.g. I had scoliosis surgery as a teen; never had back issues. COBRA excluded all back and neck coverage. I also had a radio frequency ablation for a fast heartbeat. Itâs an outpatient procedure. I left with three band aids. COBRA excluded heart coverage. To pay $1,200. a month and not have coverage for my back, neck or heart, for their health âcoverageâ was a joke.</p><p>Weâll all have to wait to see how the Affordable Health Care Act (AHCA) plays out in 2014. Something has to budge to improve our health care system in the U.S. The good news is that as of 2013 itâs illegal in U.S.A. to exclude coverage based on a pre-existing condition. The question remaining is what that coverage will cost. I spoke with someone at Medi-Cal, and they said there is nothing in writing as far as implementation of the AHCA, so no one knows how it will look. Iâve heard some doctors in favor, and others think itâs a bad move. All I know is that there are way too many people working for employers and are not covered by insurance. Health care is a human right. To live in America and lack health care is absurd.</p><p>For those who are in the cancer process without insurance, call your Social Security office, call Medicare, call American Cancer Society. Ask your doctors and nurses where you can find the hospital/clinic social worker, and if they know of organizations that can help you. If you think seeing a psychologist would help you through cancer and all it brings, ask if there are doctoral student interns, or try a support group. Even with insurance, cancer costs can skyrocket above $100,000. Itâs not that doctors provide unnecessary treatment, either. Itâs that no one knows what causes cancer, and are often working in the dark. Cancer is as individual as the people who have it.</p><p>Anyone with ideas for post-diagnosis folks, please leave a comment.Â </p><p>Thanks!</p><p>&nbsp;</p>]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Metaphysical View of Death</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/06/we-are-eternal/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 06 May 2013 15:00:18 +0000</pubDate>

  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[The metaphysical view of death is known as transition.

We are eternal. The body moves on, but there is no finality of the soul.

Here is a ten minute video from <a title="metaphysical view on death" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGUWe6VtN8E">Abraham Hicks</a> (via Esther about Jerry's transition in 2012.)

<item>
  <title>Carbs and Protein Together Help the Healing Process  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/09/carbs-and-protein-together-help-the-healing-process/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 09 May 2013 15:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1583</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/ilovefcp2.gif"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1584" alt="ilovefcp2" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/ilovefcp2.gif?w=584" width="584" height="853" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Whether youâve had an injury or surgery, your body needs to heal. You may need to stop exercising, or at least modify what you do for a while. The choices you make for food are important in the healing process. During your recovery or rehabilitation, while youâre unable to exercise, you can still avoid gaining weight and heal quickly.

It comes down to conscious decisions for healthy eating. Itâs not just a matter of watching fat and caloric intake. Along with self-control, nutrients help your body heal. Obviously, the habit of healthy eating is better to have in place before the injury or surgery. When I was first diagnosed with stage three breast cancer, I laughed when I was told, âYouâre extremely healthyâwith cancer.â I felt it was the ultimate <i>booby</i> prize. I soon understood the blessing of having a high health baseline. I never missed a chemo treatment, and when I was midway through treatment I had a few people (including a doctor in the oncology clinic) question when Iâd <i>begin</i> chemo. I wore a scarf, not a wig, so I found this question bizarre. A friend pointed out to me that I looked healthier than others theyâd seen with cancer. Whatever the reasoning, Iâm sold on having a high baseline of health.

Physical activity will decrease during the recovery period leading to decreased appetite. If some adjustment to eating doesnât happen while in recovery you may gain weight. But by negating the right nutrients and caloric intake, your body canât heal as quickly. Some people take the âopportunityâ of having an injury or surgery to eat too few calories. Â  Thatâs a huge mistake. A healthy balance is necessary.

Eat from all the food groups. They work together. Consciously graze throughout the day rather than eating only three times, but larger amounts. This is important to keep your blood sugar levels consistent and metabolism active. Also, so that when you do eat, youâre not starvingâthus gulping down any and everything, especially right before you head off to bed.

When you eat carbohydrates for energy, your body will use the protein you eat to repair your muscles. If you donât eat enough carbs, your body will burn the protein you eat for energy, and not for healing muscles. This makes it harder on your body to heal. This isnât to say load up on carbs, especially if youâre not active. Eat smaller portions of carbs and other foods high in nutrients.

After an injury or surgery, you need extra protein to help recovery. Prior to cancer, I was a near vegetarian, eating only fish and sometimes chicken. During chemo I craved roast beef and beef hot dogs. At the end of cancer treatment my oncologist told me it was very important for me to eat more protein than before cancer, and to keep eating meat.

Fats and antioxidants contain anti-inflammation properties. After an injury or surgery, the first visible response is inflammation. While itâs not a nutrient, Iâve used arnica montana 30x strength two weeks before, and one-two weeks after each surgery (seven). Swelling and bruising was almost nil in every surgery.

Vitamin C helps reduce inflammation and encourages the body to form collagen. Collagen is a needed protein for strength, flexibility and repair of tendons, ligaments and strengthens bones. Vitamin A helps with cell development, cell growth and the immune system.

&nbsp;

Carbohydrates: whole grains, pasta, breads, fruits, veggies

Protein: lean meat, fish, beans, lentils, nuts, low-fat dairy

Fats: olive oil, canola oil, nuts, avocados

Antioxidants/Fruits high in vitamin C: kiwi fruit, oranges, strawberries, broccoli, tomatoes]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>What Do Google PageRank, Viterbi Algorithm and Cancer Have in Common?  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/13/what-do-google-pagerank-viterbi-algorithm-and-cancer-have-in-common/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 13 May 2013 15:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1587</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/300px-hmm-viterbi-algorithm-med.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1588" alt="300px-Hmm-Viterbi-algorithm-med" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/300px-hmm-viterbi-algorithm-med.png" width="300" height="316" /></a>Â </b>image credit: Good Search

&nbsp;

Google PageRank algorithm. Viterbi Algorithm. Cancer. What can they possibly have in common?

Google PageRank was developed in 1996 by Larry Page, and Sergey Brin. PageRank predicts websites most likely to have pertinent information. It examines the destiny of links between websites. Thirty years earlier at Stanford University, Andrew Viterbi invented an algorithm that predicts the mostly likely path of digital wireless signals through a cellphone network.

Enter the twenty first century: Paul Newton of USCâs Viterbi School of Engineering collaborated with scientists at La Jolla-based Scripps Institute, one of 12 established by the National Cancer Institute. Several institutions took part in this study. The purpose was to understand behavior of cancer cells during metastasis (when cancer spreads from the primary tumor to other sites in the body.) The study specifically aimed to learn better ways of managing cancer. Andrew Viterbi was an advisor during this study.

The study was published in the journal of Cancer Research in March, 2013. It analyzed records of 3,827 deaths of untreated cancer patients between 1914 and 1943. One hundred sixty three were lung cancer patients. The years of these studies were before the use of radiation and chemotherapy for lung cancer. Sine the patients were untreated, their records showed the natural progression of cancer. According to American Lung Association, lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the U.S.. About 160,000 Americans die each year from lung cancer. As of nowâin general, once lung cancer becomes metastatic, few localized therapies are done. This study may change that. A follow-up study is looking to see if this is true for colon cancer as well.

The finding in the first study was that different areas in the body are âspreadersâ or âspongesâ of metastatic lung cancer cells. As their names suggest, some areasÂ spread the cancer cells, and some areas receive the cancer cells, but donât spread them as readily. So, some areas for metastasis are more dangerous than others. The study found that adrenal glands are âspreadersâ and bones metastases are âsponges.â

When someone dies from metastatic lung cancer, they have metastases in multiple areas throughout their body. But, not everyone has the metastases in the same areas. The study is taking place in hopes of gaining an understanding of pathways cancer takes.

Viterbi said, âItâs very exciting to see mathematics being applied in all sorts of ways. For decades, it was mostly in physics or physical phenomena. Now itâs being used in software and even biology. It isnât just this, it was much more effectively used in DNA sequence analysis where youâve got lots and lots of bits.â

We can often get frustrated about the lack of progress on cancer research when we read findings that in moderation, eating dark chocolate and drinking red wine are good for our healthâbut further studies are needed. Of all the news Iâve read about studies being done, this âspreader/spongeâ study is the most exciting to me. To think that itâs origin is from math and computer algorithms just amazes me.

Sources: Wikipedia; San Diego Union Tribune March 28, 2013; USC News.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

  <wp:post_date_gmt>2013-05-13 15:00:30</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>what-do-google-pagerank-viterbi-algorithm-and-cancer-have-in-common</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="spreaders-and-sponges"><![CDATA["spreaders and sponges"]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="cancer-research"><![CDATA[Cancer research]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="lung-cancer"><![CDATA[Lung cancer]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="national-cancer-institute"><![CDATA[National Cancer Institute]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="pagerank"><![CDATA[PageRank]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="paul-newton"><![CDATA[Paul Newton]]></category>
  <category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="viterbi-algorithm"><![CDATA[Viterbi Algorithm]]></category>

<item>
  <title>"But I Hate Vegetables!"</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/16/but-i-hate-vegetables/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1591</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/funny-vegetables.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1592" alt="funny-vegetables" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/funny-vegetables.jpg" width="400" height="274" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

Whenâs the last time you ate a mango? What about jicama, leeks, or kale? Having a range of vegetables in your diet is one way to ensure youâre getting a variety of nutrients. Try new vegetables, or ones you havenât tried in a while. Often, when we think we hate a certain type of food, then we find out itâs our lack of knowing how to prepare it. Have fun! Try some new foods. If you're at a loss use Google for ideas of how to prepare them, or just try it on your own!

Jicama: Slice and peel it. Squeeze lemon or lime juice over it, and sprinkle chili powder on top. Or, use the slice of jicama as you would a tortilla chip and dip it into salsa or guacamole. When jicama is cold, itâs a refreshing summer treat. Keep the slices in a bag on ice at a picnic.

Kale: With a <i>tiny</i> bit of olive oil drizzled over it and a tiny bit of kosher salt sprinkled on top, you might find you can eat a big piece of kale each day.

Brussels sprouts: Steam, microwave, roast or cut them in half and put them in a frying pan. When I roast them, I cut them lengthwise and drizzle a bit of olive oil on the pan and then some over the vegetables. Sometimes I add balsamic vinegarâsometimes not. Other vegetables on my cookie sheet might include carrots, cauliflower, sweet potato, onion, mushroomsâwhatever I have on hand. If I only have a few to cook, I cut brussels sprouts length wise and put a bit of olive oil, pepper, cayenne, or ginger, basil, on the skillet. I place the brussels sprouts flat-side down in a cast iron skillet and when they begin to brown on the flat side I turn them over and keep checking until they soften a bitÂ  (not too much!) At this point, I sprinkle a bit of kosher salt on top.

Use meat as a condiment, instead of the major part of your meals.

Add beans to soup or casseroles such as a rice, bean and tomato foundation.

If you eat cereal, add some sliced fruit. Peaches, strawberries, apples, raisins, bananas are perfect additions!

Keep in mind plate size and proportions. (And, if you eat a pound of chocolate, you may gain a pound of chocolate.) âJust sayinâ.

Walk. Hike. Run. Bicycle. Dance. Garden. Surf. Drop to the floor and do some crunches. <i>Move</i>. It doesnât have to be vigorous or take all day. You donât have to be the best one out there. This is for <i>you</i>.

<b>Related Link:Â </b><a href="http://www.nutrition-and-you.com/vegetable-nutrition.html">NutritionÂ and You</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The Origin of the Word, "Cancer"</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/20/the-origin-of-the-word-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 20 May 2013 15:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1595</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/full-hippocrates_tcm7-92835.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1596" alt="full-hippocrates_tcm7-92835" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/full-hippocrates_tcm7-92835.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="406" /></a>

image credit: Good Search

Throughout history, cancer has been recorded. Fossilized bone tumors show earliest evidence of cancer in human mummies in ancient Egypt. While the word âcancerâ wasnât used, the oldest description of cancer was discovered in Egypt, dating back to about 3000 B.C.E.. The description is in a copy of part of an ancient Egyptian textbook on trauma surgery. The textbook is called the Edwin Smith Papyrus. These papers describe eight cases of tumors or ulcers of the breast. The treatment was cauterization with what was called âThe fire drill.â The writings about the disease: âThere is no treatment.â

Greek physician Hippocrates (460-370 B.C.E.), who is considered the âFather of Medicineâ, is credited for the origin of the word âcancer.â He used the terms <i>carcinos</i> and <i>carcinoma </i>to<i> </i>describe<i> </i>all<i> </i>tumors<i>. </i>In Greek, <i>carcinos </i>and<i> carcinoma </i>refer to âcrabâ, a reference presumably applied to the disease for itâs claw-like spreading projections from the tumor, bringing to mind the shape of a crab.

The Roman physician, Celsus (28-50 B.C.E.), later translated the Greek term, <i>carcinoma </i>into <i>cancer</i>, the Latin word for crab.

Along came another Roman physician, Galen (130-200 A.D.), who used the word <i>oncos</i> (Greek for swelling) to describe tumors. The crab analogy of Hippocrates and Celsus is still used to describe malignant tumors. Galenâs term is now used as a part of the name for cancer specialists â oncologists.

<b>Cancer causes: Theories throughout history Â </b>Source:Â <a title="caner throughout the ages" href="http://www.cancer.org"><i>American</i> <i>Cancer</i> <i>Society</i></a>

From the earliest times, physicians have puzzled over the causes of cancer. Ancient Egyptians blamed cancers on the gods.

Hippocrates believed that the body had 4 <i>humors</i> (body fluids): blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile. When the humors were balanced, a person was healthy. The belief was that too much or too little of any of the humors caused disease. An excess of black bile in various body sites was thought to cause cancer.

This theory of cancer was passed on by the Romans and was embraced by the influential doctor Galenâs medical teaching, which remained the unchallenged standard through the Middle Ages for over 1,300 years. During this period, the study of the body, including autopsies, was prohibited for religious reasons, which limited progress of medical knowledge.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>FDA Approves a New Drug for Prostate Cancer  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/23/fda-approves-a-new-drug-for-prostate-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 23 May 2013 15:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1599</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/xofigo_378336.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1600" alt="xofigo_378336" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/xofigo_378336.jpg" width="320" height="320" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

The German drug companies Bayer and itâs development partner, Algeta have just received approval from US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for a prostate cancer drug. Radium-223-dichloride (Xofigo) is an injection treatment for patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer, symptomatic bone metastases and no known visceral metastatic disease.

The drug chemically binds to minerals in bone directly delivering radiation to bone tumors and limiting damage to surrounding tissues.

The downside is the adverse reactions to radium-223, which occurred in greater than ten percent of patients in trials. The reactions include: nausea, diarrhea, vomiting and peripheral edema. There were also hematologic laboratory abnormalities in greater than ten percent of patients in trials, including anemia, lymphocytopenia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia and neutropenia.

According to the Reuters report, "Xofigo is the first alpha particle-emitting radioactive therapeutic agent approved by the FDA that has demonstrated improvement in overall survival and delay in time to first symptomatic skeletal event compared to placebo, as shown in the pivotal phase III ALSYMPCA trial," the companies said.
<h6 class="zemanta-related-title" style="font-size:1em;">Related articles</h6>
<ul class="zemanta-article-ul">
	<li class="zemanta-article-ul-li"><a href="http://www.medicaldaily.com/articles/15571/20130515/xofigo-prostate-cancer-fda-drug.htm" target="_blank">Advanced Prostate Cancer Drug Xofigo Approved By FDA</a> (medicaldaily.com)</li>
</ul>

<item>
  <title>Radiation, Hair loss and the Circadian Cycle</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/05/30/radiation-hair-loss-and-the-circadian-cycle/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 30 May 2013 15:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1610</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/th.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1611" alt="th" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/th.jpeg" width="480" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

image credit: Good Search

A study by Salk Institute, recently published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that hair follicles rest during the circadian cycle. The study was preformed on mice, and showed dramatic reduction in hair loss by delivering gamma radiation when follicular cells were least rapidly dividing. During radiation and chemotherapy, the fast growing cellsâthose that rapidly divide, are the cells targeted to be killed. The problem with this is, normal rapidly dividing cells are killed along with cancerous ones, creating all sorts of unpleasant side effects like hair loss, nausea and loss of taste to name a few.

It isnât known if hair of mice and men share the similar circadian clock, but it is known that facial hair on men grows during the day, thus the 5 oâclock shadow. In a Salk news release, Satchidananda Panda, a Salk Institute researcher said, âThereâs no 5 a.m. shadow if you shave at night.â

The study stated, âThese findings parallel daily changes in sensitivity of epidermis to external UV genotoxicity and can have important implications for designing radiation therapy and possibly chemotherapy protocols. More immediately, radiation treatment can be administered during the mitotic depression phase to minimize hair loss said effect.â

Some cancers have shortened circadian cycles that would need to be factored into treatment by cancer chronotherapy. In the study, mice were given 400 -700 rads. One group received radiation during a circadian time known as CT50 (when their hair cells were most actively dividing.) The other group of mice received radiation at CT58 (when their hair cells were least actively dividing.)

The study showed a dramatic difference between the two groups. The group irradiated when their cells were actively dividing were almost completely bald. The other group maintained most of their hair. Once levels of rads increased to 600 or more, both groups of mice had nearly total hair loss, which the study suggests was caused by prolonged effects of high cytotoxic radiation levels.

A third group of mice was tested to see if circadian cycles were truly responsible for the differences. This group consisted of mutant mice whose circadian cycles had been disrupted. At 500 rads, this third group had nearly total hair loss, irrelevant of the time of day they were irradiated.

Source: U-T San Diego, May 21, 2013

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="proceedings-of-the-national-academy-of-sciences-of-the-united-states-of-america"><![CDATA[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]></category>
  <category domain="post_tag" nicename="radiation-therapy"><![CDATA[radiation therapy]]></category>

  <wp:postmeta>

    <wp:meta_value><![CDATA[23862730]]></wp:meta_value>

<item>
  <title>Ductal Carcinoma in situ (DCIS)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/03/ductal-carcinoma-in-situ-dcis/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 03 Jun 2013 15:00:23 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1613</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Nci-vol-4353-300_ductal_carcinoma_in_situ.jpg" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured" title="Shown is a drawing of a breast duct containing..." alt="Shown is a drawing of a breast duct containing..." src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Nci-vol-4353-300_ductal_carcinoma_in_situ.jpg/300px-Nci-vol-4353-300_ductal_carcinoma_in_situ.jpg" width="300" height="217" /></a> Shown is a drawing of a breast duct containing ductal carcinoma in situ. (Photo credit: Wikipedia)[/caption]

Ductal Carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is an atypical proliferation of cells in the breast duct. Itâs not a breast tumor, and itâs not invasive cancer. There are two ways to look at this: It is pre-invasive. It is non-invasive. So, it is pre-cancer?

I came across an article âFiguring out what DCIS diagnosis really meansâ, by Sue Rochman, MAMM Oct, 2000. The little I knew about DCIS, I presumed DCIS was pre-spread of cancer, and considered cancer. The one thing I am very clear on now is that there is lots of debate about DCIS.

What is agreed upon is that DCIS doesnât have the same capabilities as a tumor. It doesnât have the molecular genetics to invade and metastasize. Women with DCIS wonât necessarily progress to invasive cancerâhowever, in an overwhelming majority, women with invasive cancer also have DCIS.

If it could be determined what causes DCIS to potentially become invasive, then doctors could figure out what women require treatment, and what women donât. Since that isnât happening yet, all women with DCIS are treated. The question I have had for years, âHow much is too much treatment?â

The shift in the last twenty years has been from seeing DCIS as a single disease and if left untreated was likely to invade, to seeing DCIS as having a risk of progressing, and invading, depending on other factors. Thereâs a spectrum within the DCIS diagnosis. The DCIS shift has also moved from mastectomy to lumpectomy, followed by radiation, and sometimes an anti-estrogen therapy (such as Tamoxifen) for hormone receptor breast cancer. Some women opt for a mastectomy over a lumpectomy. Some to avoid radiation, others require a mastectomy when the area in concern is too large for a lumpectomy in order to preserve the breastâs appearance.

Barbara Brenner, the then executive director or The San Francisco based advocacy group Breast Cancer Action, spoke about, âWhatâs too much treatment?â She said, âItâs clear that some women who get surgery and being over treated for DCIS. The problem is we donât have any method to distinguish those who need treatment from those who donât. I donât think any doctor could safely tell a patient that she shouldnât be treated for DCIS. But the net result is that we are doing way more surgeries and a lot more radiation than is probably necessary.â

Dr. Silverstein of USC, adamantly argued that some women are being over treated. âLow grade DCIS doesnât come at you like a bull and not stop. Thereâs plenty of time to deal with this, and the majority of it never becomes invasive breast cancer. I believe that you can pick out patients who are not going to benefit from radiation therapy. And thatâs what the debate is all about.â

Progress has been made. Now, DCIS is technically classified as a cancer. The cells are just like invasive cancerâexcept they Â haven't spread beyond the ducts of the breast. Can you imagine having surgeryâa lumpectomy or mastectomy, having radiation, and taking medicationâand not having statistics kept, or being considered as having cancer? Now DCIS patients do fit into the category of cancer, which I hope helps them through the process of support, gathering information, and receiving the right treatment, or non-treatment to fit their needs best.

Related Posts: <a title="DCIS" href="http://mammodoctor.wordpress.com/2013/05/03/dcis-to-treat-or-not-to-treat/">DCIS To Treat or Not to Treat</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>100 Years of American Cancer Society</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/06/100-years-of-american-cancer-society/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 06 Jun 2013 15:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1651</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/happy-100th.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1652" alt="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/happy-100th.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="460" /></a>

&nbsp;

image credit: Good Search

In 1913, (<i>One</i> <i>hundred</i> <i>years</i> <i>ago</i>) a national organization dedicated to educate the public about cancer was formed. The organization was a small group of doctors and business leaders. The organization was called the American Society for the Control of Cancer. In 1945, the American Society for the Control of Cancer shortened its name to the American Cancer Society (ACS). The following year, it began its research program, with a $1 million donation from philanthropist Mary Lasker. Since 1946, ACS has raised and spent over $3.8 billion. American Cancer Society is the largest nongovernmental funder of cancer research. It has 900 local offices in every state.

One hundred years ago, a cancer diagnosis most certainly meant a death sentences. Today, there are 14 million cancer survivors in the United States. Five-year survival rates are up 20 percent from just the mid-1970âs. According to one report, five-year survival rates reached 68 percent from 2002 - 2008.

In an interview with ACSâs chief medical officer, Dr. Otis Brawley, he shares the victories of ACS, and cancer/medical areas still remaining in need of change. The first being medical coverage. âWe know that the person who has health insurance is more likely to survive tan the person without insurance. There are a whole bunch of people with cancer who end up dying because of lack of adequate care.â

One of the ACS biggest victories is seen as their anti-smoking work. In 1965, 55 percent of men smoked, and 35 percent of women. Now, the percentages are 19.5 and 16.5 respectively. In California, itâs about 10 percent. In Missouri and Kentucky itâs about 30 percent. Brawley says, âCalifornia is an example of where we can go, and Missouri and Kentucky are examples of where we have come from.â

The biggest challenge? Brawley states, âItâs still smoking, now added with poor diet, poor physical fitness, and obesity. Without the obesity epidemic, weâd have a much bigger decline in the mortality rate over the last 20 years.â

How would American Cancer Society like people to mark the 100th birthday of the organization? I was impressed to see the request for people to take a look at their habits: Smoking, diet, exercise. Donât blame the person who smokes, has a poor diet, or doesnât exerciseâbut realize weâve created an environment that supports poor habits. Forty years ago, the family had one car, walked to the local grocery store, and made meals rather than stopping by the drive-thru for a processed fast-food dinner.

<i>Be the change you want to seeâ</i>Ghandi

100 years of celebrating birthdays. That's a lot of candles!

<a href="http://www.cancer.org">www.cancer.org</a>

1-800-227-2345 (1-800-ACS-2345)]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Know Your Charities!  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/10/know-your-charities/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 10 Jun 2013 15:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1658</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/hcharities_0613.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1659" alt="hcharities_0613" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/hcharities_0613.jpg" width="307" height="409" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Have you ever given to a charity such as Susan G. Koman? Do you know where your money goes when you give to a charity? How much of the money you give goes to administration, or to cover costs spent toward an event? Those water booth at The Walkâtheyâre not donated. Neither are the porta-potties. They say participants join events for the tee-shirts. I could do without a huge tee that ends up as a night-shirt, a rag, or donation to a thrift store. How about you?

Did you know that .50 of every $1.00 raised for Susan G. Koman walks goes to pay off event expenses? Knowing that, are you more drawn to give to a charity that uses money âfor the cureâ to actually spend it on things as such?

Iâm a strong advocate of researching a charityâno matter what the size or name, before giving any money. Youâd be surprised at how sloppy some of the most well-known charities are with money raised. <a title="Charity Navigator" href="www.charitynavigator.org"><i>Charity Navigator</i></a> is America's largest independent charity evaluator. It provides free ratings of the financial health, accountability, and transparency of thousands of charities.

If you wonder why so money is raised for cancer research, and are astounded that it seems to inch forward, maybe itâs time to look more closely at how the money is used, not how much is given. Do <i>your</i> research before giving money. Donât give trusting the charityâs name, and size without knowing for yourself how they rank. Stop being used by charities who have you ask friends and family to raise the money âfor cancerâ and spend it on promoting their name.

When I was going through chemo, there was a fundraiser for cancer. Buy a yogurt with the pink ribbon, go online and type in the code from the yogurt lid, and earn ten cents for breast cancer. I did it. The code was âinvalid.â I kept entering the code, and it kept being rejected. I called yogurt company phone number on the lid. They told me I was doing it wrong. In exasperation, I scanned the lid and emailed to them while we were on the phone. They finally agreed the lid had a faulty code! My question to them was how many other faulty codes were out there in the name of âhelp us find a cure by purchasing our productâ? They tried to assure me I found a needle in a haystack. At that point, it felt Iâd been told Iâd won the lottoâ âand rest assured, ten cents will go to your charity.â I buy a different yogurt now, one that never claims to be a front-runner in the cure for cancer.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Fatigue and Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/13/fatigue-and-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 13 Jun 2013 15:00:25 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1665</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/getty_rf_photo_of_fatigued_woman_collapsed_over_laundry.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1666" alt="getty_rf_photo_of_fatigued_woman_collapsed_over_laundry" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/getty_rf_photo_of_fatigued_woman_collapsed_over_laundry.jpg" width="405" height="225" /></a>

Image Credit: Good Search

So, You have, or have had cancer. What do you do to overcome fatigue? Do you go for a walk? Head for the couch? Are you tired because youâre depressed? Or are you exhausted because youâve been through the ringer with treatment after treatment?

No matter why youâre tired or what you do about it, recognize the <i>progress</i> youâve made, and continue to makeâeven if itâs mico-progress. If you get down about being tired or having to take naps, look at where you are now compared to where you were a few months ago. I had to quit working four hours a day, because by Wednesday, I got sick from over-extending myself, and having a less than optimal immune system. Instead, I started working three hours a day, and by doing so, I was able to work five days a week. I still rushed home for a nap, and slept a full nightâand still do.

Go through your calendar and look for things you did and crawled home after, or things you couldnât doâthat youâre doing now. Maybe youâre sleeping the same amount of hours, but doing more now. There may be a phase where your sleep requirement goes upânotice if your activity level is increasing, too. Without doing this, you may get down on yourself only seeing how much you want to doâand canât.

<b>Here are some ideas that may help retrieve your energy and get you back on schedule:</b>
<ul>
	<li>Go to bed at a reasonable and at a consistent time every night.</li>
	<li>Donât fall asleep watching TV; your sleep wonât be quality, your subconscious hears even when you donât.</li>
	<li>Set your alarm for a consistent time the morning if you find youâre sleeping too long.</li>
	<li>Exercise during the day, not at night or you might be up all night, throwing off your schedule.</li>
	<li>Eat at least a few hours before bedtime. Give your body time to digest food before sleeping.</li>
	<li>If you do take a nap in the day, take it early enough not to disrupt your bedtime.</li>
	<li>If you have lots of junk around, clear it out. Clutter can be overwhelming.</li>
	<li>Do one-two chores a day instead of trying to do five like your âused to.â</li>
	<li>Donât eat sugary foods as a âpick-me-upâ. Maintain a light food-flow throughout the day.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Breast Cancer Gene Test</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/17/breast-cancer-gene-test/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 17 Jun 2013 15:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1668</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/human-dna.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1669" alt="human-dna" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/human-dna.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="328" /></a>

Image Credit: CBC News

Hooray!

The U.S. Supreme Courtâs unanimous judgment is in: Companies cannot patent parts of naturally-occurring human genes. This decision has the potential to profoundly affect the emerging and lucrative medical and biotechnology industries. (National Human Genome Research Institute/Reuters)

Myriad Genetics Inc. is the only lab in America where testing for mutations of BRCA genes 1 and 2 are sent. The test costs between $3,000 and $6,000 and not is not covered by all health insurance. The test consists of a tube of blood. That tube is then packed in a padded box, then placed inside another padded box. The package is kept refrigerated, and shipped overnight to the Utah lab. They look to see if the DNA code is broken. If it is broken, it means the woman has a mutant gene. If thatâs the case, the woman has a higher risk (three to seven times higher) than the normal population for breast or ovarian cancer.Â  BRCA1 is more common, and points to risks of breast or ovarian cancer. BRCA2 is less common, and points to risks of other cancers forming.

The U.S. Supreme Court ruling reverses three decades of patent awards by government officials. It throws out patents held by Myriad Genetics Inc. on the BRCA 1 and 2 test.

Justice Clarence Thomas, who wrote the court's decision, said that Myriad's assertion â that the DNA it isolated from the body for its proprietary breast and ovarian cancer tests were patentable â had to be dismissed because it violates patent rules. The court has said that laws of nature, natural phenomena and abstract ideas are not patentable.

"We hold that a naturally occurring DNA segment is a product of nature and not patent eligible merely because it has been isolated," Thomas said.

For thirty years, the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has been awarding patents on human genes. Patents provide legal protection to inventors to prevent others from making, using or selling a novel device, process or application. Opponents of Myriad Genetics Incâs patents on BRCA genes 1 and 2 say patent protection shouldnât be given to something that can be found in the human body.

Iâm not up on Hollywood names. Before Angelina Jolieâs story hit the news, I didnât know a thing about her. For those of you who also live under a rock, sheâs an actress. Last month, she shared that bother her mother and maternal grandmother died of ovarian cancer. By having the BRCA gene test, Jolie learned she carries a mutated BRCA1 gene that puts her at high risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers.This led Jolie to have both of her healthy breasts removed to try to avoid the same fate.

When her story went public, I had several thoughts:
<ul>
	<li><i>Why does everyone need to know this womanâs private decision?Â </i></li>
	<li><i>Oh, great. Now a superstar makes a bilateralÂ mastectomy and implants look quick, easy, and foolproof. âBut, perhaps thatâs the mediaâs doing, not hers.</i></li>
	<li><i>What good timing to bring light to the debate about patenting DNA. </i>I see her decision as a tough, private one that has become a very public discussion. Maybe sheâs become the face to this BRCA gene test, and the importance of the test being accessible to those with questionable family cancer history. Maybe without the DNA patent ruling, the mainstream media and gossip magazines would be asking the question, âDo you agree with Jolieâs decision?â âAs if itâs ours to decide.</li>
</ul>
How the sides see this case:

Opponents of its patents say Myriad can use the patents to keep other researchers from working with the BRCA gene to develop other tests.

Companies have billions of dollars of investment and years of research on the line in this case. Their advocates argue that without the ability to recoup their investment through the profits that patents bring, breakthrough scientific discoveries to combat all kinds of medical maladies wouldn't happen.

"Genes and the information they encode area not patent eligibleâ¦ simply because they have been isolated from the surrounding genetic material," Thomas said.

Justice Antonin Scalia concurred, "the portion of the DNA isolated from its natural state sought to be patented is identical to that portion of the DNA in its natural state."

The court did rule that synthetically created DNA, known as cDNA, can be patented "because it is not naturally occurring," Thomas said.

Thomas noted there were still ways for Myriad to make money off its discovery. "Had Myriad created an innovative method of manipulating genes while searching for the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, it could possibly have sought a method patent," he said. And he noted that the case before the court did not include patents on the application of knowledge about the two genes.

Source: The Associated Press Posted: Jun 13, 2013 12:11 PM ET]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Midsummer; Summer Solstice</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/20/midsummer-summer-solstice/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 20 Jun 2013 15:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1674</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/midsummer.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1675" alt="midsummer" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/midsummer.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="426" /></a>Image Credit: Good Search

Iâm off to a wedding held in a meadow. Maybe Iâll have some photos to post when I return.Â Until then, Iâm focused on the newness of Summer. Ahhh. It feels <i>great</i>!

Summer Solsticeâan important day for the relationship between the earth, and the sun. On this day, the earth axis tilts the most toward the sun (about 23.5 degrees from itâs orbital plane.) Without planet earth tilting, weâd live in perpetual twilight (unless at the north or south poleâwhere weâd be in perpetual light, or darkness.) In the Northern hemisphere, today is the longest day of sunlight.

Summer Solstice is also known as Midsummerâcelebrated since the time of the Vikings, by visiting healing water wells, and making large bonfires to ward away evil spirits. Visits to water wells have been replaced to trips to the beach, if theyâre close by. Bon fires are part of the Midsummer tradition worldwide, with the exception of Sweden and parts of Finland. In Sweden, they instead focus their attention on raising and dancing around the maypole. The earliest historical mention of the maypole in Sweden is from the Middle Ages. Midsummer came out of an ancient fertility festival, and even though Midsummer maintained many of its pagan traditions, the church later adapted it into St. Johnâs Day. On Midsummer, thereâs sure to be folk costumes, singing and dancing, eating and drinkingâand wildflower wreaths worn on heads. If youâre so inclined, pick some wildflowers and tuck them under your pillow and hope youâll dream about your future spouse.

My mom recalls a story shared to her by her grandmother, Jenny, from Sweden. When Jenny was 15, she stuffed her bed pillows under her bed sheets to make it look as if she were still sleeping there. Then, before dawn, she stole out of her home to go celebrate Midsommar. Jenny danced all day long with Hugo, who would become her husband.

<span style="color:#0000ff;"><b>Ha entrevlig Midsommar! (Have a nice Midsummer!)<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/sweden-midsummer-garland-of-flowers.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1705 alignright" alt="sweden-midsummer-garland-of-flowers" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/sweden-midsummer-garland-of-flowers.jpg?w=300" width="300" height="286" /></a></b></span>

[caption id="" align="alignleft" width="300"]<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Midsommar_i_Vaxholm.jpg" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured" title="Midsommar i Vaxholm 2008." alt="Midsommar i Vaxholm 2008." src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Midsommar_i_Vaxholm.jpg/300px-Midsommar_i_Vaxholm.jpg" width="300" height="400" /></a> Midsommar i Vaxholm 2008. (Photo credit: Wikipedia)[/caption]]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Open Source Cancer Research</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/24/open-source-cancer-research/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 24 Jun 2013 15:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1710</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_1515_jay-bradner-open-source-cancer-research.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1711" alt="img_1515_jay-bradner-open-source-cancer-research" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_1515_jay-bradner-open-source-cancer-research.jpg?w=300" width="300" height="225" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

Why would a person whoâs a doctor and a chemist <i>give</i> away his medical research rather than patent it? Because heâs hoping for faster open-source drug discovery for cancer.

You maybe familiar with crowd sourcing (where anyone can go online and make a pitch for your project, and complete strangers interested will contribute money. If you raise your goal, you get the funds, and begin sending out your thanks-youâs, product prototype, etc.) An open-source drug discovery is where all the ideas and data are shared in real-time and anyone can participate. There are no pattens. Itâs not owned by any lab. The concept behind this is for discovery of good drugs for cancer, anyway possible and as quickly as possible.

I couldn't get the video to post here, but the link to a 12 minute TED Talk video is below. Â It's an inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research. Itâs about a social experiment that turned into cancer prototype drug. This project is funded by open-source, and crowd sourcing. Heâs still looking for financial support for this project.Â <a title="Open Source Drug Research" href="http://www.ted.com/talks/jay_bradner_open_source_cancer_research.html">Open Source Cancer DrugÂ Research</a>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Don't Let the Diagnosis Kill You</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/01/1719/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 01 Jul 2013 14:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1719</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/polls_the_big_listen316692292_5049_389496_poll_xlarge.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1720" alt="polls_the_big_listen316692292_5049_389496_poll_xlarge" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/polls_the_big_listen316692292_5049_389496_poll_xlarge.jpg" width="300" height="300" /></a>image credit: Good Search

The family still mourns the son who died of Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Now, another son of theirâs has been diagnosed.

I was visiting my mom when her phone rang. She was having a normal, casual conversation. Then, I heard a shift in her tone, âOh, Iâm so sorry to hear that.â I could tell someone long distance calling to lean on my mom for support.

His son had been diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Heâs been through this before. Another son of his died several years back from the same disease. From the immediate to-do list the family has, it sounds like much of the energy is going toward planning to die.

While dying is a fact of life, and planning is a responsible act for <i>everyone</i> to do (having a will, getting things in order so someone knows where to find xyz, getting on a donor list if thatâs your plan...) âI couldnât help but wonder if this son had decided to die at the time of diagnosis.

When I was diagnosed with stage three breast cancer, I ran the other way. I was so absolutely positive I didnât have cancer that I feared it was a misdiagnosis. It wasnât. A month later I got on board with my medical team. Two years later, I was re-diagnosed as stage four. I spent a week updating my will, looking at relationships, events and things in my life. The following week, I was told, âYes, youâre stage four, but we believe itâs âcurable.â Maybe this son is experiencing all that one goes through in the first monthâthe information comes at you so fast, and thereâs so much of it. Heâs got the added information of his brother not surviving. I donât know his details. At the time of the phone call, they didnât know anything other than, âTagâyouâre it.â

According to the American Cancer Society:

- About 9,290 new cases will occur (4,220 in females and 5,070 in males). These numbers have not changed much over the past few years.

- About 1,180 people (520 females, 660 males) will die of this cancer.

- Because of advances in treatment, survival rates have improved in the past few decades. The 1-year relative survival rate for all patients diagnosed with Hodgkin disease is now about 92%; the 5-year and 10-year survival rates are about 85% and 80%, respectively.

If you know someone whoâs recently been diagnosed, listen to them, or their family member. They may be morose at first, or defiant. Just be there. Donât say, âYouâre not going to die from this.â You donât know that. Iâd also suggest you donât add to their fear, either. Skip the stories about how awful the cancer treatment is, especially if you donât know it first hand. If they ask you questions to which you do know the answer, think carefully <i>how</i> you answer. They are so raw at this stage. Donât feed their fear. Mindset is huge in this game called cancer. Reassure them. Tell them youâll be there for them, and their family. Youâll take the kids out, or drive them to appointments. Offer to set up a calendar to schedule helpers: cooks, drivers, spending time with their child or parent.

In my momâs case, I know she will support the son by supporting his father. When the father (whoâs in his 80âs) asked her how far sheâd drive for a kid with cancer, she said, âTo the end of the earth.â She drove 50 miles each way to help me after several surgeries and during the months of chemo. I know some people, who no matter how much they love someone, wouldnât drive that far more than once, especially in traffic.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>A Mid Summer Wedding</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/06/27/a-mid-summer-wedding/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 27 Jun 2013 15:00:18 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1722</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5591.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1725" alt="IMG_5591" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5591.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="438" /></a>Here are some photos from my friendâs mid-summer wedding. The ceremony was in a gorgeous meadow that had a labyrinth. The path was as wide as a lawn mower. When we arrived to the meadow, I picked wild daisies to make the bride a wreath for her head. Then I took photos of the surrounding area. Next thing I knew, I was being tapped on the shoulder to sage and bless each guest before their entering the labyrinth.<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5600.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1727" alt="IMG_5600" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5600.jpg?w=584" width="584" height="438" /></a>This wedding got me thinking of gifts that can be given from the heart. First, there was the opportunity for every guest (17) to bring organic, non-GMO fruit, vegetable, or flower seeds for the couple to plant and act as a reminder for them to nurture their friendships. The couple also asked each guest to bringÂ  something from nature. In addition to seeds and nature, guests were asked to write a poem or message about, or to the Summer Solstice and read it to the group.

Up until the point of finding an item of nature, I had confidence that as usual, I packed light, and smart. But then I found two rocksâeach in the shape of a heart. Why couldnât I be happy with a leaf or feather!

Sticking to my original plan, I was also giving the couple a great chef knife. My friend loves to cook and entertain. So, this meant I had to plan ahead and ship off the knife, and pack the rocks along with wrapping paper (only to get scolded by the bride for <i>using</i> paper.) One guest gifted the couple with catering the simple but beautifulÂ hors d'oeuvres. Another guest made a six-foot wine bottle holder out of wood heâd found, adding shape and holes to the piece of wood.<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5598.jpg"><img alt="IMG_5598" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5598.jpg?w=300" width="300" height="225" /></a>

Iâm on the good side of cancerârebuilding strength. This was my first big trip, and I was determined to carry-on my bag rather than pay $25 for the same weight as some womenâs purses. It wasnât pretty and I ached from doing it, but I did it. It reminded me of a story I was told by a man years ago.

This man was staying in Africa for several months. He made friends with the locals. On his birthday, one of his new friends gifted him with a sea shell. This man knew his friend couldnât have bought the shell, and they lived hundreds of miles from the coast. He said, âThe ocean is far away. How did you get this shell?â His friend replied. âLong journey part of gift.â Heâd walked a few days to honor his friend with a sea shell.

&nbsp;

No matter where you're going, near or far, your journey can gift someone now. You may do things slower and with less gustoâbut use more of your energy now. Sometimes honoring someone by showing up is more than enough. I think my friend was more grateful for the head wreath, photography, and space clearing I did than the chef knife. For me, the big gift was the travel itself. The hidden energy expended that no one saw or understood. âLong journey part of gift.

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5578.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1723" alt="IMG_5578" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5578.jpg?w=225" width="225" height="300" /></a> <a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5590.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1724" alt="IMG_5590" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/06/img_5590.jpg?w=225" width="225" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Exercising after Cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/08/exercising-after-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 08 Jul 2013 14:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1734</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/img_water-bottle_1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1736" alt="img_water-bottle_1" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/img_water-bottle_1.jpg" width="300" height="389" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Sorry to ask thisâbut have you lifted any weights today? After breast or prostate cancer, thereâs an increased risk of osteoporosis (bone loss). I used to lift weights, but since cancer, I havenât. Theyâre <i>heavy</i>! swap around with walking, swimming, sit ups, leg lifts, but weights arenât as enjoyable as they used to be. Perhaps I need to go back to three-pound weights, work up to five, and take it from there. The main reason Iâve backed off weights is not wanting to wear a compression sleeve. Poor excuse, really. (Learn more about <a title="compression sleeves" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?s=compression+sleeve&amp;submit=Search">compression sleeves</a>).<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?s=compression+sleeve&amp;submit=Search">
</a>

What causes bone loss? First, letâs start with what helps <i>protect</i> us from bone loss. Hormones. Then along comes cancer, and cancer treatment. The hormones get blocked to help treat the cancer. This can make the bones less dense. Patients who are older and may already have weekend bones are at even higher risk for osteoporosis.

Patients who take aromatase inhibitors, which lower estrogen levels, are especially at risk for significant bone loss. Men who are treated for prostate cancer with androgen-deprivation therapy are also at risk for osteoporosis.

Makes you just want to sit down and eat a bowl of ice cream, doesnât it? Get your calcium, and take it with vitamin C, and get plenty of vitamin D, too. remember, bone is a living tissue. Weight-bearing activities are good for building strong bones. Go ahead, lift that grandkid! Danceâeven if someoneâs watching! I buy potatoes one by one, but maybe I should lift up a bag or two at the store just for the sake of it. My first push-up after treatment was more of a push-down. I went <i>straight</i> down to the floor! Then again, the compression sleeve issue came into play. Work up to lifting weights. Start with water bottles, or cans.

Move up in weights gradually to avoid injury, or stressing out the lymph system. it seems everyone suggests having guidance and a supervised workout program. I have found I know way more about body mechanics and cancer than some gym trainers. I left a gym because Iâd overhear the trainer giving bad advice to someone, or not correcting someone doing an exercise incorrectly. If youâre in physical therapy, itâs a great opportunity to learn new exercises, but youâll move through the sessions quickly,Â then youâre on your own. Resistance training is good, but again, start with low resistance, and slowly progress. Thatâs the take-away. âStart low, progress slow.â

Here are some ideas for weight-bearing exercises for any level:
<ul>
	<li>lunges</li>
	<li>squats</li>
	<li>rowing or pull down (youâll need equipment)</li>
	<li>bicep curls (donât go buy weights - use what you have: water bottles, cans of food, bags of rice...)</li>
	<li>tricep kickbacks</li>
	<li>push against a wall</li>
</ul>
Sometimes when I walk the beach, I pick up trash as I walk. wear gloves and carry a bag. The frequent bending (and itâs a pretty clean beach) is a great gluteus workout! The first time I did it was soon after chemo. I donât recommend that.

Here's a link to someÂ <a title="exercise ideas and tips" href="http://exercise.about.com/od/butthipsthighs/tp/butt.htm">exercise ideas and tips</a>.]]></content:encoded>
