<item>
  <title>Hiking for American Institute for Cancer Research  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/11/hiking-for-american-institute-for-cancer-research/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 11 Jul 2013 14:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1762</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/zook-earl.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1764" alt="zook-earl" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/zook-earl.jpg" width="200" height="254" /></a>Â image credit: AICR

When<b> </b>Earl Zook of Stephens City, Virginia decided to hike the Appalachian Trail, he was 87 andÂ  a walker, without any previous hiking experience. Mr. Zook had been inspired to benefit American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR), and wanted to be the oldest person to hike the trail.

Heâs a very active member of the Kiwannis Club of Winchester. He said, âEvery year the club goes to Camp Fantastic to serve breakfast to children who have cancer. And thatâs why I wanted to raise money for AICR.â

So, at 88, he set out to spend the next three summers on the trail, raising more than $7,000 for AICR. He had good planning and help from friends and a mentor. He headed south in 2010 to the trailâs origin at Springer Mountain, Georgia. Over the next two summers he trekked the northern states, reaching Mt. Washington in New Hampshireâaltitude 6,822 feet in September. Good timing. They closed it for the season in October when it gets too cold to hike. Earl ended his at Mt. Katahdin in Maine, where the trail ends.

What a way to test out two new knees! Earl had knee replacement surgery before his hike. In every state, he hiked sections of the trail, resting between them. His says, âYou see a lot more on the trail in every state when you take your time and observe whatâs around you.â What a great reminder for daily life. Earl suggests for hiking success to bring iodine tablets to purify stream water, and to take care of your feet. Get good shoes before you go, and break them in.

He celebrated his 90th birthday last October with 300 people, including friends from AICR. Earl says he plans to see them for his 100th. Thanks for the work you do Earl, and also to AICR!

<item>
  <title>Healthy Choices: Fruits and Vegetables</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/15/healthy-choices-fruits-and-vegetables/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 15 Jul 2013 14:00:40 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1771</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/5-servings.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1772" alt="5 servings" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/5-servings.jpg" width="480" height="318" /></a>

image credit: Good Search

Some people think fresh produce is the only way to get healthy produce. Not true. Sometimes, frozen or canned vegetables hold just as muchâor more nutrients than fresh. They can also be lower is cost and easier to prepare. When I was going through chemo, my idea of preparing a meal was opening a can of white or black beans, a can of tomatoes, a can of corn, and adding pre-chopped celery and onion (thank you friends and family), and maybe spices like cumin or basil. When I was real low on energy, Iâd ask someone else to open the cans. They loved this simple request! âIs <i>that</i> all you want me to do?â And depending on my energy level, my response was either, âYes.â or âIâll starve if you donât.â

Vegetables retain their nutrients by how theyâre processed or prepared. With flash freezing, vegetables hold their nutrients because soon after picking them, theyâre boiled, then moved to ice water and drained before being frozen. Fruits are washed, slices and frozen. Canning uses heat treatment to destroy microorganisms that cause spoilage.

Both flash freezing and canning are done within 24 hours of produce being picked. This is known as âminimal processing.â Foods that are highly processed, including fruits and vegetables prepared with a lot of salt, sugar, or fat are known as âhighly processedâ foods. Examples are vegetables with cheese sauce, or canned fruit pie filling. If you can, add your own cheese to vegetables, and make your own pie filling. Look for frozen fruit without syrup and canned fruit packed in water or its own juice. Buy no-salt added versions of canned vegetables, or drain out the liquid from the regular kind, and rise a few times. Store brand canned or frozen items are often lower in price and same quality as name-brand.

However you get âem - Get âem! Five servings a day of fruits and vegetables will help keep you healthy and lower the risk of cancer.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Vitamin D and Prostate Cancer  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/18/vitamin-d-and-prostate-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 18 Jul 2013 14:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1775</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/vitamin-d-foods.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1777" alt="Vitamin D foods" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/vitamin-d-foods.jpg" width="300" height="203" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Prostate cancer is the second most common type of cancer diagnosis in menâthe most common being skin cancer. David Feldman, MD, of Stanford University, has been studying how vitamin D and soy may slow or stop the growth of prostate cancer.

In an American Institute for Cancer Research newsletter, Dr. Feldman explains that vitamin D isnât really a vitamin. âVitamin D is a precursor to a potent hormone called calcitriol that regulates hundreds of genes in most tissue of he body. Taking vitamin D is more like taking a substance that the body then converts to an active drug.â

Calcitriol helps the body absorb calcium, which is why itâs often in calcium supplements. Calcitriol is has anti-cancer effects on certain pathways involved in the growth of cancer cells. Vitamin D is being studied for its potential to reduce the risk for prostate, breast and colorectal cancers.

<b>Warning!</b>

Dr. Feldman cautions men from trying to find the right amount of vitamin D and soy without the help of their medical team. While the combination of vitamin D and soy is being studied to see if it protects against the development or progression of prostate cancer, the combination can have significant and toxic side effects (including fatality).

By getting a blood test, your doctor will know how much calcium and vitamin D is in your body, and can then suggest proper doses of supplements. Dr. Feldman and his colleagues are extending their studies through a new American Institute for Cancer Research-funded study.

Until we know the findings are solid, get your calcium and vitamin D in reasonable doses, unless otherwise told to do so, increase the amounts through foods.

A note about soy to women: If youâve had family members with estrogen receptive cancer âif you donât know the answer, but know someone in the family had breast or ovarian cancer, I <i>highly</i> recommend women avoid soy. Iâm not a doctor. Iâm a woman who had estrogen receptive breast cancer, and a reoccurrence of it. I tested positive for being high risk for ovarian cancer and had my ovaries removed to prevent an estrogen receptive site from having the opportunity to host cancer. Iâve been told to not take any soy supplements. Talk with your oncologist.]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1775</wp:post_id>
  <wp:post_date>2013-07-18 07:00:21</wp:post_date>
  <wp:post_date_gmt>2013-07-18 14:00:21</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

<item>
  <title>Healthy Kids: ages 2-12</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/22/healthy-kids-ages-2-12/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 22 Jul 2013 14:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1780</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/kids-cooking.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1784" alt="kids cooking" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/kids-cooking.jpg" width="300" height="200" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

This is taken from the American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR) Healthy Kids Today Toolkit. <i>Eat powerful plant foods</i>.

Take the cancer prevention pledge with your children and grandchildren:

I pledge to:

Help my child prepare this monthâs recipe for Bean and Veggie Enchiladas. *See link for recipe.

Try one new vegetable each week.

Make a meal that contains only plant foods â vegetables, fruits, whole grains and beans â and no meat.

Incorporate different colored vegetables into our daily meals and snacks.

Tell each other what our favorite vegetable is â and give two reasons why.

Itâs never too early to eat a healthy diet that includes plenty of cancer-fighting plant foods like vegetables for lower cancer risk. In fact, research suggests that new foods are even better accepted at ages 2 to 4 than they are at ages 4 to 8.

<strong>Related Links:</strong>

*Â <a title="recipe" href="powerful-plants-recipe-1">Bean and Veggie Enchilada recipe</a>

*<a title="benefits and tips for cooking with kids 2-12" href="powerful-plants-cooking-with-kids">Benefits and tips for cooking with your child ages 2-12</a>

<item>
  <title>When weâre thirsty, weâre already dehydrating  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/25/when-were-thirsty-were-already-dehydrating/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 25 Jul 2013 14:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1787</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/hydration.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1789" alt="Hydration" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/hydration.jpg" width="425" height="282" /></a>

image credit: Good Search

<b></b>Water, water everywhere, not a drop to drink. . . . Did you know that the human body is made up mostly of water? Keep asking for refills! Without hydration, there is no life.

When we feel thirsty, itâs a sign weâre already dehydrating. According to American Institute for Cancer Research, when we feel thirsty, weâve already lost 1-2 percent of body water. During chemo, I was told to be vigilant about staying hydrated. It was explained to me, âChemo is busy burning up your inners. Staying hydrated flushes it out. Itâs done itâs job, now get rid of it.â Here are some tips on <a title="liquid tips" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/25/what-counts-as-a-liquid/">what counts as a liquid</a>, and how to avoid from filling up on liquids. <a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/25/what-counts-as-a-liquid/">
</a>

You wonât necessarily feel like drinking or eating during the months of chemo, and with age, the sense of thirst declines. Golden rule for all of us: Sip throughout the day to keep hydrated. Avoid things like sodas, coffee and alcohol. They all dehydrate the body. If you donât like the taste of water, or need it a bit heavier, add a lemon, a sprig of mint, or a slice of cucumber. When I wanted something with more flavor, Iâd drink juice, but add 40 percent of my glass would be water to thin it down. Juice straight was too heavy for me, and the taste too strong.

If the side effects of chemo or surgery anesthesia is making you constipated, donât just rely on fiber to get things moving again. The fiber requires hydration. Itâs not about drinking 32 oz. in one sitting. Sip throughout the day. In addition to constipation, itâll help prevent dizziness, kidney troubles, indigestion, dry eyes, nose and mouthâand a moist mouth will help prevent cavities. <a title="dry mouth" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/02/18/dry-mouth-during-cancer/">Hereâs a post on dry mouth</a>,Â and <a title="protecting your teeth" href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/protect-your-teeth/">protecting your teeth during chemo</a>.<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/protect-your-teeth/">
</a>

<item>
  <title>Dog Days of Summer and Exercise</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/07/29/dog-days-of-summer-and-exercise/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 29 Jul 2013 14:00:06 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1792</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/dogdaysofsummer.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1794" alt="dogdaysofsummer" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/dogdaysofsummer.jpg" width="550" height="412" /></a>image credit: Good Search

Think of yourself as a dog. (I mean this in a good way!)

Heal.

Sit.

Lie down.

Good boy/girl!

Want to go exercise? Let's go!

Hereâs some more water.

During cancer treatment, youâll want to exercise but may find you lack the energy and strength. Especially if your treatment is in the dog days of summer. I was grateful my treatment was in the summer. As my iron levels dropped, I was always coldâuntil hot flashes kicked in, then I was back to being cold. Do what you canâeven if that means a walk to the mailbox three times a day.

If you live where the temperatures are hot, you have some options for exercise: Go to an air-conditioned gym, or community center, head for a pool, or get up at zero-thirty to beat the heat for some outdoor activity. (If your treatment is in the winter, and you live where itâs cold, the gym or community center again will protect you from the elements.) No matter what you do, make sure youâre paying attention to what your body is saying.

I originally thought Iâd be walking the beach during my treatment months, even if slowly. Ha. During the months of my treatment, I walked about an-eighth of the boardwalk when I did venture to the beach (usually with a guest I wanted to take to the beach.) Weâd last 20 minutes maximum, then Iâd need to come home. The sun was too bright, and my endurance was too low. Iâd spend the next day with a cold. It was so worth it. The beach was my sanity. When my mom would visit me, sheâd offer to take me to the beach for 15-20 minutes. Iâd just sit in the car. Sheâs go to the waterâs edge before coming back to the car where I was sometimes asleep, or ready to go home.

Consider going to an indoor pool and sitting on a ânoodleâ like a swing, pumping with your legs, one at a time. Or âstandâ perpendicular in the water, holding the ânoodleâ in front of you, and move your legs like an egg beater. Itâs not a weight-bearing activity, but itâs a great place to be if your joints are aching, or youâre building your endurance. Once you have the energy and confidence, you can swim half short laps, building up to long lane laps if thatâs your desire. Water aerobic classes are plentiful and work major muscle groups.

Whatever you do, start slowly. You will hear of people who walk "The Walkâ right after treatment. Do not compare yourself with anyone else. Go at your pace. Listen to your body. Respect your needs.

Scoot over. Doggie wants to rest on the couch!

<item>
  <title>Why Would You Leave Your Doctor?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/01/why-would-you-leave-your-doctor/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 01 Aug 2013 14:00:03 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1798</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/bye-bye-doctor.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1799" alt="bye bye doctor" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/bye-bye-doctor.jpg" width="258" height="300" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Why would you leave your doctor? Let me count the ways:

Are you sick <i>and</i> tired of the hassles your doctor and/or his office put you through? Fed up with the communication breakdowns, the lack of bedside manner, or the errors from your doctor or his staff, including billing? Has your doctor gone high-tech and forgotten common sense, or the human touch? Perhaps their lingo is medical mojo.âFine. But if I donât understand it, <i>educate</i> me. Someone spent time educating you, Dr. Smarty Pants (Or is it Dr. Canât be bothered?)

Itâs your right to know what they are saying about you. <i>You</i> are a member on your medical team. Are you informed about your test results? Are your office visits rushed? I understand doctors are busyâso are many of their patients. Even if it looks like all we do is go to the doctors,âtwo doctor appointments can take all day long. How long do you wait to see your doctor?

Some people are afraid to get a second opinion, or to leave a doctor theyâve been with.

When I was diagnosed, I went for a second opinion. I stayed with the <i>second</i> surgical oncologist. After my first appointment with my oncologist (different from surgical oncologist), I left the appointment knowing it wasnât a good fit. I called before my second appointment to ask for a transfer to another doctor. Iâm happy I did. From that point on, I keptâand loved my medical team. Well. . . until three years into it. Then I left my reconstruction surgeon, and my only regret is that I hadnât done so two years earlier. With the latter two changes, I remained at the same office for my medical care.

Some suggest talking to the administrative staff if you have issues with the doctor. I donât agree with that, but I see where it could be less intimidating for some people. From what I hear and see, the staff speak too freely and in ear shot. They have no reason to be loyal to you, the patient. Itâs not their medical license up for review.

Regarding my complaint over much larger implants than expected, a <i>physician assistant</i> replied, âIâm not going to tell [the surgeon] that!â Because my after surgery complaint was not passed on, I waited for my next appointment to ask, âWhy am I larger than the implants being replaced? That was an agreed upon size.â In my case, Iâd gone to someone other than the doctor, and <i>they</i> were afraid to tell the doctor <i>my</i> complaint!

Have you ever been forgotten in the exam room? I have. In waiting rooms, I now sit where the receptionist can see me. In the exam room, I pop my head out if Iâm in there more than 15 minutes.

If surveys are sent to you, fill them out. You can do it anonymously, if you want.

If you do change doctors, by law, you are entitled to take your medical records with you. This September, patients should be able to get them electronically, too.

<b>Consider leaving your doctor if:</b>
<ul>
	<li>If your questions arenât answered, or theyâre not answered in a way you understand.</li>
</ul>
Bring someone with you to the appointments if youâre having some trouble, and then you can decide if itâs youâstressed out, tired, hearing problems, or your doctorâs issue.
<ul>
	<li>If your questions are faced with dismissal.</li>
</ul>
I show up with my yellow pad of paper. Iâve thought out questions before my appointment, and as things arise between appointments, I write them down on my pad of paper. Only one doctor has visibly shown dread with this. The office packed with patients, the doctor in fast speed robo-mode, and after my waiting one-and-a-half hours to be seen, I expected some answers. <i>Five</i> minutes later (this includes the time for pleasantries and the exam), the doctor went for the door handle. My list on my lap, I said, âOhh nooo. I have questions for you.â The answers I got equated to a pat on the head and âWeâre not there yetâ which translated to (as always, Iâm too busy for a patient to have a meltdown. I canât answer the long version of those questions.)
<ul>
	<li>If the doctor seems offended that you want a second opinionâkeep walking.</li>
</ul>
It is common place for patients to get second opinions, and health insurance usually covers them.

Before you go to any doctor, make sure they are board certified, or board-eligible if theyâre just out of medical school. If you have a doctor, and not sure theyâre board certified, you can check at <a href="http://www.certificationmatters.org">www.certificationmatters.org</a>Â  or call (866) 275-2267.

Remember, <em>you</em> are also on your medical team. Sometime it comes down to chemistry. Other times, the doctor/patient relationship changes. Donât stay out of loyalty if something is wrong.

Itâs for your health.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Grew Tomatoes. Now What?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/05/grew-tomatoes-now-what/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 05 Aug 2013 14:00:21 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1805</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/tomato-vine.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1804" alt="tomato vine" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/tomato-vine.jpg" width="317" height="318" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Did you grow tomatoes this summer and now wonder what to do with them? If you can find a neighbor who grew zucchini, youâre in luck! Swap vegetables, and swap some recipes, too. Here are some facts about the tomato you can digest in good health:

When processed or cooked, tomatoes actually contain more lycopene than raw tomatoes. The structure of the antioxidant lycopene changes, making it more easily absorbed by our bodies. So, pour on the pasta sauce, and feel good about buying canned tomatoes in the winter. Just half-cup of tomato sauce is plenty for an adequate lycopene boost to your system. Food sources of lycopene have been found to be more beneficial than supplements. <a title="tomatoes" href="http://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatmentsandsideeffects/complementaryandalternativemedicine/dietandnutrition/lycopene">Here's a link for more information aboutÂ lycopene</a>.

&nbsp;

<b>Tons of tomatoesânow what?</b>

Tomatoes are consumed more than any other non-starchy vegetable in America. Here are some ideas to make sure they donât go to waste.
<ul>
	<li>Share them! If a friend or neighbor has plenty of something else, barter ;)</li>
	<li>No sandwich is complete without a tomato slice.</li>
	<li>Is spaghetti for dinner? Cook up some tomatoes, and crush them for the sauce.</li>
	<li>To add some character to your breakfast eggs, dice some tomatoes.</li>
	<li>Cold or warm tomato or gazpacho soup. Youâre on your own here. Iâve never made either.</li>
	<li>Stuff tomatoes like you would a stuffed pepper and cook, or stuff it with tuna, or cottage cheese.</li>
	<li>Make stew or soup with all sorts of tomatoes: fresh, canned, dried - they each add their own flavor.</li>
</ul>
<b>For snacks or hâorderves:</b>
<ul>
	<li>Make some salsa for a quick appetizer: (dice tomatoes, chop cilantro, onion, jalapeno pepper, garlic, and squeeze some lemon.) If you have a molcajete - a traditional Mexican version of a mortar and pestle, crush the ingredients - itâll bring the flavor out even more by crushing them a bit. If you like smooth rather than chunky salsa, put things in the blender after you chop them up.</li>
	<li>Another side dish or snack with tomato: thick slices of tomatoes and alternatively overlap with slices of mozzarella cheese as you make your way around a plate (If youâre near a Costco, they sell packages already sliced.) Add some fresh basil. Drizzle olive oil on top, and add salt and pepper, and balsamic vinegar if you want a stronger flavor.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Cold Caps May Reduce Hair Loss During Chemo  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/08/cold-caps-may-reduce-hair-loss-during-chemo/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 08 Aug 2013 14:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1808</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/cold-cap.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1809" alt="cold cap" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/cold-cap.jpg" width="214" height="300" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

Youâve either heard, seen or experienced it: Chemo-related hair loss. For many women, itâs the toughest part of cancer. Itâs an announcement of your health status. People will freely ask you, âWhat kind of cancer do you have?â Now thereâs a buzz about a new treatment in the U.S. that may help keep your private details of cancer hair loss from the public eye.

Itâs been dubbed âthe cold capâ and has been used in Europe, New Zealand, Australia, and Canada for years. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration hasnât approved any of the caps used in other countries. Now U.S. researchers are experimenting with this hair-preserving treatment for those undergoing chemo. This summer, researchers in the U.S. will begin enrolling 110 early-stage breast cancer patients to participate in a study of the brand DigniCap.

The cap is so cold that it numbs the scalp during chemotherapy. Near-freezing temperatures of the cap are said to reduce the blood flow in the scalp. With such low temperatures, the hair follicles are more difficult to harm by the drugs used in chemo, a drug that effects <i>all</i> fast growing cellsâboth healthy and cancerous ones.

I wonder if the cap, being so cold, creates any headaches for the patient. Ever eat ice cream too fast? During chemo, I was frequently very cold. With a cold cap, will it be standard for the patient to get warm blankets, too? Iâve read that patients keep much of their hair. Does that mean it gets real thin, but doesnât all fall out? So many things to wait and learn.

Have you or anyone you know used a cold cap? What are your thoughts about them?

Related articles
<ul class="zemanta-article-ul">
	<li class="zemanta-article-ul-li"><a href="http://www.fresnobee.com/2013/07/22/3399060/cold-caps-tested-to-prevent-hair.html" target="_blank">Cold caps tested to prevent hair loss during chemo</a> (fresnobee.com)</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

    <wp:comment_date>2013-08-08 08:51:35</wp:comment_date>
    <wp:comment_date_gmt>2013-08-08 15:51:35</wp:comment_date_gmt>
    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I had my treatment in England, and was offered the cold cap. But it's sooooo cold. :) I think it's a considerable challenge for people, particularly as the chemo goes on. However, talking to the nurses they said that it did seem to work often enough. But what they don't tell you is you need to arrive an hour or so early, and stay an hour or so extra after treatment with that cap on your head - adding quite a bit of time. Just hearing that was enough for me, and I went without. Though it is very hard to lose hair, very hard indeed. ~Catherine]]></wp:comment_content>

<item>
  <title>If laugher is medicine, whatâs your dose? </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/12/if-laugher-is-medicine-whats-your-dose/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 12 Aug 2013 14:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1819</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[What do you do for a good laugh?

I was needing to yuck-it-up.

Usually, I can reframe from sad to happy easily if I need to. Or, if I just need to shift my point of view, or mood, Iâll grab a book of one of my bookshelves, and turn my attitude to gratitude. Recently, I was feeling low, and none of my positive mindset, spiritual, or how-to books were holding my interest. Walking the beach wasnât the fix, either. I asked myself, âWhenâs the last time I had a <i>good, long</i> laugh?â It had been too long.

I searched You Tube the words âfunnyâ and âlaughterâ. I watched lots of videos, turning most of them off within thirty seconds. âStupidâ or âfoulâ is how Iâd categorize them. Lots of animal videos. My analytical and protective mind took over, not allowing anything to be funny. <i>Is a cat falling off the counter again and again, funny? Did the cat get up there by itself?Â </i>

Then I looked up âLaughter Yogaâ. Iâm familiar with it, but the videos were educational, and like all the books on my shelves, they werenât what I needed.

I needed to laugh.

The next day, I went to my local record store - a hole in the wall that sells oldies, and lots of hipster paraphernalia. My intention was to trade-in a pile of my CDs for a comedy CD. The store wasnât taking any trades at this time because they had so many CDs in stock. I bought a well-known Bill Cosby routine. But it wasnât the laugh I was looking for.

I went to the library to pick-up comedy CDs. Did you know âComedyâ is found under âNon-Fictionâ? Now <i>thatâs</i> funny! The library near my apartment is super small, and I was re-directed to the larger library across town. I put it on my âto-doâ list. That evening, I gave You Tube another try. This time, I used the words âComedyâ and âClean Stand upâ. B-I-N-G-O! I laughed my head off for one hour. I got up to get tissue for my happy tears flowing down my face. I knew my neighbors could hear me laughing hysterically, which made me laugh harder at one point.

This one hour stand-up routine of Ellen DeGeneres is what the doctor ordered. Itâs clean. Itâs something we can relate to. It has nothing to do with cancer. Enjoy!

[youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5V5IzWgZzcY]Â Please share what makes you laugh.]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>The Importance of Encouraging Words  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/15/the-importance-of-encouraging-words/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 15 Aug 2013 14:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1823</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/be-positive.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1824" alt="be positive" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/be-positive.jpg" width="207" height="300" /></a>Â Image Credit: Good Search

When you were diagnosed, or re-diagnosed, what was your reaction? Did you let your shock, anger, fear just come out in the office? Or did it hit you later? And, when it did hit, what was it like? Some people sit and cry. Some have a surge of fear or anger well up. Others turn analytical, turning their focus within.

Did you ever express your emotions as a knee jerk reaction in the exam room, only to be told by someone on the medical team, âBe positive.â Thatâs great advice, but I also think it depends when and where that advice is given. If youâre in the exam room and have just been diagnosed, or re-diagnosed, I think, âBe positiveâ is a cop-out for staff. They deal with the words all day, everydayâfor cancer in someone elseâs body. Even if itâs a re-diagnosis, itâs new information to you. If youâre the one who found the bump on your body, thereâs still that phase where you donât know if itâs cancer or not. Thereâs that waiting period. Blood test, biopsy, and maybe a scan or two. Â I know itâs a matter of semantics, but hearing, âIâm sorry. Stay focused on the goodâ or âI know this is hard. Keep positiveâ has a better ring to it than,Â âBeÂ  positive."As if being positive will magically change the bump from malignant to benign over night.

For me, the doctorâs office is the place where I vent. I expect that to be the safe place for my complaints about side effects, and the place for me to ask tons of questions that have popped up since my last visit, or while hearing a new diagnosis. Being told to, âBe positiveâ at this point doesnât help me. When Iâm at home, I listen to hypnotherapy, beautiful music, and comedy. I walk the beach, or read New Thought books. I meditate. I pray. I surround myself with like-minded people, who will affirm good. Iâve just begun to travel again. Iâm working a bit, too. My book is with an editor now. Being told, âBe positiveâ from a nurse as she hands me the doctorâs urgent orders for four tests, allows me to witness someone whoâs uncomfortable with the moment. Ha! That makes two of us. . .

Like most people, I claim to be a positive person. For over thirty years, Iâve been steeped in New Thought (positive, practical spirituality). When I go dark, it feels very foreign to me. Even in really tough times, I can bring myself back to the Light, to break up the downward pull. Sometimes it means I come back to the Light 100 times a day. Like the Chinese proverb: Fall down seven times. Get up eight. Itâs not about denying the dark side. Itâs about denying the dark side, power.

Itâs okay to be present with the diagnosis given youâbut then you must decide how you walk this path. There will be moments you trip and fall. Your thoughts may go dark, you may hurt physically and emotionally. Tend to your woundsâthen get up. Find the good in the situation. Find the good in life; in humanity.

If you hear, âBe positiveâ itâs because people want you to experience happiness. Cancer cannot take that away. (Well, okay, it canâbut thatâs because we drift off with it, giving cancer and it's side effects the power to claim our life while we are still living.)]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Whatâs your cancer song?  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/19/whats-your-cancer-song/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 19 Aug 2013 14:00:04 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1828</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/still-standing.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1829" alt="still standing" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/still-standing.jpg" width="300" height="225" /></a>Â Image credit: Good Search

You know how it goes. You hear a song on the radio, and itâs not a love song, or break-up song, but a cancer song. The words fit your situation perfectly, or communicates what you need to hear to boost you up. When I was first diagnosed, I played and re-played Mario Lanzaâs âWhen You Walk Through a Storm.â The song gave me strength, reminding me I was not on the path alone.

Then, my roots deepened with a gospel song from The Glide Ensemble Love to Give CD. âGod Will Take Care of You.â Iâd play the second one all the way to the cancer clinicâover and over, and <i>over</i>. âDonât you worry so much about the path you chose. . .â

Word got out I was groovinâ to gospel. I was gifted the WOW Gospel 2008 CD. Iâd have my morning pep session, listening to a song on the CD sung by Myron Butler and Levi. âStrongerâ starts off with a guy saying, âUgh, I wasnât really expecting this.â It makes me laugh. What a perfect cancer lament! Then the song goes into, âYou thought the test was gonna take you out, but now youâre stronger than before.â

Toward the end of chemo, my song became Elton Johnâs âStill Standing.â âDid you think this fool could ever win, well look at me, Iâm cominâ back again. . .â

Several years later, I was re-diagnosed, a second time. Working out at the gym, Pat Benatar came belting over the radio: âHit me with your best shot! . . . You donât fight fair - thatâs okay, see if I care. . . Iâll get right back on my feet again.â The song gave me some âumphâ to put into my workout, as I sang this song along in my mind to cancer.

What song brings you through though or scary times of the cancer journey?

<item>
  <title>Who Did You Help Today?</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/22/who-did-you-help-today/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 22 Aug 2013 14:00:30 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1833</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/helpful-happy.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1843" alt="Helpful happy" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/helpful-happy.jpg" width="584" height="584" /></a>

Image credit: Good Search

Every once in a while, a complete stranger, who doesnât know your situation, will touch your heart. I was recently on an airplane for a two and a half hour flight. I got the short straw, and had a middle seat on a full plane. The three of us women shared pleasantries with each other, then wentÂ  back into our personal space.

I had some of my lymph nodes removed during a cancer surgery. Because of that, I wear a compression sleeve as a precaution against lymphedema, which can come when the lymph system is blocked. The compression sleeve compresses/constrains my arm, and helps the lymphatic system work more easily when my arm is being stressed (flying, repetitive motions, lifting weights.)

Just before landing, one of the women pointed to my compression sleeve and asked, âIs that for edema?â I said, âItâs to prevent lymphedema. I had lymph nodes removed, and I wear it when I fly or work out so the lymphatic system doesnât get stressedâso my arm doesnât swell.â

The plane landed in Phoenix, and the three of us women wished each other well before we went our separate ways, each catching a connecting flight. On the way to my gate, I stopped to put my book and sweater into my carry-on, and in the process, my sweater fell. The woman who sat next to me and had asked about my sleeve saw what looked like an ordeal, and came over. Without the tone of pity, but genuine care, she asked, âDo you need any help?â I laughed and said, âIt looks like it, but really, Iâm okay. Thanks.â I got everything in its proper place, and we walked off in the same direction, together before parting ways.

This scenario touched me. A stranger in the same kind of hurry as I, took the time to offer help. The offer wasnât out of pity, or out of her being nosy. I think this brief interaction empowered both of us. Once in a while, the kind act of someone can make such a difference, and yet be brief, effortless, free for them to do.

As I settled into my seat on the next flight, I thought back to the airport sceneâthen my mind jumped to a month earlier. I was at the Portland airport and a man looked confused as he read the monitor showing departures. I asked if he needed help. In very broken English, this French man explained on the way to the USA, he ended up in Portland, Maine. (He was expecting to land in Portland, Oregon.) Now, the day of departure, he couldnât find his flight number on the monitor. I asked to see his ticket. I noticed a small, faint âpâânot âp.m.â, but âp.â

He was at the airport twelve hours before his flight was scheduled to depart. This is when using the 24 hour clock, common in Europe, hospitals and the military,Â isÂ Â wonderful! By using the 24 hour clock, and motions with my watch and finger rotating around the dial, Â I was able to explain to him when his flight would leaveâsome thirteen hours later. I still needed to get through security for my flight, and he had no idea what to do, or how to say it. I pointed out the desk location for him, and in charades, motioned him to hand his ticket to the employee, and point to the âp.â I said, âIâm sorryâ and reached out to pat his arm. He said, âMerci. Go! Flight!â

What goes around, comes around. How has a stranger helped you, doing something brief, effortless and free? How have you helped a stranger with just a few moments, without hassle, or spending a dime?

<item>
  <title>Win a âPink Time Outâ Getaway!</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/26/win-a-pink-time-out-getaway/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 26 Aug 2013 14:00:45 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1847</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/jean-new-smile.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1848" alt="Jean-new-smile" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/jean-new-smile.jpg" width="313" height="352" /></a>

Photo Courtesy: Jean Campbell

If Â you know Jean Campbell, you know her work with No Boobs About it, and Pink Time Out. She's a special lady who gives so much time and effort to women Â transitioning from breast cancer treatment to "Life after breast cancer."

No Boobs About it has its second âPink Time Outâ coming up this December.

Christmas in New York City will be a 3-day NYC getaway for a woman who has

recently completed active treatment for breast cancer and a companion. The

getaway will include a stay at a luxury hotel in mid-Manhattan, tickets to

Radio City Holiday Show, breakfasts, and dinners at elegant restaurants.

This "Pink Time Out" getaway is being sponsored by my former students at

the Allen School for Health Sciences, Brooklyn, NY. Please read all about

it at <a href="http://www.noboobsaboutit.org/">www.noboobsaboutit.org</a>.

The Christmas in NYC recipient will be chosen through a lottery drawing.

The lottery will be open for enrollment October 1st and close October

31st. The lottery drawing will be on November 1. Any woman who has

completed, or will complete active treatment between October 1, 2012 and

October 31, 2013 may enroll in the lottery. For more information, visit

<a href="http://noboobsaboutit.org/pink-time-outs/">http://noboobsaboutit.org/pink-time-outs/</a>.

Why a "Pink Time Out"? Itâs about getting away from all things breast

cancer, putting closure on months of active treatment, and easing the

transition to life in survivorship!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Anger</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/08/29/anger-2/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 29 Aug 2013 14:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1860</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-5024201897871049pid15-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1073" title="mood" alt="" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/http-ts2-mm-bing-netthidi-5024201897871049pid15-1.jpg" width="300" height="199" /></a>Â image credit: Google

&nbsp;

Cancer. Anger. Anxiety. Depression.

&nbsp;

This is a re-post:

Ask your medical team if the cancer treatment you receive can trigger emotional change. Some medications have side effects of possible depression, anger or anxiety. Itâs much easier to deal with these new emotions when you know where itâs coming from. In addition to medication, anger can arise from the process of menopause. Youâre not crazy. Youâre not a horrible person. Your body is used to a certain amount of estrogen and progesterone, and now thatâs gone. Itâs a triple-quadruple whammy: Chemo, surgeries, medication, menopause. (Itâs enough to make you scream, isnât it?)

&nbsp;

Some say anger helps them through cancer. Iâve met some very angry people. Their anger may help <em>them</em>, but that doesnât mean<em> I </em>need to be their target or audience for inappropriate dealings of their anger. Iâm all for tying to understand frustration, and supporting others when we can. This coin has two sides: People encouraging each other. People practicing the life they want.

&nbsp;

Having said this, when someoneâs depressed, they cannot just turn on the switch to joy. It takes time and effort on everyoneâs part. When I was diagnosed with cancer, in factâwith every change and every surgery (6) I found myself at the bottom of the emotional ladder. (Even if it was a new level, I'd be at the lowest rung of that level.) Iâve been a New Thought minister and know the ropes around positive thinking. But, some days I had to allow others to lift me, knowing I was being dark and miserableâand knowing at some level, someday Iâd return to âme.â My mantra was often, âTrust. Float.â (We donât float in water by fighting it. We float by relaxing into it.)

&nbsp;

As I often point out, this isnât about stuffing or internalizing emotions. If youâre angry, go aheadâswear at cancer, punch a pillow, cry, shake your fist at God. Do what feels good. <strong>Then</strong>, move out of anger. It will not serve you to <em>stay</em> there. But, if youâre angry, fearful or sad and you ignore it, youâre asking for trouble. Be present. Know how you feel. Only then can you make a shift to a better feeling. Even just by saying, âI want to feel better.â Itâs like an alert to your body that youâre ready to shift gears. After making that announcement, you can continue with a list of (start with five) things for which youâre grateful. I covered my walls with shelf paper and used felt tips pens for my âWall of Gratitude.â I knew I wouldnât seek out a journal to read or write when I felt awful. This way it was in my constant view, and Iâd get lost in it, reading and thinking, <em>Yes! I really am grateful for that!</em>

&nbsp;

Lean into friends, family, neighbors, support groups, medical team, and counselors. Notice the support around you. I received incredible support from grocery store cashiers, and the general public. Not long after completing chemo, I was at Costco one night in December, buying one box of smoked salmon. That's it. Nothing else. A woman in the line next to me pointed at me, and loud enough to cross the checkout lanes said, âYOU ROCK!â At first I smiled, âThank you.â She said it again with emphasis. I teared up. She understood the absurdity. Costco. Night shopping. Christmas time. <em>One</em> item.

&nbsp;

Cancer is often accompanied with feelings of isolation and loneliness, intensifying with anger. You may storm in and out anger during the few years of cancer treatment. It may continue after treatment is over. Many patients focus on getting back to âthe way it was before.â It may happen, and if not, maybe the change in the long run will be spectacular. As you get fresh air, good sleep, exercise, and healthy food, youâre raising the bar for the new norm. If you need to, get angry. But direct it appropriately, and move on.

&nbsp;

<strong>Related Resources:</strong>

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.cancer.org/index">http://www.cancer.org/index</a></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

1-800-227-2345 English, Spanish, Asian and Pacific Languages. They also have a chat line.

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.cancer.gov/global/contact">http://www.cancer.gov/global/contact</a></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

1-800-4-cancer 1-800-422-6237Â  English, Spanish. They also have a chat line.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

    <wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I'm sorry, but glad it was good timing, and that it helped in some way. If we hold in anger, it festers, and that's no good for health. If we blow up at everyone, including ourselves, it's no good for relationships, including the one each of us have with ourself. If we are honest, we'll look at the cause of anger. Is it fear? (Anger often comes from fear.) Then, release the cause of anger, fear or whatever else it may be, to the extent we can. Without denying your emotions, moving forward is key. Good for you!]]></wp:comment_content>

<item>
  <title>If the shoe fits (autobiography in five short chapters)</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/09/05/if-the-shoe-fits-autobiography-in-five-short-chapters/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 05 Sep 2013 14:00:39 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1864</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/walk.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1866" alt="walk" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/08/walk.jpg" width="300" height="300" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

I love this poem. Whatever your current situation, this may fit. Maybe you're upset over something, maybe you're just ready to approach life from a new angle. (How about a TRY angle?)

If you've been re-diagnosed, and are in the sad, angry, or why-me stage, this could relate to cancer. It's not making those emotions wrong, it's giving you the opportunity to choose empowerment. And it's okay if you don't choose that right away. Emotions must be payed attention to, or they will move from whisper to scream, and that will affect your health even more.

If you're a caregiver, the poem could be for how you play your role. Cancer is a heavy load to walk with someone. Note the word <em>with</em>. You alone, cannot carry this load. Share it. Ask for help. Give yourself "me" time. Lighten up. Love yourself.

Put on your walking shoes...

<strong>Autobiography in five short chapters</strong>

<strong>by Portia Nelson</strong>

&nbsp;

CH 1

I walk down the street.

There is a deep hole in the sidewalk.

I fall in. I am lost...I am helpless.

It isnât my fault.

It takes forever to get out.

&nbsp;

CH 2

I walk down the same street.

There is a deep hole in the sidewalk.

I pretend I donât see it.

I fall in again. I canât believe Iâm in the same place.

But it isnât my fault.

It still takes a long time to get out.

&nbsp;

CH 3

I walk down the same street.

There is a deep hole in the sidewalk.

I see it is there.

I still fall in... itâs a habit.

My eyes are open.

I know where I am.

It is my fault.

I get out immediately.

&nbsp;

CH 4

I walk down the same street.

There is a deep hole in the sidewalk.

I walk around it.

&nbsp;

CH 5

I walk down another street.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1864</wp:post_id>

  <wp:post_date_gmt>2013-09-05 14:00:39</wp:post_date_gmt>
  <wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
  <wp:post_name>if-the-shoe-fits-autobiography-in-five-short-chapters</wp:post_name>
  <wp:status>publish</wp:status>
  <wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
  <wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
  <wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
  <wp:post_password/>
  <wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

  <category domain="category" nicename="caregivers"><![CDATA[Caregivers]]></category>

</item>
<item>
  <title>Happy Labor Day</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/09/02/happy-labor-day/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 02 Sep 2013 14:00:44 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1869</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA["If you were arrested for being good at your job, would they have enough evidence to convict you?" âLeo Buscaglia

Enjoy the day off!

I will be posting but not responding for a few weeks.

  <title>Taking a Break</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/09/09/taking-a-break/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 09 Sep 2013 14:00:41 +0000</pubDate>

  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/timeline_cover_donotrename79.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-661" alt="Timeline_Cover_doNotRename79" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/timeline_cover_donotrename79.png" width="584" height="215" /></a>

Also, Facebook page, Cancer What to Do or Say will still have some posts.

Thank you!]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>TKI1258, BKM120, trial studies for metastatic breast cancer</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/10/17/tki1258-bkm120-trial-studies-for-metastatic-breast-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 17 Oct 2013 14:00:20 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1878</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[There are two studies currently looking for participants. If you are a woman with metastatic breast cancer, and your oncologist hasnât mentioned the studies to you, bring it up with them. I know the studies are being done nationwide right now (fall 2013). I was expected to begin pre-trial base-line markers this month, but I am not in the studies, after all. More in next blog about that, but I wanted to get this information out to those interested.

One study, TKI1258 (TKI) is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled, phase II trial. Itâs being evaluated for the safety and efficacy of TKI in combination with fulvestrant - also known as <a class="zem_slink" title="Fulvestrant" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulvestrant" target="_blank" rel="wikipedia">Faslodex</a> (a shot). The trial will be of <a class="zem_slink" title="Menopause" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menopause" target="_blank" rel="wikipedia">post-menopausal</a> women with Her2, and HR+ breast cancer that have evidence of disease progression on or after [one] prior endocrine therapy.

The other trial study, BKM120, is a phase III randomized, double-blind <a class="zem_slink" title="Placebo-controlled study" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placebo-controlled_study" target="_blank" rel="wikipedia">placebo controlled study</a> with BKM120 with fulvestrant. The participants will be post-menopausal women with hormone receptor positive or Her2-negative, locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer which progressed on or after aromatase inhibitor treatment.

There is expected to be 150 TKI and 1,060 BKM participants in the multi-center studies in the USA. Both studies are by the pharmaceutical company <a class="zem_slink" title="Novartis" href="http://www.novartis.com/" target="_blank" rel="homepage">Novartis</a>. The hospital where I go was looking for five patients for each study. If youâre interested in the study, look into it. It may take them a while to find matches.

Talk with your oncologist. Good luck!]]></content:encoded>

  <title>Diagnosis isnât always black and white</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/10/21/diagnosis-isnt-always-black-and-white/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 21 Oct 2013 14:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1880</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/butterfllyiguana.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1189" alt="ButterfllyIguana" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/butterfllyiguana.jpg" width="584" height="584" /></a></p><p>image credit: Good Search</p><p>If youâve ever had a biopsy come back negative, and not one, but two surgeons come in the room for âthe talkââthen you know sometimes a biopsy can show a negative result, but come back positive after further testing. Unfortunately, that âfurther testingâ is often after surgery, and chopping body parts off, one by one isnât the ideal way to become cancer-free.</p><p>For the past few months, Iâve been in the been in the process of being re-diagnosed. Borrowing from sophisticated theory: if it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck, chances are it is a duck. The only difference in this case is, tests have come back negative. So, technically, itâs not a duckâor cancer. Most people would be doing the âhappy danceââand in the past, I would have done it, too. The only thing stopping me is my memory.</p><p>The first time I had cancer, the biopsy test came back positive. I didnât believe it. I didnât trust the medical field much, either. During treatment, I required another biopsy, which came back negative. The medical staff didnât trust the test results but they gave me the option to leave the bump alone, watching it, knowing I may return someday for it to be removed. They also gave me the option to go ahead and have the second bump removed along with the originally planned surgery for the removal of the first tumor. I opted to have a two-for-one surgery. Tests run after surgery came back positive. It was cancer, but had tested negative before surgery.</p><p>Two years later, at my last appointment with the surgical oncologist who removed cancer the first time, saw a bump near my collar-bone. It tested positive. New treatment for cancer began, again.</p><p>Another two years down the road: I see bumps that look like cancer, feel like cancer, and are located in similar places, just a little higher up. But, tests have come back negative.</p><p>So, What does one do in the meantime? Hereâs what I suggest: keep a (positive, strong) song in your heart, whistle a happy tune, and think, do and be kind.</p><p>âOh, and maybe thatâs what we all should doâbefore, during and after any type of diagnosis.</p><p>&nbsp;</p>]]></content:encoded>

<item>
  <title>Metastatic Cancer.</title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/metastatic-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Thu, 24 Oct 2013 14:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1884</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/crunchy-on-the-outside-chewey-on-the-inside.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1885" alt="Crunchy on the outside; chewey on the inside" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/crunchy-on-the-outside-chewey-on-the-inside.jpg" width="584" height="389" /></a>

image credit: Good Search

Before getting into the postâwhat's worse, a camel biting your head off, or your sister laughing at your plight? This picture reminds me that fretting about cancer is rather silly. I mean, <em>now</em> I'm lookin' over my shoulder for camels in the office on Wednesdays! Heads up!

The appointment after I received the negative biopsy results, I got the bone density scan and blood test results. The bone density scan came back showing lower levels of bone densityâand the blood test came back showing elevated calcium levels. Those are two contradicting results, and neither is a result you want to hear.

Those opposing results led my oncologist to order a bone scan, which showed a dark mass at my sacrum. To be sure it wasnât a hairline fracture, I had some x-rays. Good news, no hairline fracture. My bones are in great shape. So, the next step was a bone biopsy.

The following week, it was a matter of listening the "It's cancer" all over again. The options, the statisticsâthe whirling noise in my head, searching for answers, and a way out of this situation.

My doctor hoped I was a candidate for two trial studies. I wasnât accepted. The first one would require chemo right off the bat. Patients whoâd had prior chemo, and experienced neuropathy, werenât eligible to participate in this study. That was me. The second study didnât accept me because they were looking for patients whoâd been on a medication that hadnât worked. (We soon learned âaâ meant âoneâ medication. Iâd been on two that hadnât worked.)

There is a third study I did qualify to participate in. Iâve declined to take part. For me, the side effects, the odds, and the requirements of participants werenât a <em>trial</em>, but a <em>sentence</em>. (Can you tell I was called for jury duty recently?)]]></content:encoded>
  <excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
  <wp:post_id>1884</wp:post_id>

  <wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

<item>
  <title>How do you tell your partner, parent or child that you have cancer?  </title>
  <link>https://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/2013/10/28/how-do-you-tell-your-partner-parent-or-child-that-you-have-cancer/</link>
  <pubDate>Mon, 28 Oct 2013 14:00:59 +0000</pubDate>
  <dc:creator>bookoftips</dc:creator>
  <guid isPermaLink="false">http://cancerwhattodoorsay.wordpress.com/?p=1887</guid>
  <description/>
  <content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/th.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1888" alt="th" src="http://cancerwhattodoorsay.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/th.jpeg" width="300" height="213" /></a>Â image credit: Good Search

If you've ever been re-diagnosed with cancer, how did you tell the people who were by your side through cancer before?

Some people openly talk about the concerns they have when they find lumps or bumps. I guess the atmosphere is set up for this a bit more when you live with a partner, parent, or child. OtherÂ  patients bring another person with them to every doctor appointment, or at least the ones they know theyâll be getting information that could change their life.

If you go to the doctor alone, and get the news, âyou have cancerâ or, âcancer is backâ â how do you tell your partner, parent, or child? How do you tell your best friends? Thereâs something that seems to shift when itâs the second re-diagnosis; the third time of cancer.

It was the hardest thing I can recall ever sharing with my parents. It took me weeks to tell each of them, and a month to share with friends, and only as we'd plan to get together for other reasons.

If youâve been tapped on the shoulder by cancer again, maybe you need to sit with the information before sharing it with othersâwhoâll seem to take it personally, and who'll look at you genuinely hurt, shocked, and confused. These are the people youâd never in a million years set out to hurt. Theyâre the one who've pulled for you, and rooted you on during cancer the first, and second time. They celebrated your triumph, and closed the door with you on any thought of cancer coming back. They believed in you when you said, "I'm cancer free" and " I'm done with cancer." These people <i>still</i> believe in you. And for me, thatâs why it was so hard to tell themâagain.

A while back I wrote a post called, âDonât let the diagnosis kill you.â I wrote it before I knew anything of my re-diagnosis. Itâs been a great reminder for me when my mind strays to dark territories. We all die at some point. Thatâs the thing about life: You canât get out alive. But that doesnât mean we (with or without cancer) can mope around about the card(s) weâve been dealt.

Look around you. You have <i>awesome</i> people in your life. You are loved. And by many people, you are loved <i>unconditionally</i>. Think of that! <i>without</i> <i>conditions</i>. Wow. Take it in. Breathe in life. If youâve been re-diagnosed, Iâm sorry. Itâs tough on the psyche as well as the body. But hold your head high, tell your loved ones when and how you can. Keep in mind, youâve had more time to absorb the news than they have.

Iâve always been a staunch believer of telling the truth, and in some cases, that means just telling it quickly. I didnât see this one coming: I was visiting my dad. I thought we had 45 minutes together and alone before we headed out. When I went to confirm, he said, âNo. Weâre leaving in <i>10</i> minutes.â Oooo, not in my plan. I was waiting for my way-too-hot oatmeal to cool down. I still needed to put on make-up, and brush my teeth. I put down my breakfast spoon, mainly to ensure I didnât fling oatmeal anywhere, and kept one eye on the clock.

I quickly apologized for the timing, and for the news itself. ââI have bumps again. Cancer is back.â My voice started to crack, but I was able to rein it right back in. We didnât have time for my that, and it would only hurt my dad more, seeing me drop into a puddle of tears over something he couldnât do anything about. His head lowered. I could see he was going into analytical mode. I picked up my spoon, and began shoveling oatmeal into my mouth, keeping my eye on the clock. âSorry. Itâs sort of complicated. Theyâll do more testing, and Iâll keep you updated. I wanted to tell you face to face.â

Done.

I got up to wash my bowl, put on make-up, and brush my teeth. We left on time.

Wherever you are on this journey. Peace.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
